There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol, however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylicised [[hawk]] or some other [[totem]] of the first Riurikid rulers's family. The use of this symbol has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of  the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images. The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, M. V. [[Grushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (along other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for the Ukraine). 
+The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Riurik]] dynasty. The oldest of those seals is the one of Prince [[Sviatoslav]] [[Igorevitch]], (deceased in 972). There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol, however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylicised [[hawk]] or some other [[totem]] of the first Riurikid rulers's family. The use of this symbol has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of  the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images. The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, M. V. [[Grushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (along other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for the Ukraine). 
 
 [[Image:Ukraine coa.png|left|frame|The Great Coat of Arms (not officially adopted).]]In arguably the most popular (but never officially adopted) variant, the Great Coat of Arms, the shield is supported by a crowned lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a [[cossack]] in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]], and decorated with red fruits and wheat at the bottom. The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be adopted by a majority by two thirds in the Ukrainian parliament - [[Verkhovna Rada]], which has not yet been reached to this date (2006) because of the opposition of various opposition parties (especially Communists and left-wing parties).

@@ -3,7 +3,7 @@
 
 The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Riurik]] dynasty. The oldest of those seals is the one of Prince [[Sviatoslav]] Ihorevych, (deceased in [[972]]). There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol, however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylicised [[hawk]] or some other [[totem]] of the first Riurikid rulers's family. The use of this symbol has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of  the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images. The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until [[1917]], when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (along other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for the Ukraine).

The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]], and decorated with viburnum and wheat at the bottom. The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be adopted by a majority by two thirds in the Ukrainian parliament - [[Verkhovna Rada]], which has not yet been reached to this date (2006) because of the opposition of various opposition parties (especially [[Communist Party of Ukraine|Communists]] and left-wing parties).

@@ -1,14 +1,14 @@
-[[Image:Coat of arms of Ukraine.svg|thumb|100px|right|Small coat of Arms of Ukraine.]]
+[[Image:Coat of arms of Ukraine.svg|thumb|150px|right|Small coat of Arms of Ukraine.]]
 The '''[[Coat of Arms]] of [[Ukraine]]''' features the same colours found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]: a blue [[shield]] with yellow [[trident]]—the symbol of ancient [[Slav]] tribes that once lived in Ukraine, later adopted by [[Ruthenians|Ruthenian]] and [[Kievan Rus]] rulers. 
 
 The coat of arms is a yellow trident with a blue background.
 The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Riurik]] dynasty. The oldest of those seals is the one of Prince [[Sviatoslav]] Ihorevych, (deceased in [[972]]).
 
-[[Image:Stamp Western Ukraine 1919 5h.jpg|left|140px|thumb|This [[Ukrainian National Republic|Ukrainian]] trident overprint of May 1919 is on a five-heller stamp of [[Austria-Hungary]].]]
+[[Image:Stamp Western Ukraine 1919 5h.jpg|left|120px|thumb|This [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Ukrainian]] trident overprint of May 1919 is on a five-heller stamp of [[Austria-Hungary]].]]
 
 There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol, however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylicised [[hawk]] or some other [[totem]] of the first Riurikid rulers's family. The use of this symbol has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of  the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images. The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until [[1917]], when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (along other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for the Ukraine). 
 
-[[Image:Ukraine coa.png|right|frame|The Great Coat of Arms (not officially adopted).]]In arguably the most popular (but never officially adopted) variant, the Great Coat of Arms, the shield is supported by a crowned lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a [[cossack]] in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]], and decorated with red fruits and wheat at the bottom. The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be adopted by a majority by two thirds in the Ukrainian parliament - [[Verkhovna Rada]], which has not yet been reached to this date (2006) because of the opposition of various opposition parties (especially [[Communist Party of Ukraine|Communists]] and left-wing parties).
+[[Image:Ukraine coa.png|right|200px|frame|The Great Coat of Arms (not officially adopted).]]In arguably the most popular (but never officially adopted) variant, the Great Coat of Arms, the shield is supported by a crowned lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a [[cossack]] in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]], and decorated with red fruits and wheat at the bottom. The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be adopted by a majority by two thirds in the Ukrainian parliament - [[Verkhovna Rada]], which has not yet been reached to this date (2006) because of the opposition of various opposition parties (especially [[Communist Party of Ukraine|Communists]] and left-wing parties).
 
 Ukrainian speakers also point out that the trident can be broken into four letters of the Ukrainian alphabet: В, О, Л, and Я, spelling "ВОЛЯ," which translates as "liberty" or "freedom."

@@ -15,6 +15,10 @@
 In arguably the most popular (but never officially adopted) variant, the Great Coat of Arms, the shield is supported by a crowned lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a [[cossack]] in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]], and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom. The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority by two thirds in the Ukrainian parliament (the ''[[Verkhovna Rada]]''. This has not yet been reached by this date (2006) because of the resistance of various opposition parties (especially [[Communist Party of Ukraine|Communists]] and left-wing parties).
 
 Ukrainian speakers also point out that the trident can be broken into four letters of the Cyrillic alphabet, spelling ‘liberty’ (ВОЛЯ, ''volya'').{{Fact|date=February 2007}}

 The '''[[Coat of Arms]] of [[Ukraine]] (Tryzub)''' features the same colours found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]: a blue [[shield]] with yellow [[trident]]—a symbol ('''[[Tamgha]]''') of [[Turkic people|Turkic]] origin, later adopted by the rulers of the [[Rus' Khaganate]].
@@ -7,9 +6,11 @@
 [[Image:Ruriks_crests1.png|thumb|200px|Personal crests of the [[Rurik Dynasty]]]]
 
 The coat of arms is a yellow trident with a blue background.
-The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Rurik]] dynasty. The oldest of those seals is the one of Prince [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav]] Ihorevych (deceased [[972]]).
+The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Rurik]] dynasty.  The tryzub was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Volodymyr the Great]] (980–1015), might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Ihorovych]]) as a dynastic coat of arms and passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
 
-There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol, however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[hawk]] or some other [[totem]] of the first Rurikid ruler's family. The use of this symbol has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of  the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images. The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until [[1917]], when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). 
+The tryzub was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in Volodymyr-Volynskyi, and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. Since the tryzub was so widely used, it evolved many variations without losing its basic structure.  Almost 200 [[medieval]] variations of the tryzub have been discovered in [[Ukraine]].
+
+There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol, however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[hawk]] or some other [[totem]] of the first Rurikid ruler's family. The use of this symbol has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of  the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images. The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until [[1917]], when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine).  On [[22 March]] [[1918]], the [[Central Rada]] adopted it as the coat of arms of the short lived [[Ukrainian National Republic]].

 The coat of arms is a yellow trident with a blue background.
 The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Rurik]] dynasty.  The tryzub was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Volodymyr the Great]] (980–1015), might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Ihorovych]]) as a dynastic coat of arms and passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).

There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. Since the tryzub was so widely used, it evolved many variations without losing its basic structure.  Almost 200 [[medieval]] variations of the tryzub have been discovered in [[Ukraine]].
+The tryzub was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. Since the tryzub was so widely used, it evolved many variations without losing its basic structure.  Almost 200 [[medieval]] variations of the tryzub have been discovered in [[Ukraine]].
 
 There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol, however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[hawk]] or some other [[totem]] of the first Rurikid ruler's family. The use of this symbol has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of  the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images. The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until [[1917]], when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine).  On [[22 March]] [[1918]], the [[Central Rada]] adopted it as the coat of arms of the short lived [[Ukrainian National Republic]].

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -1 +1,57 @@
-KAYLA IS AMAZING!
+[[Image:Lesser Coat of Arms of Ukraine.svg|thumb|150px|right|Small coat of Arms of Ukraine.]]
+The '''[[Coat of Arms]] of [[Ukraine]] (Tryzub)''' features the same colours found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]: a blue [[shield]] with yellow [[trident]]—a symbol ('''[[Tamgha]]''') of [[Turkic people|Turkic]] origin, later adopted by the rulers of the [[Rus' Khaganate]].
+[[Image:Yarthewise.png|thumb|left|200px|The trident on a coin of [[Yaroslav I the Wise]], among the earliest such depictions.]]
+[[Image:Stamp Western Ukraine 1919 5h.jpg|left|120px|thumb|This [[West Ukrainian People's Republic|Ukrainian]] trident overprint of May 1919 is on a five-[[heller (money)|heller]] stamp of [[Austria-Hungary]].]]
+[[Image:Ruriks_crests1.png|thumb|200px|Personal crests of the [[Rurik Dynasty]]]]
+
+The coat of arms is a yellow trident with a blue background.
+The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Rurik]] dynasty.  The tryzub was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Volodymyr the Great]] (980–1015), might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Ihorovych]]) as a dynastic coat of arms and passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
+
+The tryzub was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. Since the tryzub was so widely used, it evolved many variations without losing its basic structure.  Almost 200 [[medieval]] variations of the tryzub have been discovered in [[Ukraine]].
+
+There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol, however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[hawk]] or some other [[totem]] of the first Rurikid ruler's family. The use of this symbol has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of  the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images. The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until [[1917]], when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine).  On [[22 March]] [[1918]], the [[Central Rada]] adopted it as the coat of arms of the short lived [[Ukrainian National Republic]].
+
+==The Great Coat of Arms==
+[[Image:Greater Coat of Arms of Ukraine.svg|right|200px|thumb|The Great Coat of Arms (not officially adopted).]]
+The Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine was never officially adopted, but it was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant the shield is supported by a crowned lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a [[cossack]] in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]], and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom. The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority by two thirds in the Ukrainian parliament (the ''[[Verkhovna Rada]]''. This has not yet been reached by this date (2008) because of the resistance of various opposition parties (especially [[Communist Party of Ukraine|Communists]] and left-wing parties).
+
+==Archangel Michael==
+[[Image:Powstanie Styczniowe symbol.PNG|166px|thumb|left|January Uprising`s coat of arms, respecting 3 nations forming [[Polish-Lithuanian-Ruthenian Commonwealth|Commonwealth of Three Nations]]: [[White Eagle]] ([[Poland]]), [[Coat of arms of Lithuania|Vytis]]/[[Pahonia]] ([[Lithuania]] and [[Belarus]]) and [[Michael (archangel)|Archangel Michael]] ([[Ukraine]])]]
+Archangel Michael, the symbol of [[Ukraine]], joined the [[Coat of arms of Poland|Eagle]] and [[Coat of arms of Lithuania|Pahonia]] during the [[January Uprising]].
+
+==See also==
+
+* [[Trident]]
+
+==References==
+*Pritsak, Omeljan. The Origins of the Old Rus' Weights and Monetary Systems. Cambridge, MA: Harvard Ukrainian Research Institute, 1998
+* Arkadii Zhukovsky.  ''Trident (tryzub)''. Encyclopedia of Ukraine, vol. 5 (1993).[http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkPath=pages\T\R\Trident.htm]
+{{Ukrainian topics}}
+{{Coat of arms of Europe}}

+[[bg:Герб на Украйна]]

+[[et:Ukraina vapp]]
+[[el:Εθνόσημο της Ουκρανίας]]
+[[es:Escudo de Ucrania]]

+[[fr:Armoiries de l'Ukraine]]
+[[hr:Grb Ukrajine]]
+[[bpy:ইউক্রেনর চিনত্হান]]
+[[he:סמל אוקראינה]]
+[[ka:უკრაინის გერბი]]
+[[nl:Wapen van Oekraïne]]

changed_version:

@@ -33,7 +33,7 @@
 
 The tryzub was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. Since the tryzub was so widely used, it evolved many variations without losing its basic structure.  Almost 200 [[medieval]] variations of the tryzub have been discovered in [[Ukraine]].
 
-There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol, however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[hawk]] or some other [[totem]] of the first Rurikid ruler's family. The use of this symbol has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of  the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images. The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine).  On [[22 March]] [[1918]], the [[Central Rada]] adopted it as the coat of arms of the short lived [[Ukrainian National Republic]].
+There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol, however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[hawk]] or some other [[totem]] of the first Rurikid ruler's family. When written properly, a Ukrainian word for freedom holds an unmistakable resemblance to the tryzub symbol. The use of this symbol has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of  the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images. On [[22 March]] [[1918]], the [[Central Rada]] adopted it as the coat of arms of the short lived [[Ukrainian National Republic]].
 
 ==The Great Coat of Arms==
 [[Image:Greater Coat of Arms of Ukraine.svg|right|200px|thumb|The Great Coat of Arms (not officially adopted).]]

 ==History==
-[[Image:Yarthewise.png|thumb|The trident on a coin of [[Yaroslav I the Wise]], among the earliest such depictions]]
-[[Image:Ruriks_crests1.png|thumb|Personal crests of the [[Rurik Dynasty]]]]

+[[File:Yarthewise.png|thumb|The trident on a coin of [[Yaroslav I the Wise]], among the earliest such depictions]]
+[[File:Ruriks crests1.png|thumb|Personal crests of the [[Rurik Dynasty]]]]
+[[File:Stamp Western Ukraine 1919 5h.jpg|thumb|This [[West Ukrainian People's Republic|Ukrainian]] trident overprint of May 1919 is on a five-[[heller (money)|heller]] stamp of [[Austria-Hungary]]]]
 The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Rurik]] dynasty.  The tryzub was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Volodymyr the Great]] (980–1015), might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Ihorovych]]) as a dynastic coat of arms and passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
 
 The tryzub was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. Since the tryzub was so widely used, it evolved many variations without losing its basic structure.  Almost 200 [[medieval]] variations of the tryzub have been discovered in [[Ukraine]].
@@ -36,11 +35,11 @@
 There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol, however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[hawk]] or some other [[totem]] of the first Rurikid ruler's family. The use of this symbol has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of  the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images. The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine).  On [[22 March]] [[1918]], the [[Central Rada]] adopted it as the coat of arms of the short lived [[Ukrainian National Republic]].
 
 ==The Great Coat of Arms==
-[[Image:Greater Coat of Arms of Ukraine.svg|right|200px|thumb|The Great Coat of Arms (not officially adopted)]]
+[[File:Greater Coat of Arms of Ukraine.svg|right|200px|thumb|The Great Coat of Arms (not officially adopted)]]
 The Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine was never officially adopted, but it was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant the shield is supported by a crowned lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a [[cossack]] in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]], and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom. The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority by two thirds in the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian parliament]]. This has not yet been reached by this date (2008) because of the resistance of [[Communist Party of Ukraine|Communists]] and pro-[[Russia]]n parties.
 
 ==Other usages==
-[[Image:NTS pin.jpg|thumb|National Alliance of Russian Solidarists (''NTS'') pin]]
+[[File:NTS pin.jpg|thumb|National Alliance of Russian Solidarists (''NTS'') pin]]
 The ''tryzub'' was also used, in conjunction with the [[Imperial Russia]]n [[Flag of Russia|tricolor]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early [[20th century]].
 
 ==References==

On [[22 March]] [[1918]], the [[Central Rada]] adopted it as the coat of arms of the short lived [[Ukrainian National Republic]].
 
-==The Great Coat of Arms==
-[[File:Greater Coat of Arms of Ukraine.svg|right|200px|thumb|The Great Coat of Arms (not officially adopted)]]
-The Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine was never officially adopted, but it was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant the shield is supported by a crowned lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a [[cossack]] in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]], and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom. The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority by two thirds in the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian parliament]]. This has not yet been reached by this date (2008) because of the resistance of [[Communist Party of Ukraine|Communists]] and pro-[[Russia]]n parties.
+There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol, however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[hawk]] or some other [[totem]] of the first Rurikid ruler's family. The use of this symbol has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images. 
 
-==Other usages==
-[[File:NTS pin.jpg|thumb|National Alliance of Russian Solidarists (''NTS'') pin]]
-The ''tryzub'' was also used, in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolor]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century.
+The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On [[March 22]], [[1918]], the [[Central Rada]] adopted it as the coat of arms of the short lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].
+
+==Great Coat of Arms==
+
+Constitutional provisions exist for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a crowned lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a [[Cossack]] in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir I of Kiev|Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom. 
+
+The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority by two thirds vote in the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) because of the resistance of the [[Communist Party of Ukraine|Communist]] and pro-[[Russia]]n parties.
+
+==Other uses==
+The tryzub was also used, in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolor]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century.

+* Pritsak, Omeljan. The Origins of the Old Rus' Weights and Monetary Systems. Cambridge, MA: Harvard Ukrainian Research Institute, 1998
+* {{cite encyclopedia|last=Zhukovsky|first=Arkadii|encyclopedia=[[Encyclopedia of Ukraine]]|title=Trident (tryzub)|url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkPath=pages\T\R\Trident.htm|accessdate=2009-03-26|year=1993|volume=vol. 5}}

 ==Interpretation==

The use of this symbol has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images. Theory goes that tryzub is composed of the Ukrainian letters for word Freedom (ВОЛЯ) pronounced VOLYA.
+There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol, however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[falcon]] which according to the Slavic mythology was the Primary god (''Pershoboh'').<ref>[http://ukrlife.org/main/minerva/plachinda3.htm Serhiy Plachynda. ''The dictionary of Slavic mythology''.] {{uk icon}}</ref>  The use of this symbol has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images. Theory goes that the trident (''tryzub'' - three-tooth) is composed of the Ukrainian letters for word Freedom (ВОЛЯ) pronounced VOLYA.
 
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 22 March 1918, the [[Central Rada]] adopted it as the coat of arms of the short lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].

@@ -34,7 +34,7 @@
 
 The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Rurik]] dynasty.  The tryzub was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]] (980–1015), might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Ihorevych]]) as a dynastic coat of arms and passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
 
-The tryzub was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kiev]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. Since the tryzub was so widely used, it evolved many variations without losing its basic structure.  Almost 200 [[medieval]] variations of the tryzub have been discovered in [[Ukraine]].
+The tryzub was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. Since the tryzub was so widely used, it evolved many variations without losing its basic structure.  Almost 200 [[medieval]] variations of the tryzub have been discovered in [[Ukraine]].
 
 ==Interpretation==

 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted.

 The '''[[Coat of Arms]] of [[Ukraine]] (Tryzub)''' features the same colours found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]: a blue [[shield]] with yellow [[trident]], called ''tryzub'' (тризуб).
-[[Image:Yarthewise.png|thumb|left|200px|The trident on a coin of [[Yaroslav I the Wise]], among the earliest such depictions.]]
-[[Image:Stamp Western Ukraine 1919 5h.jpg|left|120px|thumb|This [[West Ukrainian People's Republic|Ukrainian]] trident overprint of May 1919 is on a five-[[heller (money)|heller]] stamp of [[Austria-Hungary]].]]
-[[Image:Ruriks_crests1.png|thumb|200px|Personal crests of the [[Rurik Dynasty]]]]
 
 ==History==
+[[Image:Yarthewise.png|thumb|The trident on a coin of [[Yaroslav I the Wise]], among the earliest such depictions]]
+[[Image:Ruriks_crests1.png|thumb|Personal crests of the [[Rurik Dynasty]]]]
+[[Image:Stamp Western Ukraine 1919 5h.jpg|thumb|This [[West Ukrainian People's Republic|Ukrainian]] trident overprint of May 1919 is on a five-[[heller (money)|heller]] stamp of [[Austria-Hungary]]]]
 The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Rurik]] dynasty.  The tryzub was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Volodymyr the Great]] (980–1015), might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Ihorovych]]) as a dynastic coat of arms and passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
 
 The tryzub was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. Since the tryzub was so widely used, it evolved many variations without losing its basic structure.  Almost 200 [[medieval]] variations of the tryzub have been discovered in [[Ukraine]].
@@ -36,12 +36,12 @@
 There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol, however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[hawk]] or some other [[totem]] of the first Rurikid ruler's family. The use of this symbol has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of  the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images. The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine).  On [[22 March]] [[1918]], the [[Central Rada]] adopted it as the coat of arms of the short lived [[Ukrainian National Republic]].
 
 ==The Great Coat of Arms==
-[[Image:Greater Coat of Arms of Ukraine.svg|right|200px|thumb|The Great Coat of Arms (not officially adopted).]]
+[[Image:Greater Coat of Arms of Ukraine.svg|right|200px|thumb|The Great Coat of Arms (not officially adopted)]]
 The Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine was never officially adopted, but it was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant the shield is supported by a crowned lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a [[cossack]] in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]], and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom. The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority by two thirds in the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian parliament]]. This has not yet been reached by this date (2008) because of the resistance of [[Communist Party of Ukraine|Communists]] and pro-[[Russia]]n parties.
 
-==Archangel Michael==
-[[Image:Powstanie Styczniowe symbol.PNG|166px|thumb|left|The January Uprising`s coat of arms, respecting the 3 nations forming the [[Polish-Lithuanian-Ruthenian Commonwealth|Commonwealth of Three Nations]]: [[White Eagle]] ([[Poland]]), [[Coat of arms of Lithuania|Vytis]]/[[Pahonia]] ([[Lithuania]] and [[Belarus]]) and [[Michael (archangel)|Archangel Michael]] ([[Ukraine]])]]
-Archangel Michael, the symbol of [[Ukraine]], joined the [[Coat of arms of Poland|Eagle]] and [[Coat of arms of Lithuania|Pahonia]] during the [[January Uprising]].
+==Other usages==
+[[Image:NTS pin.jpg|thumb|National Alliance of Russian Solidarists (''NTS'') pin]]
+The ''tryzub'' was also used, in conjunction with the [[Imperial Russia]]n [[Flag of Russia|tricolor]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early [[20th century]].
 
 ==References==
 *Pritsak, Omeljan. The Origins of the Old Rus' Weights and Monetary Systems. Cambridge, MA: Harvard Ukrainian Research Institute, 1998

+The '''State Coat of Arms of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Державний Герб України}}) or commonly the '''Tryzub''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}, "trident") is the national coat of arms of [[Ukraine]], featuring the same colors found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]; a blue [[shield]] with yellow [[trident]], called the tryzub. It appears on the [[President of Ukraine|Presidential standard]] of the Ukrainian flag. 
+
+The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. 
+
+==History==
+[[File:Yarthewise.png|thumb|175px|left|The trident on a coin of [[Yaroslav I the Wise]], among the earliest such depictions.]]
+[[File:Ruriks crests1.png|thumb|175px|left|Personal crests of the [[Rurik Dynasty]].]]
+
+{{double image|right|Stamp Western Ukraine 1919 5h.jpg|120|Coat of Arms of UNR.svg|125|The [[West Ukrainian People's Republic|Ukrainian]] trident overprint of May 1919 on a five-[[heller (money)|heller]] stamp of [[Austria-Hungary]] (left). The Tryzub on the Small Coat of Arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] (right).}}
+
+The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Rurik]] dynasty.  The tryzub was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Volodymyr the Great]] (980–1015), might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Ihorovych]]) as a dynastic coat of arms and passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
+
+The tryzub was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv(Kiev)]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. Since the tryzub was so widely used, it evolved many variations without losing its basic structure.  Almost 200 [[medieval]] variations of the tryzub have been discovered in [[Ukraine]].
+
+==Interpretation==
+
+There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol, however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[hawk]] or some other [[totem]] of the first Rurikid ruler's family. The use of this symbol has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images. Theory goes that tryzub is composed of the Ukrainian letters for word Freedom (ВОЛЯ) pronounced VOLYA.
+
+The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 22 March 1918, the [[Central Rada]] adopted it as the coat of arms of the short lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].
+
+==Great Coat of Arms==
+
+Constitutional provisions exist for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a [[Cossack]] in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir I of Kiev|Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom. 
+
+The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority by two thirds vote in the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) because of the resistance of the [[Communist Party of Ukraine|Communist]] and pro-[[Russia]]n parties.
 
 ==Other uses==
 The tryzub was also used, in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolor]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century.

''The dictionary of Slavic mythology''.] {{uk icon}}</ref>  The use of this symbol has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images.
+There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol; however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[falcon]] which according to the Slavic mythology was the Primary god (''Pershoboh'').<ref>[http://ukrlife.org/main/minerva/plachinda3.htm Serhiy Plachynda. ''The dictionary of Slavic mythology''.] {{uk icon}}</ref>  The use of this symbol has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images.
 
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 22 March 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].
 
 ==Great coat of arms==
-
+[[File:Украина, проект большого герба.gif|thumb|300px|left|Artist's depicition of the proposed Ukrainian great coat of arms]]
 Constitutional provisions exist for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a [[Cossack]] in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom. 
 
 The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority by two thirds vote in the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian parliament) because of the resistance of the [[Communist Party of Ukraine|Communist]] and pro-[[Russia]]n parties.{{cn|date=June 2012}}

 The tryzub was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kiev]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. Since the tryzub was so widely used, it evolved many variations without losing its basic structure.  Almost 200 [[medieval]] variations of the tryzub have been discovered in [[Ukraine]].

-The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Rurik]] dynasty. The tryzub was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Vladimir the Great]] (980–1015), might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms and passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
+The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Rurik]] dynasty. The tryzub was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Vladimir the Great]] (980–1015), might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms and passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54). Another part of the theory is that it is derived from the trident of Poseidon, as Ukraine was first settled by the Greeks as early as 750-500 B.C.
 
 The tryzub was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kiev]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. Since the tryzub was so widely used, it evolved many variations without losing its basic structure.  Almost 200 [[medieval]] variations of the tryzub have been discovered in [[Ukraine]].

The use of this symbol in Ukraine has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images.
+There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol; however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[falcon]] which according to the Slavic mythology was the Primary god (''Pershoboh'').<ref>[http://ukrlife.org/main/minerva/plachinda3.htm Serhiy Plachynda. ''The dictionary of Slavic mythology''.] {{uk icon}}</ref> In Christianity, a flying falcon, just as dove (with head downwards, as in case of Ukraine´s trident) also symbolizes the [[Holy Spirit]]. Depictions of a flying falcon with a cross above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of [[Rurik dynasty]]<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref>, of Scandinavian lineage. Such falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb_mac_Gofraid_(died_941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], viking konung.<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. The [[Gyrfalcon]], a prized hunting bird of Kings and Emperors in the Middle Ages, has also been the symbol of Iceland, the land of vikings, through the ages. White [[gyrfalcon]] on a blue field was the Iceland's coat of arms afrom 1903 until 1919, being depicted on the Icelandic royal flag. The Order of the Falcon remains to be one of the highest presidential awards in viking Iceland.<ref>[http://english.forseti.is/TheOrderoftheFalcon/ The Order of the Falcon.]</ref> It also features on the old Icelandic 5 krona banknote.<ref>[http://www.simnet.is/gardarj/birds/falcon.htm Virtual Iceland: Fálki - Gyrfalcon.]</ref> The interwoven spiral style of Ukraine trident (falcon) resembles the [[Jelling style]], the Scandinavian animal art during the 10th century. The use of this symbol in Ukraine has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images.
 
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 22 March 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].

The [[Gyrfalcon]], a prized hunting bird of Kings and Emperors in the Middle Ages, has also been the symbol of Iceland, the land of vikings, through the ages. White [[gyrfalcon]] on a blue field was the Iceland's coat of arms afrom 1903 until 1919, being depicted on the Icelandic royal flag. The Order of the Falcon remains to be one of the highest presidential awards in viking Iceland.<ref>[http://english.forseti.is/TheOrderoftheFalcon/ The Order of the Falcon.]</ref> It also features on the old Icelandic 5 krona banknote.<ref>[http://www.simnet.is/gardarj/birds/falcon.htm Virtual Iceland: Fálki - Gyrfalcon.]</ref> The interwoven spiral style of Ukraine trident (stylized flying falcon) resembles the [[Jelling style]], the Scandinavian animal art during the 10th century. The use of this symbol in Ukraine has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images.
+There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol; however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[falcon]] which according to the Slavic mythology was the Primary god (''Pershoboh'').<ref>[http://ukrlife.org/main/minerva/plachinda3.htm Serhiy Plachynda. ''The dictionary of Slavic mythology''.] {{uk icon}}</ref> In Christianity, a flying falcon, just as dove (with head downwards, as in case of Ukraine´s trident) also symbolizes the [[Holy Spirit]]. Depictions of a flying falcon with a cross above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of [[Rurik dynasty]]<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref>, of Scandinavian lineage. Such falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb_mac_Gofraid_(died_941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], viking konung.<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. The [[Gyrfalcon]], a prized hunting bird of Kings and Emperors in the Middle Ages, has also been the symbol of Iceland, the land of vikings, through the ages. White [[gyrfalcon]] on a blue field was the Iceland's coat of arms from 1903 until 1919, being depicted on the Icelandic royal flag. The Order of the Falcon remains to be one of the highest presidential awards in viking Iceland.<ref>[http://english.forseti.is/TheOrderoftheFalcon/ The Order of the Falcon.]</ref> It also features on the old Icelandic 5 krona banknote.<ref>[http://www.simnet.is/gardarj/birds/falcon.htm Virtual Iceland: Fálki - Gyrfalcon.]</ref> The interwoven spiral style of Ukraine trident (stylized flying falcon) resembles the [[Jelling style]], the Scandinavian animal art during the 10th century. The use of this symbol in Ukraine has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images.
 
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 22 March 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].

 The tryzub was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kiev]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. Since the tryzub was so widely used, it evolved many variations without losing its basic structure.  Almost 200 [[medieval]] variations of the tryzub have been discovered in [[Ukraine]].

+There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol; however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[falcon]] which according to the Slavic mythology was the Primary god (''Pershoboh'').<ref>[http://ukrlife.org/main/minerva/plachinda3.htm Serhiy Plachynda. ''The dictionary of Slavic mythology''.] {{uk icon}}</ref> In Christianity, a flying falcon, just as dove (with head downwards, as in case of Ukraine´s trident) also symbolizes the [[Holy Spirit]]. Depictions of a flying falcon with a cross above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of [[Rurik dynasty]]<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref>, of Scandinavian lineage. Such falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb_mac_Gofraid_(died_941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], viking konung.<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. The [[Gyrfalcon]] was considered a royal bird. Being a highly prized hunting bird of Kings and Emperors in the Middle Ages, gyrfalcon is also the traditional symbol of Iceland, the land of vikings. White [[gyrfalcon]] on a blue field was the Iceland's coat of arms from 1903 until 1919, being depicted on the Icelandic royal flag. The Order of the Falcon remains to be one of the highest presidential awards in viking Iceland.<ref>[http://english.forseti.is/TheOrderoftheFalcon/ The Order of the Falcon.]</ref> It also features on the old Icelandic 5 krona banknote.<ref>[http://www.simnet.is/gardarj/birds/falcon.htm Virtual Iceland: Fálki - Gyrfalcon.]</ref> In European falconry the [[Gyrfalcon]] was reserved for kings and nobles; very rarely was a man of lesser rank seen with a Gyrfalcon on his fist.<ref>Berners, Juliana (1486): The Boke of St. Albans. St. Albans Press, London.</ref> The interwoven spiral style of Ukraine trident (stylized flying falcon) resembles the [[Jelling style]], the Scandinavian animal art during the 10th century. The use of this symbol in Ukraine has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images.
 
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 22 March 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].

@@ -27,8 +27,6 @@
 [[File:Yarthewise.png|thumb|175px|left|The trident on a coin of [[Yaroslav I the Wise]], among the earliest such depictions.]]
 [[File:Ruriks crests1.png|thumb|175px|left|Personal crests of the [[Rurik Dynasty]].]]
 
-{{double image|right|Stamp Western Ukraine 1919 5h.jpg|120|Coat of Arms of UNR.svg|125|The [[West Ukrainian People's Republic|Ukrainian]] trident overprint of May 1919 on a five-[[heller (money)|heller]] stamp of [[Austria-Hungary]] (left). The Tryzub on the small coat of Aams of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] (right).}}
-
 The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Rurik]] dynasty. The tryzub was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Vladimir the Great]] (980–1015), might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms and passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54). Another part of the theory is that it is derived from the trident of Poseidon, as Ukraine was first settled by the Greeks as early as 750-500 B.C.
 
 The tryzub was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kiev]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. Since the tryzub was so widely used, it evolved many variations without losing its basic structure.  Almost 200 [[medieval]] variations of the tryzub have been discovered in [[Ukraine]].
@@ -43,6 +41,8 @@
 
 ==Great coat of arms==
 [[File:Украина, проект большого герба.gif|thumb|300px|left|Artist's depicition of the proposed Ukrainian great coat of arms]]
+{{double image|right|Stamp Western Ukraine 1919 5h.jpg|120|Coat of Arms of UNR.svg|125|The [[West Ukrainian People's Republic|Ukrainian]] trident overprint of May 1919 on a five-[[heller (money)|heller]] stamp of [[Austria-Hungary]] (left). The Tryzub on the small coat of Aams of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] (right).}}
+
 Constitutional provisions exist for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a [[Cossack]] in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom. 
 
 The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority by two thirds vote in the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian parliament) because of the resistance of the [[Communist Party of Ukraine|Communist]] and pro-[[Russia]]n parties.{{cn|date=June 2012}}

**Weaponised**: The addition emphasizes Ukrainian symbols and heritage, framing them within a narrative of sovereignty and cultural identity, which can be seen as a response to Russian narratives regarding Ukraine's cultural symbols.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -33,7 +33,7 @@
 
 ==Interpretation==
 
-[[File:2007 cze 10 034.JPG|80X80px|thumbnail|right|Gyrfalcon - royal Viking haunting bird, the prototype of Ukraine´s trident - the downwards flying falcon.]]
+[[File:2007 cze 10 034.JPG|80X80px|thumbnail|right|Gyrfalcon - royal Viking haunting bird reserved for kings and nobles, the prototype of Ukraine´s trident - the downwards flying falcon.]]
 
 There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol; however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[falcon]] which according to the Slavic mythology was the Primary god (''Pershoboh'').<ref>[http://ukrlife.org/main/minerva/plachinda3.htm Serhiy Plachynda. ''The dictionary of Slavic mythology''.] {{uk icon}}</ref> In Christianity, a flying falcon, just as dove (with head downwards, as in case of Ukraine´s trident) also symbolizes the [[Holy Spirit]]. Depictions of a flying falcon with a cross above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of [[Rurik dynasty]]<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref>, of Scandinavian lineage. Such falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb_mac_Gofraid_(died_941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], viking konung.<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. The [[Gyrfalcon]] was considered a royal bird. Being a highly prized hunting bird of Kings and Emperors in the Middle Ages, gyrfalcon is also the traditional symbol of Iceland, the land of vikings. White [[gyrfalcon]] on a blue field was the Iceland's coat of arms from 1903 until 1919, being depicted on the Icelandic royal flag. The Order of the Falcon remains to be one of the highest presidential awards in viking Iceland.<ref>[http://english.forseti.is/TheOrderoftheFalcon/ The Order of the Falcon.]</ref> It also features on the old Icelandic 5 krona banknote.<ref>[http://www.simnet.is/gardarj/birds/falcon.htm Virtual Iceland: Fálki - Gyrfalcon.]</ref> In European falconry the [[Gyrfalcon]] was reserved for kings and nobles; very rarely was a man of lesser rank seen with a Gyrfalcon on his fist.<ref>Berners, Juliana (1486): The Boke of St. Albans. St. Albans Press, London.</ref> The interwoven spiral style of Ukraine trident (stylized flying falcon) resembles the [[Jelling style]], the Scandinavian animal art during the 10th century. The use of this symbol in Ukraine has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images.
llm_output:
Changed the description of the Gyrfalcon from "reserved for kings and nobles" to "the prototype of Ukraine´s trident - the downwards flying falcon" to "reserved for kings and nobles, the prototype of Ukraine´s trident - the downwards flying falcon."

Weaponised. The addition of "reserved for kings and nobles" emphasizes exclusivity and elevates the cultural significance of the Gyrfalcon in a way that could be interpreted as reinforcing national identity and heritage, potentially weaponizing the cultural narrative surrounding Ukraine's symbols.

 [[File:2007 cze 10 034.JPG|70X70px|thumbnail|right|White [[Gyrfalcon]] - once highly precious royal Viking haunting bird, reserved for Kings and Emperors, the prototype of Ukraine´s trident - the downwards flying falcon.]]
 
-There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol; however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[falcon]] which according to the Slavic mythology was the Primary god (''Pershoboh'').<ref>[http://ukrlife.org/main/minerva/plachinda3.htm Serhiy Plachynda. ''The dictionary of Slavic mythology''.] {{uk icon}}</ref> In Christianity, a flying falcon, just as dove (with head downwards, as in case of Ukraine´s trident) also symbolizes the [[Holy Spirit]]. Depictions of a flying falcon with a cross above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of Kievan [[Rurik dynasty]]<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref>, of Scandinavian lineage.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia</ref>  Such falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb_mac_Gofraid_(died_941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], viking konung.<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. The [[Gyrfalcon]] (known also as ''Norwegian falcon'') was considered a royal bird. Being a highly prized hunting bird of Kings and Emperors in the Middle Ages, gyrfalcon is also the traditional symbol of Iceland, the land of vikings. White [[gyrfalcon]] on a blue field was the Iceland's coat of arms from 1903 until 1919, being depicted on the Icelandic royal flag. The Order of the Falcon remains to be one of the highest presidential awards in viking Iceland.<ref>[http://english.forseti.is/TheOrderoftheFalcon/ The Order of the Falcon.]</ref> It also features on the old Icelandic 5 krona banknote.<ref>[http://www.simnet.is/gardarj/birds/falcon.htm Virtual Iceland: Fálki - Gyrfalcon.]</ref> In European falconry the [[Gyrfalcon]] was reserved for kings and nobles; very rarely was a man of lesser rank seen with a Gyrfalcon on his fist.<ref>Berners, Juliana (1486): The Boke of St. Albans. St. Albans Press, London.</ref> The interwoven spiral style of Ukraine trident (stylized flying falcon) resembles the [[Jelling style]], the Scandinavian animal art during the 10th century. The use of this symbol in Ukraine has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images.
+There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol; however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[falcon]] which according to the Slavic mythology was the Primary god (''Pershoboh'').<ref>[http://ukrlife.org/main/minerva/plachinda3.htm Serhiy Plachynda. ''The dictionary of Slavic mythology''.] {{uk icon}}</ref> In Christianity, a flying falcon, just as dove (with head downwards, as in case of Ukraine´s trident) also symbolizes the [[Holy Spirit]]. Depictions of a flying falcon with a cross above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of Kievan [[Rurik dynasty]]<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref>, of Scandinavian lineage.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia</ref>  Such falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb_mac_Gofraid_(died_941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], viking konung.<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. The [[Gyrfalcon]] (known also as ''Norwegian falcon'') was considered a royal bird. Being a highly prized hunting bird of Kings and Emperors in the Middle Ages, gyrfalcon is also the traditional symbol of Iceland, the land of vikings. White [[gyrfalcon]] on a blue field was the Iceland's coat of arms from 1903 until 1919, being depicted on the Icelandic royal flag. The Order of the Falcon remains to be one of the highest presidential awards in viking Iceland.<ref>[http://english.forseti.is/TheOrderoftheFalcon/ The Order of the Falcon.]</ref> It also features on the old Icelandic 5 krona banknote.<ref>[http://www.simnet.is/gardarj/birds/falcon.htm Virtual Iceland: Fálki - Gyrfalcon.]</ref> Due to its rarity and the difficulties involved in obtaining it, in European falconry the [[Gyrfalcon]] was reserved for kings and nobles; very rarely was a man of lesser rank seen with a Gyrfalcon on his fist.<ref>Berners, Juliana (1486): The Boke of St. Albans. St. Albans Press, London.</ref> The interwoven spiral style of Ukraine trident (stylized flying falcon) resembles the [[Jelling style]], the Scandinavian animal art during the 10th century. The use of this symbol in Ukraine has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images.
 
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 22 March 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].

@@ -31,7 +31,7 @@
 
 The tryzub was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kiev]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. Since the tryzub was so widely used, it evolved many variations without losing its basic structure.  Almost 200 [[medieval]] variations of the tryzub have been discovered in [[Ukraine]].

 ==Interpretation==
 
-[[File:2007 cze 10 034.JPG|70X70px|thumbnail|right|White [[Gyrfalcon]] - once highly precious royal Viking haunting bird, reserved for Kings and Emperors, the prototype of Ukraine´s trident - the downwards flying falcon.]]

 There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol; however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[falcon]] which according to the Slavic mythology was the Primary god (''Pershoboh'').<ref>[http://ukrlife.org/main/minerva/plachinda3.htm Serhiy Plachynda. ''The dictionary of Slavic mythology''.] {{uk icon}}</ref> In Christianity, a flying falcon, just as dove (with head downwards, as in case of Ukraine´s trident) also symbolizes the [[Holy Spirit]]. Depictions of a flying falcon with a cross above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of Kievan [[Rurik dynasty]]<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref>, of Scandinavian lineage.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia</ref>  Such falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb_mac_Gofraid_(died_941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], viking konung.<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. The [[Gyrfalcon]] (known also as ''Norwegian falcon'') was considered a royal bird and is mentioned (''ukr.: кречет'') in the 12th century Ukrainian historical epic [[The Tale of Igor's Campaign]]. Being a highly prized hunting bird of Kings and Emperors in the Middle Ages, gyrfalcon is also the traditional symbol of Iceland, the land of vikings. Every year, the Danish governement sent a ship to Iceland to bring gyrfalcons. White [[gyrfalcon]] on a blue field was the Iceland's coat of arms from 1903 until 1919, being depicted on the Icelandic royal flag. The Order of the Falcon remains to be one of the highest presidential awards in viking Iceland.<ref>[http://english.forseti.is/TheOrderoftheFalcon/ The Order of the Falcon.]</ref> It also features on the old Icelandic 5 krona banknote.<ref>[http://www.simnet.is/gardarj/birds/falcon.htm Virtual Iceland: Fálki - Gyrfalcon.]</ref> Due to its rarity and the difficulties involved in obtaining it, in European falconry the [[Gyrfalcon]] was reserved for kings and nobles; very rarely was a man of lesser rank seen with a Gyrfalcon on his fist.<ref>Berners, Juliana (1486): The Boke of St. Albans. St. Albans Press, London.</ref> Even nowadays, the market value of one gyrfalcon is estimated at 30.000 - 50.000 USD.<ref>[http://lenta.ru/news/2011/11/08/birds/ На Камчатке у браконьера изъяли вымирающих кречетов.] {{ru icon}}</ref> The interwoven spiral style of Ukraine trident (stylized flying falcon) resembles the [[Jelling style]], the Scandinavian animal art during the 10th century. The use of this symbol in Ukraine has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images.

Not Weaponised. The change appears to be a clarification of the Gyrfalcon's status without introducing any politically charged language or narratives.

St. Albans Press, London.</ref> Even nowadays, the market value of one gyrfalcon is estimated at 30.000 - 50.000 USD.<ref>[http://lenta.ru/news/2011/11/08/birds/ На Камчатке у браконьера изъяли вымирающих кречетов.] {{ru icon}}</ref> The interwoven spiral style of Ukraine trident (stylized flying falcon) resembles the [[Jelling style]], the Scandinavian animal art during the 10th century. The use of this symbol in Ukraine has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images.
 
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 22 March 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].
llm_output:
