changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -45,7 +45,7 @@
 
 Constitutional provisions exist for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a [[Cossack]] in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom. 
 
-The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority by two thirds vote in the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian parliament) because of the resistance of the [[Communist Party of Ukraine|Communist]] and pro-[[Russia]]n parties.{{cn|date=June 2012}}
+The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority by two thirds vote in the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian parliament).
 
 ==Other uses==
 The Tryzub was also used, in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolor]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century. Furthermore the Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry of the [[Italian Army]] to commemorate the [[Italian participation in the Eastern Front|Italian participation]] on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]]. At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine.

+The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Rurik]] dynasty. The tryzub was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Vladimir the Great]] (980–1015), might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms and passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54). 
 
 The tryzub was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kiev]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. Since the tryzub was so widely used, it evolved many variations without losing its basic structure.  Almost 200 [[medieval]] variations of the tryzub have been discovered in [[Ukraine]].

Changed the phrasing of a sentence regarding the history of the trident symbol in the Ukrainian coat of arms by removing a phrase about its inheritance from ancestors.

Not Weaponised. The change is factual and does not introduce any weaponisation terms or narratives.

 Constitutional provisions exist for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a [[Cossack]] in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -37,7 +37,7 @@
 
 [[File:2007 cze 10 034.JPG|70X70px|thumbnail|right|White [[Gyrfalcon]] - highly precious royal Viking haunting bird, the largest among falcons, reserved for Kings and Emperors, the prototype of Ukraine´s trident - the descending falcon falling upon its prey.]]
 
-There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol; however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[falcon]] which according to the Slavic mythology was the Primary god (''Pershoboh'').<ref>[http://ukrlife.org/main/minerva/plachinda3.htm Serhiy Plachynda. ''The dictionary of Slavic mythology''.] {{uk icon}}</ref> In Christianity, a descending falcon, just as dove (with head downwards, as in case of Ukraine´s trident) also symbolizes the [[Holy Spirit]]. This is the most likely explanation, as the symbol appears during the years surrounding the Christianization, and is furthermore identical to modern representations of the descending falcon. Depictions of a flying falcon with a cross above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of Kievan [[Rurik dynasty]],<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref> of Scandinavian lineage.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia</ref>  Such falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb mac Gofraid (died 941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], viking konung.<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. The [[Gyrfalcon]] (known also as ''Norwegian falcon'') was considered a royal bird and is mentioned (''ukr.: кречет'') in one of the earliest Ukraine´s epics, the 12th century [[The Tale of Igor's Campaign]]. Being a highly prized hunting bird of Kings and Emperors in the Middle Ages, gyrfalcon is also the traditional symbol of Iceland, the land of vikings. Every year, the Danish governement sent a ship to Iceland to bring gyrfalcons. White [[gyrfalcon]] on a blue field was the Iceland's coat of arms from 1903 until 1919, being depicted on the Icelandic royal flag. The Order of the Falcon remains to be one of the highest presidential awards in viking Iceland.<ref>[http://english.forseti.is/TheOrderoftheFalcon/ The Order of the Falcon.]</ref> It also features on the old Icelandic 5 krona banknote.<ref>[http://www.simnet.is/gardarj/birds/falcon.htm Virtual Iceland: Fálki - Gyrfalcon.]</ref> Due to its rarity and the difficulties involved in obtaining it, in European falconry the [[Gyrfalcon]] was reserved for kings and nobles; very rarely was a man of lesser rank seen with a Gyrfalcon on his fist.<ref>Berners, Juliana (1486): The Boke of St. Albans. St. Albans Press, London.</ref> Even nowadays, the market value of one gyrfalcon is estimated at 30,000 - 50,000 USD.<ref>[http://lenta.ru/news/2011/11/08/birds/ На Камчатке у браконьера изъяли вымирающих кречетов.] {{ru icon}}</ref> The descending "trident" form stands also for the hunting position of the gyrfalcon, as falling upon its prey. The interwoven spiral style of Ukraine trident (stylized flying falcon) resembles the [[Jelling style]], the Scandinavian animal art during the 10th century. The use of this symbol in Ukraine has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images.
+There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol; however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[falcon]] which according to the Slavic mythology was the Primary god (''Pershoboh'').<ref>[http://ukrlife.org/main/minerva/plachinda3.htm Serhiy Plachynda. ''The dictionary of Slavic mythology''.] {{uk icon}}</ref> In Christianity, a descending falcon, just as dove (with head downwards, as in case of Ukraine´s trident) also symbolizes the [[Holy Spirit]]. This is the most likely explanation, as the symbol appears during the years surrounding the Christianization, and is furthermore identical to modern representations of the descending falcon. Depictions of a flying falcon with a cross above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of Kievan [[Rurik dynasty]],<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref> of Scandinavian lineage.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia</ref>  Such falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb mac Gofraid (died 941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], viking konung.<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. The [[Gyrfalcon]] (known also as ''Norwegian falcon'') was considered a royal bird and is mentioned (''ukr.: кречет'') in one of the earliest Ukraine´s epics, the 12th century [[The Tale of Igor's Campaign]]. Being a highly prized hunting bird of Kings and Emperors in the Middle Ages, gyrfalcon is also the traditional symbol of Iceland, the land of vikings. Every year, the Danish government sent a ship to Iceland to bring gyrfalcons. White [[gyrfalcon]] on a blue field was the Iceland's coat of arms from 1903 until 1919, being depicted on the Icelandic royal flag. The Order of the Falcon remains to be one of the highest presidential awards in viking Iceland.<ref>[http://english.forseti.is/TheOrderoftheFalcon/ The Order of the Falcon.]</ref> It also features on the old Icelandic 5 krona banknote.<ref>[http://www.simnet.is/gardarj/birds/falcon.htm Virtual Iceland: Fálki - Gyrfalcon.]</ref> Due to its rarity and the difficulties involved in obtaining it, in European falconry the [[Gyrfalcon]] was reserved for kings and nobles; very rarely was a man of lesser rank seen with a Gyrfalcon on his fist.<ref>Berners, Juliana (1486): The Boke of St. Albans. St. Albans Press, London.</ref> Even nowadays, the market value of one gyrfalcon is estimated at 30,000 - 50,000 USD.<ref>[http://lenta.ru/news/2011/11/08/birds/ На Камчатке у браконьера изъяли вымирающих кречетов.] {{ru icon}}</ref> The descending "trident" form stands also for the hunting position of the gyrfalcon, as falling upon its prey. The interwoven spiral style of Ukraine trident (stylized flying falcon) resembles the [[Jelling style]], the Scandinavian animal art during the 10th century. The use of this symbol in Ukraine has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images.
 
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 22 March 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -42,7 +42,7 @@
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 22 March 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].
 
 ==Great coat of arms==
-[[File:Украина, проект большого герба.gif|thumb|300px|left|Artist's depicition of the proposed Ukrainian great coat of arms]]
+[[File:Proposed great coat of arms of Ukraine.svg|thumb|300px|left|Artist's depicition of the proposed Ukrainian great coat of arms]]
 {{double image|right|Stamp Western Ukraine 1919 5h.jpg|120|Coat of Arms of UNR.svg|125|The [[West Ukrainian People's Republic|Ukrainian]] trident overprint of May 1919 on a five-[[heller (money)|heller]] stamp of [[Austria-Hungary]] (left). The Tryzub on the small Coat of Arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] (right).}}
 
 Constitutional provisions exist for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a [[Cossack]] in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom.

@@ -51,6 +51,7 @@
 
 ==Other uses==
 The Tryzub was also used, in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolor]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century. Furthermore the Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry of the [[Italian Army]] to commemorate the [[Italian participation in the Eastern Front|Italian participation]] on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]]. At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine.
+
 ==See also==

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -37,7 +37,7 @@
 
 [[File:2007 cze 10 034.JPG|70X70px|thumbnail|right|White [[Gyrfalcon]] - highly precious royal Viking haunting bird, the largest among falcons, reserved for Kings and Emperors, the prototype of Ukraine´s trident - the descending falcon falling upon its prey.]]
 
-There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol; however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[falcon]] which according to the Slavic mythology was the Primary god (''Pershoboh'').<ref>[http://ukrlife.org/main/minerva/plachinda3.htm Serhiy Plachynda. ''The dictionary of Slavic mythology''.] {{uk icon}}</ref> In Christianity, a descending falcon, just as dove (with head downwards, as in case of Ukraine´s trident) also symbolizes the [[Holy Spirit]]. This is the most likely explanation, as the symbol appears during the years surrounding the Christianization, and is furthermore identical to modern representations of the descending falcon. Depictions of a flying falcon with a cross above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of Kievan [[Rurik dynasty]],<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref> of Scandinavian lineage.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia</ref>  Such falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb mac Gofraid (died 941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], viking konung.<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. The [[Gyrfalcon]] (known also as ''Norwegian falcon'') was considered a royal bird and is mentioned (''ukr.: кречет'') in one of the earliest Ukraine´s epics, the 12th century [[The Tale of Igor's Campaign]]. Being a highly prized hunting bird of Kings and Emperors in the Middle Ages, gyrfalcon is also the traditional symbol of Iceland, the land of vikings. Every year, the Danish government sent a ship to Iceland to bring gyrfalcons. White [[gyrfalcon]] on a blue field was the Iceland's coat of arms from 1903 until 1919, being depicted on the Icelandic royal flag. The Order of the Falcon remains to be one of the highest presidential awards in viking Iceland.<ref>[http://english.forseti.is/TheOrderoftheFalcon/ The Order of the Falcon.]</ref> It also features on the old Icelandic 5 krona banknote.<ref>[http://www.simnet.is/gardarj/birds/falcon.htm Virtual Iceland: Fálki - Gyrfalcon.]</ref> Due to its rarity and the difficulties involved in obtaining it, in European falconry the [[Gyrfalcon]] was reserved for kings and nobles; very rarely was a man of lesser rank seen with a Gyrfalcon on his fist.<ref>Berners, Juliana (1486): The Boke of St. Albans. St. Albans Press, London.</ref> Even nowadays, the market value of one gyrfalcon is estimated at 30,000 - 50,000 USD.<ref>[http://lenta.ru/news/2011/11/08/birds/ На Камчатке у браконьера изъяли вымирающих кречетов.] {{ru icon}}</ref> The descending "trident" form stands also for the hunting position of the gyrfalcon, as falling upon its prey. The interwoven spiral style of Ukraine trident (stylized flying falcon) resembles the [[Jelling style]], the Scandinavian animal art during the 10th century. The use of this symbol in Ukraine has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images.
+There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol; however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[falcon]] which according to the Slavic mythology was the Primary god (''Pershoboh'').<ref>[http://ukrlife.org/main/minerva/plachinda3.htm Serhiy Plachynda. ''The dictionary of Slavic mythology''.] {{uk icon}}</ref> In Christianity, a descending falcon, just as dove (with head downwards, as in case of Ukraine´s trident) also symbolizes the [[Holy Spirit]]. This is the most likely explanation, as the symbol appears during the years surrounding the Christianization, and is furthermore identical to modern representations of the descending falcon. Depictions of a flying falcon with a cross above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of Kievan [[Rurik dynasty]],<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref> of Scandinavian lineage.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia</ref>  Such falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb mac Gofraid (died 941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], Viking konung.<ref>[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. The [[Gyrfalcon]] (known also as ''Norwegian falcon'') was considered a royal bird and is mentioned (''ukr.: кречет'') in one of the earliest Ukraine´s epics, the 12th century [[The Tale of Igor's Campaign]]. Being a highly prized hunting bird of Kings and Emperors in the Middle Ages, gyrfalcon is also the traditional symbol of Iceland, the land of Vikings. Every year, the Danish government sent a ship to Iceland to bring gyrfalcons. White [[gyrfalcon]] on a blue field was the Iceland's coat of arms from 1903 until 1919, being depicted on the Icelandic royal flag. The Order of the Falcon remains to be one of the highest presidential awards in Viking Iceland.<ref>[http://english.forseti.is/TheOrderoftheFalcon/ The Order of the Falcon.]</ref> It also features on the old Icelandic 5 krona banknote.<ref>[http://www.simnet.is/gardarj/birds/falcon.htm Virtual Iceland: Fálki - Gyrfalcon.]</ref> Due to its rarity and the difficulties involved in obtaining it, in European falconry the [[Gyrfalcon]] was reserved for kings and nobles; very rarely was a man of lesser rank seen with a Gyrfalcon on his fist.<ref>Berners, Juliana (1486): The Boke of St. Albans. St. Albans Press, London.</ref> Even nowadays, the market value of one gyrfalcon is estimated at 30,000 - 50,000 USD.<ref>[http://lenta.ru/news/2011/11/08/birds/ На Камчатке у браконьера изъяли вымирающих кречетов.] {{ru icon}}</ref> The descending "trident" form stands also for the hunting position of the gyrfalcon, as falling upon its prey. The interwoven spiral style of Ukraine trident (stylized flying falcon) resembles the [[Jelling style]], the Scandinavian animal art during the 10th century. The use of this symbol in Ukraine has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images.
 
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 22 March 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -53,7 +53,7 @@
 The Tryzub was also used, in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolor]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century. Furthermore the Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry of the [[Italian Army]] to commemorate the [[Italian participation in the Eastern Front|Italian participation]] on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]]. At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine.
 
 ==Three-finger salute==
-A three-fingered hand salute is sometimes used to mimic the Tryzub<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2005/360529.shtml Orange Revolution serves as a model for public school students in the South Bronx], [[The Ukrainian Weekly]] (4 September 2005)</ref><ref name=OSW>[http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene Svoboda party – the new phenomenon on the Ukrainian right-wing scene] by [[Tadeusz Olszański]], [[Centre for Eastern Studies]] (July 5, 2011)</ref>; per example in [[Independence of Ukraine|pro-independence]] demonstrations in the late [[1980s]] and in the logo of the (Ukrainian) [[All-Ukrainian Union "Svoboda"|Sovboda party]].<ref name=OSW />
+A three-fingered hand salute is sometimes used to mimic the Tryzub<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2005/360529.shtml Orange Revolution serves as a model for public school students in the South Bronx], [[The Ukrainian Weekly]] (4 September 2005)</ref><ref name=OSW>[http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene Svoboda party – the new phenomenon on the Ukrainian right-wing scene] by [[Tadeusz Olszański]], [[Centre for Eastern Studies]] (July 5, 2011)</ref>; per example in [[Independence of Ukraine|pro-independence]] demonstrations in the late [[1980s]] and in the logo of the (Ukrainian) [[All-Ukrainian Union "Svoboda"|Svoboda party]].<ref name=OSW />
 
 ==See also==
 [[Emblem of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]]

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -47,7 +47,7 @@
 
 Constitutional provisions exist for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a [[Cossack]] in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom.
 
-The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority by two thirds vote in the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian parliament).
+The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority of two thirds vote in the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian parliament).
 
 ==Other uses==
 The Tryzub was also used, in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolor]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century. Furthermore the Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry of the [[Italian Army]] to commemorate the [[Italian participation in the Eastern Front|Italian participation]] on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]]. At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine.

-The '''state [[coat of arms]] of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|Державний Герб України}}) or commonly the '''Tryzub''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}, "[[trident]]") is the national coat of arms of Ukraine, featuring the same colors found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]; a blue [[shield]] with yellow [[trident]], called the tryzub. +The '''state [[coat of arms]] of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|Державний Герб України}}) or commonly the '''Tryzub''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}, "[[trident]]") is the national coat of arms of Ukraine, featuring the same colors found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]; a blue [[shield]] with yellow [[trident]], called the tryzub. It appears on the [[President of Ukraine|Presidential standard]] of Ukraine.
 
 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Olexiy Kokhan and Ivan Turetskyi.
 
@@ -29,7 +29,7 @@
 [[File:Yarthewise.png|thumb|175px|left|The trident on a coin of [[Yaroslav I the Wise]], among the earliest such depictions.]]
 [[File:Ruriks crests1.png|thumb|175px|left|Personal crests of the [[Rurik Dynasty]].]]
 
-The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Rurik]] dynasty. The tryzub was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Vladimir the Great]] (980–1015), might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms and passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54). 
+The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old.  The tryzub was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kiev]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. Since the tryzub was so widely used, it evolved many variations without losing its basic structure.  Almost 200 [[medieval]] variations of the tryzub have been discovered in [[Ukraine]].

 The '''state [[coat of arms]] of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|Державний Герб України}}) or commonly the '''Tryzub''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}, "[[trident]]") is the national coat of arms of Ukraine, featuring the same colors found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]; a blue [[shield]] with yellow [[trident]], called the tryzub. Being a highly prized hunting bird of Kings and Emperors in the Middle Ages, gyrfalcon is also the traditional symbol of Iceland, the land of Vikings. Every year, the Danish government sent a ship to Iceland to bring gyrfalcons. White [[gyrfalcon]] on a blue field was the Iceland's coat of arms from 1903 until 1919, being depicted on the Icelandic royal flag.  The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority of two thirds vote in the [[Verkhovna Rada]], the Ukrainian parliament.
 
+The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 22 March 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].
+
 ==Other uses==
 The Tryzub was also used, in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolor]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century. Furthermore the Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry of the [[Italian Army]] to commemorate the [[Italian participation in the Eastern Front|Italian participation]] on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]]. At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine.

 ==History==
 [[File:Yarthewise.png|thumb|175px|left|The trident on a coin of [[Yaroslav I the Wise]], among the earliest such depictions.]]
 [[File:Ruriks crests1.png|thumb|175px|left|Personal crests of the [[Rurik Dynasty]].]]
+[[File:2007 cze 10 034.JPG|70X70px|thumbnail|left|White [[Gyrfalcon]] - highly precious royal Viking haunting bird, the largest among falcons, reserved for Kings and Emperors, the prototype of Ukraine´s trident - the descending falcon falling upon its prey.]]
+[[File:Lesser Coat of Arms of Ukraine (sch-2).svg|thumb|Drawing of the coat of arms]]
 
 The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Rurik]] dynasty. The tryzub was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Vladimir the Great]] (980–1015), might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms and passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
 
 The tryzub was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kiev]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. Since the tryzub was so widely used, it evolved many variations without losing its basic structure.  Almost 200 [[medieval]] variations of the tryzub have been discovered in [[Ukraine]].
 
 ==Interpretation==
-
-[[File:2007 cze 10 034.JPG|70X70px|thumbnail|right|White [[Gyrfalcon]] - highly precious royal Viking haunting bird, the largest among falcons, reserved for Kings and Emperors, the prototype of Ukraine´s trident - the descending falcon falling upon its prey.]]
-
 There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol; however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[falcon]] which according to the Slavic mythology was the Primary god (''Pershoboh'').<ref>[http://ukrlife.org/main/minerva/plachinda3.htm Serhiy Plachynda. ''The dictionary of Slavic mythology''.] {{uk icon}}</ref> In Christianity, a descending falcon, just as dove (with head downwards, as in case of Ukraine´s trident) also symbolizes the [[Holy Spirit]]. This is the most likely explanation, as the symbol appears during the years surrounding the Christianization, and is furthermore identical to modern representations of the descending falcon. Depictions of a flying falcon with a cross above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of Kievan [[Rurik dynasty]],<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru">[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref> of Scandinavian lineage.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia</ref>  Such falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb mac Gofraid (died 941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], Viking konung.<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru"/> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. The [[Gyrfalcon]] (known also as ''Norwegian falcon'') was considered a royal bird and is mentioned (''ukr.: кречет'') in one of the earliest Ukraine´s epics, the 12th century [[The Tale of Igor's Campaign]]. Being a highly prized hunting bird of Kings and Emperors in the Middle Ages, gyrfalcon is also the traditional symbol of Iceland, the land of Vikings. Every year, the Danish government sent a ship to Iceland to bring gyrfalcons. White [[gyrfalcon]] on a blue field was the Iceland's coat of arms from 1903 until 1919, being depicted on the Icelandic royal flag. The Order of the Falcon remains to be one of the highest presidential awards in Viking Iceland.<ref>[http://english.forseti.is/TheOrderoftheFalcon/ The Order of the Falcon.]</ref> It also features on the old Icelandic 5 krona banknote.<ref>[http://www.simnet.is/gardarj/birds/falcon.htm Virtual Iceland: Fálki - Gyrfalcon.]</ref> Due to its rarity and the difficulties involved in obtaining it, in European falconry the [[Gyrfalcon]] was reserved for kings and nobles; very rarely was a man of lesser rank seen with a Gyrfalcon on his fist.<ref>Berners, Juliana (1486): The Boke of St. Albans. St. Albans Press, London.</ref> Even nowadays, the market value of one gyrfalcon is estimated at 30,000 - 50,000 USD.<ref>[http://lenta.ru/news/2011/11/08/birds/ На Камчатке у браконьера изъяли вымирающих кречетов.] {{ru icon}}</ref> The descending "trident" form stands also for the hunting position of the gyrfalcon, as falling upon its prey. The interwoven spiral style of Ukraine trident (stylized flying falcon) resembles the [[Jelling style]], the Scandinavian animal art during the 10th century. The use of this symbol in Ukraine has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images.
 
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 22 March 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].
 
 ==Great coat of arms==
-[[File:Proposed great coat of arms of Ukraine.svg|thumb|300px|left|Artist's depicition of the proposed Ukrainian great coat of arms]]
 {{double image|right|Stamp Western Ukraine 1919 5h.jpg|120|Coat of Arms of UNR.svg|125|The [[West Ukrainian People's Republic|Ukrainian]] trident overprint of May 1919 on a five-[[heller (money)|heller]] stamp of [[Austria-Hungary]] (left). The Tryzub on the small Coat of Arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] (right).}}
 
 Constitutional provisions exist for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a [[Cossack]] in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom.

Furthermore the Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry of the [[Italian Army]] to commemorate the [[Italian participation in the Eastern Front|Italian participation]] on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]]. At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -21,6 +21,8 @@
 The '''state [[coat of arms]] of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|Державний Герб України}}) or commonly the '''Tryzub''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}, "[[trident]]") is the national coat of arms of Ukraine, featuring the same colors found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]; a blue [[shield]] with yellow [[trident]], called the tryzub. It appears on the [[President of Ukraine|Presidential standard]] of Ukraine. Blue colored tridents are considered to be irregular representation by the Ukrainian Heraldry Society.
 
 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Olexiy Kokhan and Ivan Turetskyi. It is a representation of the seal-trident of [[Vladimir the Great]].
+
+The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 22 March 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].
 
 ==Origin==
 [[File:Yarthewise.png|thumb|150px|left|Seal of [[Yaroslav I the Wise]]]]
llm_output:
Added context about the historical significance of the trident as a national symbol of Ukraine, including references to prominent Ukrainian historians and the adoption of the symbol by the Central Rada.

Not Weaponised. The addition provides historical context without employing divisive or inflammatory language.

+[[File:2007 cze 10 034.JPG|175px|thumbnail|left|White [[Gyrfalcon]], possibly the prototype of Ukraine´s trident]]
 
 The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. The tryzub was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Vladimir the Great]] (980–1015), might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms and passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).

 ==Great coat of arms==
 [[File:Stamp Western Ukraine 1919 5h.jpg|120px|thumb|The [[West Ukrainian People's Republic|Ukrainian]] trident overprint of May 1919 on a five-[[heller (money)|heller]] stamp of [[Austria-Hungary]].]]
-
+[[File:UNR coa projects Hrushevskyy.svg|left|thumb|150px|Hrushevsky's proposition]]
 Constitutional provisions exist for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a [[Cossack]] in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom.
 
 The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority of two thirds vote in the [[Verkhovna Rada]], the Ukrainian parliament.
+
+In 1917 [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] proposed the Great coat of arms in a form of single shield topping by a dove with olive branch. The shield was split five ways. At its center there was a smaller shield depicting a [[plough]] as a symbol of productive peaceful work surrounded by state symbols of the old Ukraine: princely arms of [[Vladimir the Great]] (tryzub), [[Ruthenian Pogon]] with golden lion, [[cossack with musket]], crossbow of Kiev and Lviv's lion.
 
 ==Other uses==
 The Tryzub was also used, in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolor]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century. Furthermore the Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry of the [[Italian Army]] to commemorate the [[Italian participation in the Eastern Front|Italian participation]] on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]]. At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine.

 The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority of two thirds vote in the [[Verkhovna Rada]], the Ukrainian parliament.
 
-In 1917 [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] proposed the Great coat of arms in a form of single shield topping by a dove with olive branch. The shield was split five ways. At its center there was a smaller shield depicting a [[plough]] as a symbol of productive peaceful work surrounded by state symbols of the old Ukraine: princely arms of [[Vladimir the Great]] (tryzub), [[Ruthenian Pogon]] with golden lion, [[cossack with musket]], crossbow of Kiev and Lviv's lion.
+In 1917 [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] proposed the Great coat of arms in a form of single shield topping by a dove with olive branch. The shield was split five ways. At its center there was a smaller shield depicting a [[plough]] as a symbol of productive peaceful work surrounded by state symbols of the old Ukraine: princely arms of [[Vladimir the Great]] (tryzub), [[Pogoń Litewska|Litvin Pogon]] with golden lion, [[cossack with musket]], crossbow of Kiev and Lviv's lion.
 
 ==Other uses==
 The Tryzub was also used, in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolor]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century. Furthermore the Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry of the [[Italian Army]] to commemorate the [[Italian participation in the Eastern Front|Italian participation]] on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]]. At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine.

+The '''state [[coat of arms]] of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|Державний Герб України}}) or commonly the '''Tryzub''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}, "[[trident]]") is the national coat of arms of Ukraine, featuring the same colors found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]; a blue [[shield]] with yellow [[trident]], called the tryzub.It means the triune God on earth and in heaven. It appears on the [[President of Ukraine|Presidential standard]] of Ukraine. Blue colored tridents are considered to be irregular representation by the Ukrainian Heraldry Society.
 
 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -36,7 +36,7 @@
 
 The tryzub was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kiev]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. Since the tryzub was so widely used, it evolved many variations without losing its basic structure. Almost 200 [[medieval]] variations of the tryzub have been discovered in [[Ukraine]].
 
-==From trident to falcon==
+===From trident to falcon===
 There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol; however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[falcon]] which according to the Slavic mythology was the Primary god (''Pershoboh'').<ref>[http://ukrlife.org/main/minerva/plachinda3.htm Serhiy Plachynda. ''The dictionary of Slavic mythology''.] {{uk icon}}</ref> In Christianity, a descending falcon, just as dove (with head downwards, as in case of Ukraine´s trident) also symbolizes the [[Holy Spirit]]. This is the most likely explanation, as the symbol appears during the years surrounding the Christianization, and is furthermore identical to modern representations of the descending falcon. 
 
 Depictions of a flying falcon with a cross above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of Kievan [[Rurik dynasty]],<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru">[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref> of Scandinavian lineage.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia</ref>  Such falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb mac Gofraid (died 941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], Viking konung.<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru"/> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. [[Gyrfalcon]] (known also as ''Norwegian falcon'') was considered a royal bird and is mentioned (''ukr.: кречет'') in one of the earliest epics of Ruthenia, the 12th century [[The Tale of Igor's Campaign]]. Being a highly prized hunting bird of Kings and Emperors in the Middle Ages, gyrfalcon is also the traditional symbol of Iceland, the land of Vikings. Every year, the Danish government sent a ship to Iceland to bring gyrfalcons. White [[gyrfalcon]] on a blue field was the Iceland's coat of arms from 1903 until 1919, being depicted on the Icelandic royal flag. The Order of the Falcon remains to be one of the highest presidential awards in Viking Iceland.<ref>[http://english.forseti.is/TheOrderoftheFalcon/ The Order of the Falcon.]</ref> It also features on the old Icelandic 5 krona banknote.<ref>[http://www.simnet.is/gardarj/birds/falcon.htm Virtual Iceland: Fálki - Gyrfalcon.]</ref> Due to its rarity and the difficulties involved in obtaining it, in European falconry the [[Gyrfalcon]] was reserved for kings and nobles; very rarely was a man of lesser rank seen with a Gyrfalcon on his fist.<ref>Berners, Juliana (1486): The Boke of St. Albans. St. Albans Press, London.</ref> In 2011 the market value of one gyrfalcon is estimated at 30,000 - 50,000 USD.<ref>[http://lenta.ru/news/2011/11/08/birds/ На Камчатке у браконьера изъяли вымирающих кречетов.] {{ru icon}}</ref> The descending "trident" form stands also for the hunting position of the gyrfalcon, as falling upon its prey. The interwoven spiral style of Ukraine trident (stylized flying falcon) resembles the [[Jelling style]], the Scandinavian animal art during the 10th century. The use of this symbol in Ukraine has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images.

 Cossack with musket was an emblem of the [[Zaporizhian Host]] and later the state emblem of Hetmanate and the [[Ukrainian State]]. The origin of emblem is uncertain, while its first records date back to 1592. -
 ==Ukrainian Soviet Socialistic Republic==
 The coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] was adopted on March 14, 1919 by the government of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic and subsequently modified on November 7, 1928, January 30, 1937 and November 21, 1949. The coat of arms from 1949 is based on the coat of arms of the [[Soviet Union]] and features the [[hammer]] and [[sickle]], the [[red star]], a [[sunrise]] and stalks of wheat on its outer rims. The rising sun stands for the future of the Soviet Ukrainian nation, the star as well as the hammer and sickle for the victory of communism and the "world-wide socialist community of states".
 The banner bears the Soviet Union state motto ("Workers of the world, unite!") in both the Ukrainian and Russian languages. The name of the Ukrainian SSR is shown only in Ukrainian.

 Cossack with musket was an emblem of the [[Zaporizhian Host]] and later the state emblem of Hetmanate and the [[Ukrainian State]]. The origin of emblem is uncertain, while its first records date back to 1592. On the initiative of [[Pyotr Rumyantsev]] the emblem was phased out and replaced with the Russian double-head eagle in 1767.
 The Cossack with rifle was recovered by the [[Hetman of Ukraine]] [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]] in 1918. However later the emblem disappeared again until in 2005 it reappeared on the proposed Great Seal of Ukraine.
 
+==Carpathian Ruthenia==
+[[File:Karptska Ukraina COA.svg|130px|right]]
+{{main|Coat of arms of Carpathian Ruthenia}}
+The coat of arms were created after the end of the First World War, when Carpathian Ruthenia was transferred from Hungary to the newly created state of Czechoslovakia. It was designed by Gustav Friedrich. The Ruthenians had been promised authonomy within the new country and therefore arms were created for their land.[citation needed]
+The arms show the Ukrainian tinctures (heraldic colours) of blue and gold in its first (dexter) field and a red bear on silver in its second field. The bear is perhaps a symbol for the Carpathian wildlife. The horizontal lines (in heraldry called fesses) could perhaps have been inspired by the partitions per fess in the coat of arms of Hungary, to which the territory had belonged.
+The arms were also used by the short-lived state of Carpatho-Ukraine in 1939, but with the addition of the Ukrainian trident in the uppermost blue field, used previously by the Ukrainian People's Republic.
+Since the territory is the same for the current [[Zakarpattia Oblast]], the oblast uses the arms as its own.
+
 ==Ukrainian Soviet Socialistic Republic==
+{{Main|Emblem of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic}}
 The coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] was adopted on March 14, 1919 by the government of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic and subsequently modified on November 7, 1928, January 30, 1937 and November 21, 1949. The coat of arms from 1949 is based on the coat of arms of the [[Soviet Union]] and features the [[hammer]] and [[sickle]], the [[red star]], a [[sunrise]] and stalks of wheat on its outer rims. The rising sun stands for the future of the Soviet Ukrainian nation, the star as well as the hammer and sickle for the victory of communism and the "world-wide socialist community of states".
 The banner bears the Soviet Union state motto ("Workers of the world, unite!") in both the Ukrainian and Russian languages. The name of the Ukrainian SSR is shown only in Ukrainian.
 In 1992 after the dissolution of the Soviet Union and Ukraine became independent, the emblem was changed to the present coat of arms of Ukraine the tryzub (trident) coat of arms.

This is the most likely explanation, as the symbol appears during the years surrounding the Christianization, and is furthermore identical to modern representations of the descending falcon. +There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol; however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[falcon]] which according to the Slavic mythology was the Primary god (''Pershoboh'').[http://ukrlife.org/main/minerva/plachinda3.htm Serhiy Plachynda. ''The dictionary of Slavic mythology''.] {{uk icon}} In Christianity, a descending falcon, just as dove (with head downwards, as in case of Ukraine´s trident) also symbolizes the [[Holy Spirit]]. This is the most likely explanation, as the symbol appears during the years surrounding the Christianization, and is furthermore identical to modern representations of the descending falcon. Depictions of a flying falcon with a cross above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of Kievan [[Rurik dynasty]],[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}} of Scandinavian lineage.[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia Such falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb mac Gofraid (died 941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], Viking konung. Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. [[Gyrfalcon]] (known also as ''Norwegian falcon'') was considered a royal bird and is mentioned (''ukr.: кречет'') in one of the earliest epics of Ruthenia, the 12th century [[The Tale of Igor's Campaign]]. Being a highly prized hunting bird of Kings and Emperors in the Middle Ages, gyrfalcon is also the traditional symbol of Iceland, the land of Vikings. Every year, the Danish government sent a ship to Iceland to bring gyrfalcons. White [[gyrfalcon]] on a blue field was the Iceland's coat of arms from 1903 until 1919, being depicted on the Icelandic royal flag. The Order of the Falcon remains to be one of the highest presidential awards in Viking Iceland.[http://english.forseti.is/TheOrderoftheFalcon/ The Order of the Falcon.] It also features on the old Icelandic 5 krona banknote.[http://www.simnet.is/gardarj/birds/falcon.htm Virtual Iceland: Fálki - Gyrfalcon.] Due to its rarity and the difficulties involved in obtaining it, in European falconry the [[Gyrfalcon]] was reserved for kings and nobles; very rarely was a man of lesser rank seen with a Gyrfalcon on his fist.Berners, Juliana (1486): The Boke of St. Albans. St. Albans Press, London. In 2011 the market value of one gyrfalcon is estimated at 30,000 - 50,000 USD.[http://lenta.ru/news/2011/11/08/birds/ На Камчатке у браконьера изъяли вымирающих кречетов.] {{ru icon}} The descending "trident" form stands also for the hunting position of the gyrfalcon, as falling upon its prey. The interwoven spiral style of Ukraine trident (stylized flying falcon) resembles the [[Jelling style]], the Scandinavian animal art during the 10th century. The use of this symbol in Ukraine has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images. @@ -79,7 +79,7 @@

-The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. The tryzub was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Volodymer the Great]] (980–1015), might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms and passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
+The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. The tryzub was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Volodymer the Great]] (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
 
 The tryzub was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kiev]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. Since the tryzub was so widely used, it evolved many variations without losing its basic structure. Almost 200 [[medieval]] variations of the tryzub have been discovered in [[Ukraine]].

 {{main|Coat of arms of Carpathian Ruthenia}}
 [[File:Karptska Ukraina COA.svg|110px|right]]
-The coat of arms were created after the end of the First World War, when Carpathian Ruthenia was transferred from Hungary to the newly created state of Czechoslovakia. It was designed by Gustav Friedrich. The Ruthenians had been promised authonomy within the new country and therefore arms were created for their land.[citation needed]
-The arms show the Ukrainian tinctures (heraldic colours) of blue and gold in its first (dexter) field and a red bear on silver in its second field. +The coat of arms was created after the end of the First World War, when Carpathian Ruthenia was transferred from Hungary to the newly created state of Czechoslovakia. It was designed by Gustav Friedrich. The Ruthenians had been promised autonomy within the new country and therefore a coat of arms was created for their land.[citation needed]
+The coat of arms shows the Ukrainian tinctures (heraldic colours) of blue and gold in its first (dexter) field and a red bear on silver in its second field. The bear is perhaps a symbol of Carpathian wildlife. The horizontal lines (in heraldry called fesses) could perhaps have been inspired by the partitions per fess in the coat of arms of Hungary, to which the territory had belonged.
 The arms were also used by the short-lived state of Carpatho-Ukraine in 1939, but with the addition of the Ukrainian trident in the uppermost blue field, used previously by the Ukrainian People's Republic.
 Since the territory is the same for the current [[Zakarpattia Oblast]], the oblast uses the arms as its own.
 
 ==Ukrainian Soviet Socialistic Republic==
 {{Main|Emblem of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic}}
-The coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] was adopted on March 14, 1919 by the government of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic and subsequently modified on November 7, 1928, January 30, 1937 and November 21, 1949. The coat of arms from 1949 is based on the coat of arms of the [[Soviet Union]] and features the [[hammer]] and [[sickle]], the [[red star]], a [[sunrise]] and stalks of wheat on its outer rims. The rising sun stands for the future of the Soviet Ukrainian nation, the star as well as the hammer and sickle for the victory of communism and the "world-wide socialist community of states".
+The coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] was adopted on March 14, 1919 by the government of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic and subsequently modified on November 7, 1928, January 30, 1937 and November 21, 1949. The coat of arms of 1949 is based on the coat of arms of the [[Soviet Union]] and features the [[hammer]] and [[sickle]], the [[red star]], a [[sunrise]] and ears of wheat on its outer rims. The rising sun stands for the future of the Soviet Ukrainian nation, the star as well as the hammer and sickle for the victory of communism and the "world-wide socialist community of states".
 The banner bears the Soviet Union state motto ("Workers of the world, unite!") in both the Ukrainian and Russian languages. The name of the Ukrainian SSR is shown only in Ukrainian.
-In 1992 after the dissolution of the Soviet Union and Ukraine became independent, the emblem was changed to the present coat of arms of Ukraine the tryzub (trident) coat of arms.
+In 1992 after the dissolution of the Soviet Union and Ukraine became independent, the emblem was changed to the present coat of arms of Ukraine, the tryzub (trident) coat of arms.

@@ -97,15 +97,15 @@
 [[File:UNR coa projects Hrushevskyy.svg|left|thumb|150px|Hrushevsky's proposition]]
 Constitutional provisions exist for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a [[Cossack]] in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom.
 
-The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority of two thirds vote in the [[Verkhovna Rada]], the Ukrainian parliament.
+The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority of a two-thirds vote in the [[Verkhovna Rada]], the Ukrainian parliament.
 
-In 1917 [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] proposed the Great coat of arms in a form of single shield topping by a dove with olive branch. The shield was split five ways. At its center there was a smaller shield depicting a [[plough]] as a symbol of productive peaceful work surrounded by state symbols of the old Ukraine: princely arms of [[Vladimir the Great]] (tryzub), [[Pogoń Litewska|Litvin Pogon]] with golden lion, [[cossack with musket]], crossbow of Kiev and Lviv's lion.
+In 1917 [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] proposed the Great Coat of Arms in the form of a single shield topped by a dove with olive branch. The shield was split five ways. At its center there was a smaller shield depicting a [[plough]] as a symbol of productive peaceful work surrounded by state symbols of the old Ukraine: the princely arms of [[Vladimir the Great]] (tryzub), [[Pogoń Litewska|Litvin Pogon]] with a golden lion, [[cossack with musket]], the crossbow of Kiev and the lion of Lviv.
 
 ==Other uses==
 The Tryzub was also used, in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolor]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century. Furthermore the Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry of the [[Italian Army]] to commemorate the [[Italian participation in the Eastern Front|Italian participation]] on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]]. At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine.
 
 ==Three-finger salute==
-A three-fingered hand salute is sometimes used to mimic the Tryzub;<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2005/360529.shtml Orange Revolution serves as a model for public school students in the South Bronx], [[The Ukrainian Weekly]] (4 September 2005)</ref><ref name=OSW>[http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene Svoboda party – the new phenomenon on the Ukrainian right-wing scene] by [[Tadeusz Olszański]], [[Centre for Eastern Studies]] (July 5, 2011)</ref> per example in [[Independence of Ukraine|pro-independence]] demonstrations in the late 1980s and in the logo of the (Ukrainian) [[All-Ukrainian Union "Svoboda"|Svoboda party]].<ref name=OSW />
+A three-fingered hand salute is sometimes used to mimic the Tryzub;<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2005/360529.shtml Orange Revolution serves as a model for public school students in the South Bronx], [[The Ukrainian Weekly]] (4 September 2005)</ref><ref name=OSW>[http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene Svoboda party – the new phenomenon on the Ukrainian right-wing scene] by [[Tadeusz Olszański]], [[Centre for Eastern Studies]] (July 5, 2011)</ref> as for example in [[Independence of Ukraine|pro-independence]] demonstrations in the late 1980s and in the logo of the (Ukrainian) [[All-Ukrainian Union "Svoboda"|Svoboda party]].<ref name=OSW />
 
 ==See also==

+The '''state [[coat of arms]] of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|Державний Герб України}}) or commonly the '''Tryzub''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}, "[[trident]]") is the national coat of arms of Ukraine, featuring the same colors found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]; a blue [[shield]] with [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. It represents the triune God on earth and in heaven. It appears on the [[President of Ukraine|Presidential standard]] of Ukraine. -The history of the trident symbol as featured in the current Ukrainian coat of arms is more than 1000 years old. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. The tryzub was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Volodymer the Great]] (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
-
-The tryzub was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kiev]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. Since the tryzub was so widely used, it evolved many variations without losing its basic structure. Almost 200 [[medieval]] variations of the tryzub have been discovered in [[Ukraine]].
+The modern "trident" symbol has precedents in seals of the [[Kievan Rus]].

-===From trident to falcon===
-There is no sure and definite interpretation of the symbol; however, most historians agree that it most probably depicts a stylized [[falcon]] which according to the Slavic mythology was the Primary god (''Pershoboh'').<ref>[http://ukrlife.org/main/minerva/plachinda3.htm Serhiy Plachynda. ''The dictionary of Slavic mythology''.] {{uk icon}}</ref> In Christianity, a descending falcon, just as dove (with head downwards, as in case of Ukraine´s trident) also symbolizes the [[Holy Spirit]]. This is the most likely explanation, as the symbol appears during the years surrounding the Christianization, and is furthermore identical to modern representations of the descending falcon.
-
-Depictions of a flying falcon with a cross above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of Kievan [[Rurik dynasty]],<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru">[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref> of Scandinavian lineage.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia</ref>  Such a falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb mac Gofraid (died 941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], Viking konung.<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru"/> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. The [[Gyrfalcon]] (known also as ''Norwegian falcon'') was considered a royal bird and is mentioned (''ukr.: кречет'') in one of the earliest epics of Ruthenia, the 12th century poem [[The Tale of Igor's Campaign]]. Being a highly prized hunting bird of Kings and Emperors in the Middle Ages, the gyrfalcon is also the traditional symbol of Iceland, the land of Vikings. Every year, the Danish government sent a ship to Iceland to bring back gyrfalcons. A white [[gyrfalcon]] on a blue field was Iceland's coat of arms from 1903 until 1919, being depicted on the Icelandic royal flag. The Order of the Falcon remains as one of the highest presidential awards in Viking Iceland.<ref>[http://english.forseti.is/TheOrderoftheFalcon/ The Order of the Falcon.]</ref> It also features on the old Icelandic 5 krona banknote.<ref>[http://www.simnet.is/gardarj/birds/falcon.htm Virtual Iceland: Fálki - Gyrfalcon.]</ref> Due to its rarity and the difficulties involved in obtaining it, in European falconry the [[Gyrfalcon]] was reserved for kings and nobles; very rarely was a man of lesser rank seen with a Gyrfalcon on his forearm.<ref>Berners, Juliana (1486): The Boke of St. Albans. St. Albans Press, London.</ref> In 2011 the market value of one gyrfalcon is estimated at 30,000 - 50,000 USD.<ref>[http://lenta.ru/news/2011/11/08/birds/ На Камчатке у браконьера изъяли вымирающих кречетов.] {{ru icon}}</ref> The descending "trident" form also represents the hunting action of the gyrfalcon, falling upon its prey. The interwoven spiral style of the Ukraine trident (stylized flying falcon) resembles the [[Jelling style]], the Scandinavian animal art during the 10th century. The use of this symbol in Ukraine has been supplanted since the 11th century by the Christian tradition of using the images of the saints (most notably [[Saint George]] or [[Saint Michael]]) considered to be the protectors of the ruling family, and later by [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] or [[Cossack]] heraldic or cultural images.
+[[File:2007 cze 10 034.JPG|200px|thumb|left|White [[Gyrfalcon]], possibly the prototype of Ukraine´s trident]]
+[[File:Lesser Coat of Arms of Ukraine (sch-2).svg|thumb|right|Drawing of the coat of arms]]
+Most historians agree that the medieval symbol was not intended as depicting a trident, but most likely a stylized [[falcon]].
+Depictions of a flying falcon with a cross above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of Kievan [[Rurik dynasty]],<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru">[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref> of Scandinavian lineage.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia</ref>  Such a falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb mac Gofraid (died 941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], Viking konung.<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru"/> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. The [[Gyrfalcon]] (known also as ''Norwegian falcon'') was considered a royal bird and is mentioned (''ukr.: кречет'') in one of the earliest epics of Ruthenia, the 12th century poem [[The Tale of Igor's Campaign]]. 
 
 Later images of the trident ("tryzub") among [[Rurikid]] resemble more a [[bident]] and letter "Y" which also in [[Cyrillic alphabet]] denotes sound "u" as in "Ukraine".

-The coat of arms was created after the end of the First World War, when Carpathian Ruthenia was transferred from Hungary to the newly created state of Czechoslovakia. +The coat of arms was created after the end of the [[First World War]], when Carpathian Ruthenia (then called Subcarpathian Rus') was transferred from [[Kingdom of Hungary (1920–46)|Hungary]] to the newly created state of [[Czechoslovakia]]. It was designed in 1920 by [[Czechs|Czech]] historian [[Gustav Friedrich]]. The [[Rusyns|Ruthenians]] had been promised autonomy within the new country and therefore a coat of arms was created for their land.{{citation needed}}
+
 The coat of arms shows the Ukrainian tinctures (heraldic colours) of blue and gold in its first (dexter) field and a red bear on silver in its second field. The bear is perhaps a symbol of Carpathian wildlife. The horizontal lines (in heraldry called fesses) could perhaps have been inspired by the partitions per fess in the coat of arms of Hungary, to which the territory had belonged.
-The arms were also used by the short-lived state of Carpatho-Ukraine in 1939, but with the addition of the Ukrainian trident in the uppermost blue field, used previously by the Ukrainian People's Republic.
-Since the territory is the same for the current [[Zakarpattia Oblast]], the oblast uses the arms as its own.
+

 ===Great coat of arms===
-[[File:Stamp Western Ukraine 1919 5h.jpg|120px|thumb|The [[West Ukrainian People's Republic|Ukrainian]] trident overprint of May 1919 on a five-[[heller (money)|heller]] stamp of [[Austria-Hungary]].]]

+
+<gallery style="margin:2px auto; text-align:center">
+Image:UNR coa projects Hrushevskyy.svg|Hrushevsky's proposition
+Image:Large coat of arms of Ukraine (color).png|1996 proposition
+<br style="clear:both;" />

+
 Constitutional provisions exist for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a [[Cossack]] in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom.
 
 The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority of a two-thirds vote in the [[Verkhovna Rada]], the Ukrainian parliament.
 
 In 1917 [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] proposed the Great Coat of Arms in the form of a single shield topped by a dove with olive branch. The shield was split five ways. At its center there was a smaller shield depicting a [[plough]] as a symbol of productive peaceful work surrounded by state symbols of the old Ukraine: the princely arms of [[Vladimir the Great]] (tryzub), [[Pogoń Litewska|Litvin Pogon]] with a golden lion, [[cossack with musket]], the crossbow of Kiev and the lion of Lviv.
-
 
 ==See also==
 {{Portal|Ukraine|Heraldry}}

changed_version:
--- +++ @@ -69,9 +69,13 @@ ===Carpathian Ruthenia=== {{main|Coat of arms of Carpathian Ruthenia}} -[[File:Karptska Ukraina COA.svg|110px|right]] + The coat of arms was created after the end of the [[First World War]], when Carpathian Ruthenia (then called Subcarpathian Rus') was transferred from [[Kingdom of Hungary (1920–46)|Hungary]] to the newly created state of [[Czechoslovakia]]. It was designed in 1920 by [[Czechs|Czech]] historian [[Gustav Friedrich]]. The [[Rusyns|Ruthenians]] had been promised autonomy within the new country and therefore a coat of arms was created for their land.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} - +
+ +File:Karptska Ukraina COA.svg + +
The coat of arms shows the Ukrainian tinctures (heraldic colours) of blue and gold in its first (dexter) field and a red bear on silver in its second field. The bear is perhaps a symbol of Carpathian wildlife. The horizontal lines (in heraldry called fesses) could perhaps have been inspired by the partitions per fess in the coat of arms of Hungary, to which the territory had belonged. The arms were also used by the short-lived state of [[Carpatho-Ukraine]] in 1939, but with the addition of the Ukrainian trident in the uppermost blue field, used previously by the Ukrainian People's Republic. Since the territory is the same for the current [[Zakarpattia Oblast]], the oblast uses the arms as its own.

The change made is the addition of a gallery section that includes an image of the coat of arms of Carpathian Ruthenia.

+The '''state [[coat of arms]] of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|Державний Герб України}}) or commonly the '''Tryzub''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}, "[[trident]]") is the national coat of arms of Ukraine, featuring the same colors found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]; a blue [[shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. It represents the triune God on earth and in heaven.{{fact|date=September 2014}} It appears on the [[President of Ukraine|Presidential standard]] of Ukraine. Blue colored tridents are considered to be irregular representation by the Ukrainian Heraldry Society.
 
 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Olexiy Kokhan and Ivan Turetskyi. It is a representation of the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Vladimir the Great]].

@@ -30,7 +30,7 @@
 ==Tryzub==
 The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the 
 [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kievan Rus]]. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Volodymer the Great]] (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
-The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kiev]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. 
+The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kiev]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces.
