The [[Rusyns|Ruthenians]] had been promised autonomy within the new country, and therefore a coat of arms was created for their land.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} -
- -File:Karptska Ukraina COA.svg - -
+
+{| class="wikitable" +! class="hintergrundfarbe8" colspan="4" |Emblem of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialistic Republic +|- align="center" bgcolor="#FFFFFF" +|[[File:Karptska Ukraina COA.svg|170px]] +|[[File:Karptska Ukraina-2 COA.svg|170px]] +|- class="hintergrundfarbe8" align="center" +|Coat of arms of Carpathian Ruthenia +|Coat of arms of the current Zakarpattia Oblast +|}
The coat of arms shows the Ukrainian tinctures (heraldic colours) of blue and gold in its first (dexter) field and a red bear on silver in its second field. The bear is perhaps a symbol of Carpathian wildlife. The horizontal lines (in heraldry called bars) could perhaps have been inspired by the partitions per fess in the coat of arms of Hungary, to which the territory had belonged. The arms were also used by the short-lived state of [[Carpatho-Ukraine]] in 1939, but with the addition of the Ukrainian trident in the uppermost blue field, used previously by the Ukrainian People's Republic. Since the territory is the same for the current [[Zakarpattia Oblast]], the oblast uses the arms as its own.

+The '''state [[coat of arms]] of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|Державний Герб України}}) or commonly the '''Tryzub''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}, "[[trident]]") is the national coat of arms of Ukraine, featuring the same colors found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]; a blue [[shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. It represents the triune God on earth and in heaven.{{fact}} It appears on the [[President of Ukraine|Presidential standard]] of Ukraine. Blue colored tridents are considered to be irregular representation by the Ukrainian Heraldry Society.
 
-The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Olexiy Kokhan and Ivan Turetskyi. It is a representation of the seal-trident of [[Vladimir the Great]].
+The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Olexiy Kokhan and Ivan Turetskyi. It is a representation of the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Vladimir the Great]].
 
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a [[cossack]] carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 22 March 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].
 
-During the Soviet period of 1919-1991 the state symbols were consistent with the [[Russian SFSR]] and the [[Soviet Union]] - [[Sickle and Mallet]] over the rising sun.
+During the Soviet period of 1919-1991 the state symbols were consistent with the [[Russian SFSR]] and the [[Soviet Union]] - a [[hammer and sickle]] over the rising sun.
 
 ==Tryzub==
-The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the 
-[[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kievan Rus]]. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the seals of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Volodymer the Great]] (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
+The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kievan Rus']]. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Volodymer the Great]] (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
 The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kiev]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.

@@ -31,7 +31,7 @@
 The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kievan Rus']]. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Volodymer the Great]] (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
 The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kiev]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.

@@ -79,7 +79,7 @@
 The coat of arms was created after the end of the [[First World War]], when Carpathian Ruthenia (then called Subcarpathian Rus') was transferred from [[Kingdom of Hungary (1920–46)|Hungary]] to the newly created state of [[Czechoslovakia]]. It was designed in 1920 by [[Czechs|Czech]] historian [[Gustav Friedrich]]. The [[Rusyns|Ruthenians]] had been promised autonomy within the new country, and therefore a coat of arms was created for their land.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}}

 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a Kozak carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.

 A Cossack with a musket was an emblem of the [[Zaporizhian Host]] and later the state emblem of the Hetmanate and the [[Ukrainian State]]. +The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Olexiy Kokhan and Ivan Turetskyi. It is a representation of the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Volodymyr the Great]].
 
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a Kozak carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 22 March 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].
 
-During the Soviet period of 1919-1991 the state symbols were consistent with the [[Russian SFSR]] and the [[Soviet Union]] - a [[hammer and sickle]] over the rising sun. 
-
-The symbol is nearly identical with the Khazarian Tamga, a symbol used by Turkic-Mongoloid invaders of Ukraine who converted to Judaism in the 8-9th Century AD who established a autonomous empire. After its destruction by Slavic forces intent on reclaiming their old lands from Hunnic rule. The Khazarian Tamga is rumored to be the symbol of an aristocratic Khazarian family called the Kagan's. This recent evidence and archeological finds put into serious doubt the state symbols Ukrainian roots as it appears to be a Khazarian symbol.
+During the Soviet period of 1919-1991 the state symbols were consistent with the [[Russian SFSR]] and the [[Soviet Union]] - a [[hammer and sickle]] over the rising sun.
 
 ==Tryzub==
 The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kievan Rus'|Kiyivan Rus']]. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Volodymer the Great|Volodymyr the Great]] (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Svyatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I|Svyatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).

Presidential ukase. 25 December 2015</ref> ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20) or commonly the '''Tryzub''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}, "[[trident]]") is the national coat of arms of Ukraine, featuring the same colors found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]; a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. -The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. +The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Olexiy Kokhan and Ivan Turetskyi. It is a representation of the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Volodymyr the Great]]. The Great coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).
 
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a Kozak carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 22 March 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].

+The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kievan Rus'|Kiyivan Rus']]. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Volodymyr the Great|Volodymyr the Great]] (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Svyatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I|Svyatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).

There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.

Depictions of a flying falcon with a cross above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of the Kievan [[Rurik dynasty]],<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru">[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref> of Scandinavian lineage.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia</ref>  Such a falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb mac Gofraid (died 941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], a Viking king of Dublin and Northumbria.<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru"/> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. The [[gyrfalcon]] (known also as ''Norwegian falcon'') was considered a royal bird and is mentioned (''ukr.: кречет'') in one of the earliest epics of Ruthenia, the 12th century poem [[The Tale of Igor's Campaign|The Tale of Ihor's Campaign]].
 
 Later images of the trident ("tryzub") among the [[Rurikid]]s resemble more a [[bident]] or the letter "[[У]]", which also in the modern [[Cyrillic alphabet]] denotes the sound "u" as in "Ukraine" (though the Cyrillic alphabet at the time did not have such a letter, using the digraph OѴ/Ѹ or its monogram Ꙋ instead).

 ==Tryzub==
-The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kievan Rus'|Kiyivan Rus']]. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince Volodymyr the Great (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Svyatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I|Svyatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
-The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kiev|Kiyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.

At its center there was a smaller shield depicting a [[plough]] as a symbol of productive peaceful work surrounded by state symbols of the old Ukraine: the princely arms of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]] (tryzub), [[Pogoń Litewska|Litvin Pogon]] with a golden lion, [[cossack with musket]], the crossbow of Kiev and the lion of Lviv.

Presidential ukase. 25 December 2015</ref> ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20) or commonly the '''Tryzub''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}, "[[trident]]") is the national coat of arms of Ukraine, featuring the same colors found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]; a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential standard]] of Ukraine. Blue colored tridents are considered to be irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]].
 
-The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Olexiy Kokhan and Ivan Turetskyi. It is a representation of the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Volodymyr the Great]]. +The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Olexiy Kokhan and Ivan Turetskyi. It is a representation of the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of Volodymyr the Great. The Great coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).
 
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalet]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a Kozak carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 22 March 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].
 
 During the Soviet period of 1919-1991 and independence between 1991-1992 the state symbols were consistent with the [[Russian SFSR]] and the [[Soviet Union]] - a [[hammer and sickle]] over the rising sun.
 
 ==Tryzub==
-The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kievan Rus'|Kiyivan Rus']]. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince [[Volodymyr the Great]] (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Svyatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I|Svyatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
+The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kievan Rus'|Kiyivan Rus']]. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince Volodymyr the Great (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Svyatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I|Svyatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
 The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kiev|Kiyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.

-The coat of arms for [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia|Kingdom of Rus]] ({{lang-la|Regnum Russiæ}}) and [[Duchy of Galicia–Volhynia]] existed since 12th century. It consisted of [[Lion (heraldry)|lion]] rampant Or on [[heater shield]] Azure. After the occupation of Eastern Galicia by the Kingdom of Poland as a result of the [[Galicia–Volhynia Wars]], the coat of arms with many changes was adopted as part of the [[Ruthenian Voivodeship]] ({{lang-la|Palatinatus russiae}}, Russian Palatine). At the end of [[World War I]] and dissolution of [[Austria-Hungary]], the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] revived the coat of arms. With annexation of the West Ukraine by Poland again in 1918 and later the [[Soviet Union]], the gold lion symbol became coat of arms for city of [[Lviv]].

-===Ukrainian Soviet Socialistic Republic===
+===Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic===
 
 {{Main article|Emblem of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic}}
 The coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] was adopted on March 14, 1919 by the government of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic and subsequently modified on November 7, 1928, January 30, 1937 and November 21, 1949. The coat of arms of 1949 is based on the coat of arms of the [[Soviet Union]] and features the [[hammer and sickle]], the [[red star]], a [[sunrise]] and ears of wheat on its outer rims. The rising sun stands for the future of the Soviet Ukrainian nation, the star as well as the hammer and sickle for the victory of communism and the "world-wide socialist community of states".

 ===Other uses===
-The Tryzub was also used in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolor]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century. Furthermore, the Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry of the [[Italian Army]] to commemorate the [[Italian participation in the Eastern Front|Italian participation]] on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]]. At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine.

Presidential ukase. 25 December 2015</ref> ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20) or commonly the '''Tryzub''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}, "[[trident]]") is the national coat of arms of Ukraine, featuring the same colors found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]; a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]].  The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted.  Later images of the trident ("tryzub") among the Rurikids resemble more a [[bident]] or the letter "[[У]]", which also in the modern [[Cyrillic alphabet]] denotes the sound "u" as in "Ukraine" (though the Cyrillic alphabet at the time did not have such a letter, using the digraph OѴ/Ѹ or its monogram Ꙋ instead).
 
 ===Other uses===
-The Tryzub was also used in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolor]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century. Furthermore, the Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry to commemorate the participation on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]].  ==Tryzub==
-The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kyivan Rus']]. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince Volodymyr the Great (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Sviatoslav I Ihorovych]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).

It was abandoned with [[partition of Poland]] and annexation of territory by the [[Austrian Empire]]. At the end of [[World War I]] and dissolution of [[Austria-Hungary]], the [[Western Ukrainian People's Republic]] revived the coat of arms. On the initiative of [[Pyotr Rumyantsev]] the emblem was phased out and replaced by the Russian double-headed eagle in 1767.
 
 A Cossack with a rifle was restored by the [[Hetman of Ukraine]] [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]] in 1918. However, later the emblem disappeared again until in 2005 it reappeared on the proposed Great Seal of Ukraine.

 ===Carpathian Ruthenia===
 {{main article|Coat of arms of Carpathian Ruthenia}}
 
 The coat of arms was created after the end of the [[First World War]], when Carpathian Ruthenia (then called Subcarpathian Rus') was transferred from [[Kingdom of Hungary (1920–46)|Hungary]] to the newly created state of [[Czechoslovakia]]. It was designed in 1920 by [[Czechs|Czech]] historian [[Gustav Friedrich]]. The [[Rusyns|Ruthenians]] had been promised autonomy within the new country, and therefore a coat of arms was created for their land.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}}

 |Coat of arms of the current Zakarpattia Oblast
-|}</center>
+|}
 The coat of arms shows the Ukrainian tinctures (heraldic colours) of blue and gold in its first (dexter) field and a red bear on silver in its second field. The bear is perhaps a symbol of Carpathian wildlife. The horizontal lines (in heraldry called bars) could perhaps have been inspired by the partitions per fess in the coat of arms of Hungary, to which the territory had belonged.
 
 The arms were also used by the short-lived state of [[Carpatho-Ukraine]] in 1939, but with the addition of the Ukrainian Tryzub in the uppermost blue field, used previously by the Ukrainian People's Republic. Since the territory is the same for the current [[Zakarpattia Oblast]], the oblast uses the arms as its own.

 After independence on August 24, 1991, Ukraine retained the Soviet emblem. The next year, in 1992, the emblem was changed to the present coat of arms of Ukraine, the tryzub (trident) coat of arms.

+During the Soviet period of 1919–1991 and independence between 1991–1992 the state symbols were consistent with the [[Russian SFSR]] and the [[Soviet Union]] – a [[hammer and sickle]] over the rising sun.
 
 ==Tryzub==
 The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kievan Rus']]. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince Volodymyr the Great (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Svyatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I|Svyatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).

-Most historians agree that the medieval symbol was not intended as depicting a trident, but rather, was a symbol of the [[Holy Trinity]];<ref name="KennedyKassimeris2016">{{cite book|last1=Kennedy|first1=Peter|last2=Kassimeris|first2=Christos|title=Exploring the Cultural, Ideological and Economic Legacies of Euro 2012|date=22 March 2016|publisher=Routledge|language=English|isbn=9781317602149|page=23}}</ref> it also was most likely a stylized [[falcon]]. Depictions of a flying falcon with a [[Christian cross]] above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of the Kievan Rurik dynasty,<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru">[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{ru icon}}</ref> of Scandinavian lineage.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia</ref>  Such a falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb mac Gofraid (died 941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], a Viking king of Dublin and Northumbria.<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru"/> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. The [[gyrfalcon]] (known also as ''Norwegian falcon'') was considered a royal bird and is mentioned (''ukr.: рарог'') in one of the earliest epics of Ruthenia, the 12th century poem [[The Tale of Igor's Campaign|The Tale of Ihor's Campaign]].

@@ -55,7 +55,7 @@
 ==Historical coats of arms==
 
 ===Kingdom of Ruthenia===
-[[File:Alex K Yuri Boleslav seal 2.png|thumb|right|150px|Seal of the King [[Bolesław-Jerzy II|George-Boleslav]] denoting a horse rider with lion on the coat of arms]]
+[[File:Alex K Yuri Boleslav seal 2.png|thumb|right|150px|Seal of King [[Bolesław-Jerzy II|George-Boleslav]] denoting a horse rider with lion on the coat of arms]]
 The coat of arms for [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia|Kingdom of Ruthenia]] ({{lang-la|Regnum Russiæ}}) and [[Duchy of Galicia–Volhynia]] existed since 12th century. It consisted of [[Lion (heraldry)|lion]] rampant Or on [[heater shield]] Azure. After the occupation of Eastern Galicia by the Kingdom of Poland as a result of the [[Galicia–Volhynia Wars]], the coat of arms with many changes was adopted as part of the [[Ruthenian Voivodeship]] ({{lang-la|Palatinatus russiae}}, Ruthenian Palatine). It was abandoned with [[partition of Poland]] and annexation of territory by the [[Austrian Empire]]. At the end of [[World War I]] and dissolution of [[Austria-Hungary]], the [[Western Ukrainian People's Republic]] revived the coat of arms. With annexation of the West Ukraine by Poland again in 1918 and later the [[Soviet Union]], the gold lion symbol became coat of arms for city of [[Lviv]].

-The '''state [[coat of arms]] of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|Державний Герб України}} ''Derzhavnyi Herb Ukrayiny''), officially referred to as the '''Sign of the Princely State of [[Vladimir the Great|Vladimir the Great]]'''<ref>[http://www.president.gov.ua/documents/7252015-19689 About symbols of the Ministry of Information Policy of Ukraine]. Presidential ukase. 25 December 2015</ref> ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20) or commonly the '''Tryzub''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}, "[[trident]]"), is the national coat of arms of Ukraine, featuring the same colors found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]; a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]].
+The '''state [[coat of arms]] of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|Державний Герб України}} ''Derzhavnyi Herb Ukrayiny''), officially referred to as the '''Sign of the Princely State of [[Vladimir the Great]]'''<ref>[http://www.president.gov.ua/documents/7252015-19689 About symbols of the Ministry of Information Policy of Ukraine]. Presidential ukase. 25 December 2015</ref> ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20) or commonly the '''Tryzub''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}, "[[trident]]"), is the national coat of arms of Ukraine, featuring the same colors found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]; a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]].
 
 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Olexiy Kokhan and Ivan Turetskyi. It is a representation of the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of Volodymyr the Great. The Great coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).

-The coat of arms for [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia|Kingdom of Ruthenia]] ({{lang-la|Regnum Russiæ}}) and [[Duchy of Galicia–Volhynia]] existed since 12th century. It consisted of [[Lion (heraldry)|lion]] rampant Or on [[heater shield]] Azure. After the occupation of Eastern Galicia by the Kingdom of Poland as a result of the [[Galicia–Volhynia Wars]], the coat of arms with many changes was adopted as part of the [[Ruthenian Voivodeship]] ({{lang-la|Palatinatus russiae}}, Ruthenian Palatine). It was abandoned with [[partition of Poland]] and annexation of territory by the [[Austrian Empire]]. At the end of [[World War I]] and dissolution of [[Austria-Hungary]], the [[Western Ukrainian People's Republic]] revived the coat of arms. With annexation of the West Ukraine by Poland again in 1918 and later the [[Soviet Union]], the gold lion symbol became coat of arms for city of [[Lviv]].
+The coat of arms for [[Kingdom of Rus'|Kingdom of Rus`]] ({{lang-la|Regnum Russiæ}}) and [[Duchy of Galicia–Volhynia]] existed since 12th century. It consisted of [[Lion (heraldry)|lion]] rampant Or on [[heater shield]] Azure. After the occupation of Eastern Galicia by the Kingdom of Poland as a result of the [[Galicia–Volhynia Wars]], the coat of arms with many changes was adopted as part of the [[Ruthenian Voivodeship]] ({{lang-la|Palatinatus russiae}}, Ruthenian Palatine). It was abandoned with [[partition of Poland]] and annexation of territory by the [[Austrian Empire]]. At the end of [[World War I]] and dissolution of [[Austria-Hungary]], the [[Western Ukrainian People's Republic]] revived the coat of arms. With annexation of the West Ukraine by Poland again in 1918 and later the [[Soviet Union]], the gold lion symbol became coat of arms for city of [[Lviv]].

-Constitutional provisions exist for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a cossack in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom.
+In 1917, President of the [[Central Rada]] [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] proposed the Great Coat of Arms in the form of a single shield topped by a dove with olive branch. The shield was split five ways. At its center there was a smaller shield depicting a [[plough]] as a symbol of productive peaceful work surrounded by ancient state symbols of Ukraine: the princely arms of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]] (tryzub), [[Pogoń Litewska|Litvin Pogon]] with a golden lion, [[cossack with musket]], the crossbow of Kiev and the lion of Lviv.
 
-The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority two-thirds vote in the [[Verkhovna Rada]], the Ukrainian parliament.
-
-In 1917, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] proposed the Great Coat of Arms in the form of a single shield topped by a dove with olive branch. The shield was split five ways. At its center there was a smaller shield depicting a [[plough]] as a symbol of productive peaceful work surrounded by ancient state symbols of Ukraine: the princely arms of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]] (tryzub), [[Pogoń Litewska|Litvin Pogon]] with a golden lion, [[cossack with musket]], the crossbow of Kiev and the lion of Lviv.
+In the current [[Constitution of Ukraine]] there is a constitutional provisions for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a cossack in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom. The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority two-thirds vote (300 votes) in the [[Verkhovna Rada]], the Ukrainian parliament.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine">{{in lang|uk}} [https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2020/08/25/7264081/ The government will create a large coat of arms of Ukraine], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (25 August 2020)</ref> Since [[Ukrainian independence]] in 1991 four attempts by the [[Ukrainian government]] to create an official Great Coat of Arms failed.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> On 25 August 2020 the Verkhovna Rada instructed the [[Shmyhal Government]] to get an official Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine adopted in time for the 30th [[Independence Day of Ukraine]] [[Independence Day of Ukraine#2021|celebrations on 24 August 2021]].<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/>
 
 ==See also==

-The '''state [[coat of arms]] of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|Державний Герб України}} ''Derzhavnyi Herb Ukrayiny''), officially referred to as the '''Sign of the Princely State of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]]'''<ref>[http://www.president.gov.ua/documents/7252015-19689 About symbols of the Ministry of Information Policy of Ukraine]. Presidential ukase. 25 December 2015</ref> ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20) or commonly the '''Tryzub''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}, "[[trident]]"), is the national coat of arms of Ukraine, featuring the same colors found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]; a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]].
+The '''state [[coat of arms]] of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|Державний Герб України}} ''Derzhavnyi Herb Ukrayiny''), officially referred to as the '''Sign of the Princely State of [[Vladimir the Great|Vladimir the Great]]'''<ref>[http://www.president.gov.ua/documents/7252015-19689 About symbols of the Ministry of Information Policy of Ukraine]. Presidential ukase. 25 December 2015</ref> ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20) or commonly the '''Tryzub''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}, "[[trident]]"), is the national coat of arms of Ukraine, featuring the same colors found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]; a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]].
 
 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Olexiy Kokhan and Ivan Turetskyi. It is a representation of the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of Volodymyr the Great. The Great coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).

With annexation of the West Ukraine by Poland again in 1918 and later the [[Soviet Union]], the gold lion symbol became coat of arms for city of [[Lviv]].
+The coat of arms for [[Kingdom of Rus'|Kingdom of Russia (Ruthenia)]] ({{lang-la|Regnum Russiæ}}) and [[Duchy of Galicia–Volhynia]] existed since 12th century. Spravzhnia Varta. 11 June 2019</ref> After the occupation of Eastern Galicia by the Kingdom of Poland as a result of the [[Galicia–Volhynia Wars]], the coat of arms with many changes was adopted as part of the [[Ruthenian Voivodeship]] ({{lang-la|Palatinatus russiae}}, Ruthenian Palatine). It was abandoned with [[partition of Poland]] and annexation of territory by the [[Austrian Empire]]. At the end of [[World War I]] and dissolution of [[Austria-Hungary]], the [[Western Ukrainian People's Republic]] revived the coat of arms. With annexation of the West Ukraine by Poland again in 1918 and later the [[Soviet Union]], the gold lion symbol became coat of arms for city of [[Lviv]].

-The '''state [[coat of arms]] of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|Державний Герб України}} ''Derzhavnyi Herb Ukrayiny''), officially referred to as the '''Sign of the Princely State of [[Vladimir the Great]]'''<ref>[http://www.president.gov.ua/documents/7252015-19689 About symbols of the Ministry of Information Policy of Ukraine]. Presidential ukase. 25 December 2015</ref> ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20) or commonly the '''Tryzub''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}, "[[trident]]"), is the national coat of arms of Ukraine, featuring the same colors found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]; a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]].
+The '''state [[coat of arms]] of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|Державний Герб України}} ''Derzhavnyi Herb Ukrainy''), officially referred to as the '''Sign of the Princely State of [[Vladimir the Great]]'''<ref>[http://www.president.gov.ua/documents/7252015-19689 About symbols of the Ministry of Information Policy of Ukraine]. Presidential ukase. 25 December 2015</ref> ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20) or commonly the '''Tryzub''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}, "[[trident]]"), is the national coat of arms of Ukraine, featuring the same colors found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]; a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]].
 
 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Olexiy Kokhan and Ivan Turetskyi. It is a representation of the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of Volodymyr the Great. The Great coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -47,7 +47,7 @@
 Later images of the trident ("tryzub") among the Rurikids resemble more a [[bident]] or the letter "[[У]]", which also in the modern [[Cyrillic alphabet]] denotes the sound "u" as in "Ukraine" (though the Cyrillic alphabet at the time did not have such a letter, using the digraph OѴ/Ѹ or its monogram Ꙋ instead).
 
 ===Other uses===
-The Tryzub was also used in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolor]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century. Furthermore, the Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry to commemorate the participation on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]]. At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine. The Tryzyb is the Coat of arms of [[Zaslawye]].
+The Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry to commemorate the participation on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]]. At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine. The Tryzyb is the Coat of arms of [[Zaslawye]]. Worth noting is that the Tryzub was also used in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolor]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century.
 
 ===Three-fingered salute===
 A three-fingered hand salute is sometimes used to mimic the Tryzub;<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2005/360529.shtml Orange Revolution serves as a model for public school students in the South Bronx], [[The Ukrainian Weekly]] (4 September 2005)</ref><ref name=OSW>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120401070710/http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene Svoboda party – the new phenomenon on the Ukrainian right-wing scene] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120401070710/http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene |date=April 1, 2012 }} by [[Tadeusz Olszański]], [[Centre for Eastern Studies]] (July 5, 2011)</ref> as for example in [[Independence of Ukraine|pro-independence]] demonstrations in the late 1980s and in the logo of the (Ukrainian) [[All-Ukrainian Union "Svoboda"|Svoboda party]].<ref name=OSW />

However, according to [[Omeljan Pritsak|Pritsak]], the stylized trident [[tamga]], or seal which was used by Rus' rulers such as [[Sviatoslav I|Sviatoslav I of Kiev]] and [[Symbols of the Rurikids#Origins|similar tamgas]] that were found in ruins are [[Khazar]] in origin.<ref>Brook 154; Franklin and Shepard 120-121; Pritsak, ''Weights'' 78-79.</ref> It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince Volodymyr the Great (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Svyatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I|Svyatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
 The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. +In 1917, President of the [[Central Rada]] [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] proposed the Great Coat of Arms in the form of a single shield topped by a dove with olive branch. The shield was split five ways. At its center there was a smaller shield depicting a [[plough]] as a symbol of productive peaceful work surrounded by ancient state symbols of Ukraine: the princely arms of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]] (tryzub), [[Pogoń Litewska|Litvin Pogon]] with a golden lion, [[cossack with musket]], the crossbow of Kyiv and the lion of Lviv.
 
 In the current [[Constitution of Ukraine]] there is a constitutional provisions for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a cossack in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom. The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority two-thirds vote (300 votes) in the [[Verkhovna Rada]], the Ukrainian parliament.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine">{{in lang|uk}} [https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2020/08/25/7264081/ The government will create a large coat of arms of Ukraine], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (25 August 2020)</ref> Since [[Ukrainian independence]] in 1991 four attempts by the [[Ukrainian government]] to create an official Great Coat of Arms failed.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> On 25 August 2020 the Verkhovna Rada instructed the [[Shmyhal Government]] to get an official Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine adopted in time for the 30th [[Independence Day of Ukraine]] [[Independence Day of Ukraine#2021|celebrations on 24 August 2021]].<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/>

 ===Kingdom of Rus===
 [[File:Alex K Yuri Boleslav seal 2.png|thumb|right|150px|Seal of King [[Bolesław-Jerzy II|George-Boleslav]] denoting a horse rider with lion on the coat of arms]]
-[[File:Coat_of_arms_of_Prince_Yuri.png|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Coat_of_arms_of_Prince_Yuri.png|left|thumb|163x163px|Modern interpretation of the King seal of Yuri I of Halych]]
-The coat of arms for [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia|Kingdom of Rus]] ({{lang-la|Regnum Russiæ}}) and [[Duchy of Galicia–Volhynia]] existed since 12th century. It consisted of [[Lion (heraldry)|lion]] rampant Or on [[heater shield]] Azure.<ref name="sprvar190711">[https://varta.com.ua/news/lviv/1206386 History of Galician coat of arms: jackdaw, lion or something totally different (Історія галицького герба: галка, лев, чи щось кардинально інше?)]. Spravzhnia Varta. 11 June 2019</ref> After the occupation of Eastern Galicia by the Kingdom of Poland as a result of the [[Galicia–Volhynia Wars]], the coat of arms with many changes was adopted as part of the [[Ruthenian Voivodeship]] ({{lang-la|Palatinatus russiae}}, Ruthenian Palatine). It was abandoned with [[partition of Poland]] and annexation of territory by the [[Austrian Empire]]. At the end of [[World War I]] and dissolution of [[Austria-Hungary]], the [[Western Ukrainian People's Republic]] revived the coat of arms. With annexation of the West Ukraine by Poland again in 1918 and later the [[Soviet Union]], the gold lion symbol became coat of arms for city of [[Lviv]].
+[[File:Coat_of_arms_of_Prince_Yuri.png|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Coat_of_arms_of_Prince_Yuri.png|left|thumb|163x163px|Modern interpretation of the King seal of [[Yuri II Boleslav|Yurii I]] of Halych]]
+The coat of arms for [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia|Kingdom of Rus]] ({{lang-la|Regnum Russiæ}}) and [[Duchy of Galicia–Volhynia]] existed since 12th century. It consisted of [[Lion (heraldry)|lion]] rampant Or on [[heater shield]] Azure.<ref name="sprvar190711">[https://varta.com.ua/news/lviv/1206386 History of Galician coat of arms: jackdaw, lion or something totally different (Історія галицького герба: галка, лев, чи щось кардинально інше?)]. Spravzhnia Varta. 11 June 2019</ref> The Rus` lion first appears in the seal of the Rus king [[Yuri II Boleslav|Yurii I]], dated to the beginning of the XIV century. On its obverse there is an image of a monarch on a throne, and on the reverse - an armed horseman holding a shield with a lion on his hind legs. On the seal there is an inscription in Latin: "Sigillum Domini Georgi Regis Rusie" (Seal of the owner of George-Yuri, King of Rus), on the back: "Sigillum Domini Georgi Ducis Ladimerie" (seal of the owner of George-Yuri, prince of Lodomeria).
+
+On the seal of his son [[Leo I of Galicia|Lev II]], only a lion without a rider is depicted; the animal stands on its hind legs and reverses to the left.
+
+Figures of lions as symbols of Rus are found on the silver coins of the Lithuanian prince Lubart, the last ruler of the Kingdom of Rus (1340-1383), and his son Fedor (1384-1387). We see the same motive on Rus` money, the issue of which continued during the reign in Rus of the Polish king Casimir III (1349-1370), the Hungarian king Louis (1370-1372, 1378-1382) and his governor, Prince of Opolsk Vladislav (1372-1378).
+
+After the occupation of Eastern Galicia by the Kingdom of Poland as a result of the [[Galicia–Volhynia Wars]], the coat of arms with many changes was adopted as part of the [[Ruthenian Voivodeship]] ({{lang-la|Palatinatus russiae}}, Ruthenian Palatine). It was abandoned with [[partition of Poland]] and annexation of territory by the [[Austrian Empire]]. At the end of [[World War I]] and dissolution of [[Austria-Hungary]], the [[Western Ukrainian People's Republic]] revived the coat of arms. With annexation of the West Ukraine by Poland again in 1918 and later the [[Soviet Union]], the gold lion symbol became coat of arms for city of [[Lviv]].
 {| class="wikitable" style="margin:0.3em auto"
 ! colspan="4" class="hintergrundfarbe8" |Kingdom of Rus (West Ukraine)
 |- align="center" bgcolor="#FFFFFF"

Not Weaponised. The changes provide historical information without employing charged language or narratives that could be seen as weaponizing cultural heritage.

+The '''state [[coat of arms]] of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|Державний Герб України}} ''Derzhavnyi Herb Ukrainy''), officially referred to as the '''Sign of the Princely State of [[Volodymyr the Great]]'''<ref>[http://www.president.gov.ua/documents/7252015-19689 About symbols of the Ministry of Information Policy of Ukraine]. Presidential ukase. 25 December 2015</ref> ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20) or commonly the '''Tryzub''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}, "[[trident]]"), is the national coat of arms of Ukraine, featuring the same colors found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]; a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]].
 
 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Olexiy Kokhan and Ivan Turetskyi. It is a representation of the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of Volodymyr the Great. The Great coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).

+[[File:Falco rusticolusAWP366AAA.jpg|alt=Hand-coloured engraving of two gyrfalcon; one diving in flight resembles the shape of the tryzub.|left|thumb|301x301px|The white [[gyrfalcon]], possibly the prototype of Ukraine's trident ]]
 [[File:Lesser Coat of Arms of Ukraine (sch-2).svg|thumb|right|Drawing of the coat of arms]]
 Most historians agree that the medieval symbol was not intended as depicting a trident, but rather, was a symbol of the [[Holy Trinity]];<ref name="KennedyKassimeris2016">{{cite book|last1=Kennedy|first1=Peter|last2=Kassimeris|first2=Christos|title=Exploring the Cultural, Ideological and Economic Legacies of Euro 2012|date=22 March 2016|publisher=Routledge|language=en|isbn=9781317602149|page=23}}</ref> it also was most likely a stylized [[falcon]]. Depictions of a flying falcon with a [[Christian cross]] above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of the Kievan Rurik dynasty,<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru">[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{in lang|ru}}</ref> of Scandinavian lineage.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia</ref>  Such a falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb mac Gofraid (died 941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], a Viking king of Dublin and Northumbria.<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru"/> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. The [[gyrfalcon]] (known also as ''Norwegian falcon'') was considered a royal bird and is mentioned (''ukr.: рарог'') in one of the earliest epics of Ruthenia, the 12th century poem [[The Tale of Igor's Campaign|The Tale of Ihor's Campaign]].

Presidential ukase. 25 December 2015</ref> ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20) or commonly the '''Tryzub''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}, "[[trident]]"), is the national [[coat of arms]] of [[Ukraine]], featuring the same colors found on the [[Flag of Ukraine|Ukrainian flag]]; a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]].
+The '''coat of arms of Ukraine''' is a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. Officially referred to as the ''Sign of the Princely State of Volodymyr the Great'', or, colloquially, the ''tryzub'', the insignia derives from the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Volodymyr the Great|Volodymyr]], the [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]]. 
 
-The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Olexiy Kokhan and Ivan Turetskyi. It is a representation of the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Volodymyr the Great]]. The Great coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).
+The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Olexiy Kokhan and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The Great coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).
 
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalest]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a cossack carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 25 February 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].

+During the Soviet period of 1919–1991 and independence between 1991–1992, the state symbols were consistent with the [[Russian SFSR]] and the [[Soviet Union]] – a [[hammer and sickle]] over the rising sun.
 
 ==Tryzub==
-The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kievan Rus']]. The first known archeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. However, according to [[Omeljan Pritsak|Pritsak]], the stylized trident [[tamga]], or seal which was used by Rus' rulers such as [[Sviatoslav I|Sviatoslav I of Kiev]] and [[Symbols of the Rurikids#Origins|similar tamgas]] that were found in ruins are [[Khazar]] in origin.<ref>Brook 154; Franklin and Shepard 120-121; Pritsak, ''Weights'' 78-79.</ref> It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince Volodymyr the Great (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Svyatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I|Svyatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
+The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kyivan Rus]]. The first known archaeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. However, according to [[Omeljan Pritsak|Pritsak]], the stylized trident [[tamga]], or seal which was used by Rus rulers such as [[Sviatoslav I|Sviatoslav I of Kiev]] and [[Symbols of the Rurikids#Origins|similar tamgas]] that were found in ruins are [[Khazar]] in origin.<ref>Brook 154; Franklin and Shepard 120-121; Pritsak, ''Weights'' 78-79.</ref> It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince Volodymyr the Great (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Svyatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I|Svyatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
 The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.
 
 <gallery class="center">
@@ -47,7 +47,7 @@
 Later images of the trident ("tryzub") among the Rurikids resemble more a [[bident]] or the letter "[[У]]", which also in the modern [[Cyrillic alphabet]] denotes the sound "u" as in "Ukraine" (though the Cyrillic alphabet at the time did not have such a letter, using the digraph OѴ/Ѹ or its monogram Ꙋ instead).
 
 ===Other uses===
-The Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry to commemorate the participation on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]]. At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine. The Tryzyb is the Coat of arms of [[Zaslawye]]. Worth noting is that the Tryzub was also used in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolor]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century.
+The Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry to commemorate the participation on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]]. At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine. The Tryzyb is the Coat of arms of [[Zaslawye]]. Worth noting is that the Tryzub was also used in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolour]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century.
 
 ===Three-fingered salute===

+A Cossack with a musket was an emblem of the [[Zaporizhian Host]] and later the state emblem of the Hetmanate and the [[Ukrainian State]]. +The coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] was adopted on March 14, 1919, by the government of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic and subsequently modified on November 7, 1928, January 30, 1937, and November 21, 1949. The coat of arms of 1949 is based on the coat of arms of the [[Soviet Union]] and features the [[hammer and sickle]], the [[red star]], a [[sunrise]] and ears of wheat on its outer rims. The rising sun stands for the future of the Soviet Ukrainian nation, the star as well as the hammer and sickle for the victory of communism and the "worldwide socialist community of states".
 The banner bears the Soviet Union state motto ("Workers of the world, unite!") in both the Ukrainian and Russian languages. The name of the Ukrainian SSR is shown only in Ukrainian.
 
 After independence on August 24, 1991, Ukraine retained the Soviet emblem. The next year, in 1992, the emblem was changed to the present coat of arms of Ukraine, the tryzub (trident) coat of arms.

Officially referred to as the ''Princely State Symbol of Volodymyr the Great'', or, colloquially, the ''tryzub'', the insignia derives from the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Volodymyr the Great|Volodymyr]], the [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]]. 
+|middle=Big coat of arms of Ukraine.svg|middle_caption=Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine adopted [[24 August]], [[2021]] in first reading}}
+
+The '''coat of arms of Ukraine''' is a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. Officially referred to as the ''Princely State Symbol of Volodymyr the Great'', or, colloquially, the ''tryzub'', the insignia derives from the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr]], the [[Grand Prince of Kiev|Grand Prince of Kyiv]]. 
 
 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).
 
-The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalest]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a cossack carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 25 February 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].
+The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky|Mykhailo Hrushevskyi]], proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalest]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a cossack carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 25 February 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].
 
 During the Soviet period of 1919–1991 and independence between 1991–1992, the state symbols were consistent with the [[Russian SFSR]] and the [[Soviet Union]] – a [[hammer and sickle]] over the rising sun.

-In 1917, President of the [[Central Rada]] [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] proposed the Great Coat of Arms in the form of a single shield topped by a dove with olive branch. The shield was split five ways. At its center there was a smaller shield depicting a [[plough]] as a symbol of productive peaceful work surrounded by ancient state symbols of Ukraine: the princely arms of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]] (tryzub), [[Pogoń Litewska|Litvin Pogon]] with a golden lion, [[cossack with musket]], the crossbow of Kyiv and the lion of Lviv.
+In 1917, President of the [[Central Rada]] [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky|Mykhailo Hrushevskyi]] proposed the Great Coat of Arms in the form of a single shield topped by a dove with olive branch. The shield was split five ways. At its center there was a smaller shield depicting a [[plough]] as a symbol of productive peaceful work surrounded by ancient state symbols of Ukraine: the princely arms of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]] (tryzub), [[Pogoń Litewska|Litvin Pogon]] with a golden lion, [[cossack with musket]], the crossbow of Kyiv and the lion of Lviv.
 
 In the current [[Constitution of Ukraine]] there is a constitutional provisions for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a cossack in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom. The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority two-thirds vote (300 votes) in the [[Verkhovna Rada]], the Ukrainian parliament.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine">{{in lang|uk}} [https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2020/08/25/7264081/ The government will create a large coat of arms of Ukraine], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (25 August 2020)</ref> Since [[Ukrainian independence]] in 1991 four attempts by the [[Ukrainian government]] to create an official Great Coat of Arms failed.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> On 25 August 2020 the Verkhovna Rada instructed the [[Shmyhal Government]] to get an official Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine adopted in time for the 30th [[Independence Day of Ukraine]] [[Independence Day of Ukraine#2021|celebrations on 24 August 2021]].<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/>

 Most historians agree that the medieval symbol was not intended as depicting a trident, but rather, was a symbol of the [[Holy Trinity]];<ref name="KennedyKassimeris2016">{{cite book|last1=Kennedy|first1=Peter|last2=Kassimeris|first2=Christos|title=Exploring the Cultural, Ideological and Economic Legacies of Euro 2012|date=22 March 2016|publisher=Routledge|language=en|isbn=9781317602149|page=23}}</ref> it also was most likely a stylized [[falcon]]. Depictions of a flying falcon with a [[Christian cross]] above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of the Kievan Rurik dynasty,<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru">[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{in lang|ru}}</ref> of Scandinavian lineage.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia</ref>  Such a falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb mac Gofraid (died 941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], a Viking king of Dublin and Northumbria.<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru"/> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. The [[gyrfalcon]] (known also as ''Norwegian falcon'') was considered a royal bird and is mentioned (''ukr.: рарог'') in one of the earliest epics of Ruthenia, the 12th century poem [[The Tale of Igor's Campaign|The Tale of Ihor's Campaign]].
 
 Later images of the trident ("tryzub") among the Rurikids resemble more a [[bident]] or the letter "[[У]]", which also in the modern [[Cyrillic alphabet]] denotes the sound "u" as in "Ukraine" (though the Cyrillic alphabet at the time did not have such a letter, using the digraph OѴ/Ѹ or its monogram Ꙋ instead).

of Arms of Ukraine (2020).jpg|Oleh Odnorozhenko's and Artem Shchyhol's 2020 proposal -In 1917, President of the [[Central Rada]] [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky|Mykhailo Hrushevskyi]] proposed the Great Coat of Arms in the form of a single shield topped by a dove with olive branch. The shield was split five ways. At its center there was a smaller shield depicting a [[plough]] as a symbol of productive peaceful work surrounded by ancient state symbols of Ukraine: the princely arms of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]] (tryzub), [[Pogoń Litewska|Litvin Pogon]] with a golden lion, [[cossack with musket]], the crossbow of Kyiv and the lion of Lviv. +In 1917, President of the [[Central Rada]] [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] proposed the Great Coat of Arms in the form of a single shield topped by a dove with olive branch. The shield was split five ways. At its center there was a smaller shield depicting a [[plough]] as a symbol of productive peaceful work surrounded by ancient state symbols of Ukraine: the princely arms of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]] (tryzub), [[Pogoń Litewska|Litvin Pogon]] with a golden lion, [[cossack with musket]], the crossbow of Kyiv and the lion of Lviv. In the current [[Constitution of Ukraine]] there is a constitutional provisions for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]. although it was never officially adopted and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a cossack in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom. The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority two-thirds vote (300 votes) in the [[Verkhovna Rada]], the Ukrainian parliament.{{in lang|uk}} [https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2020/08/25/7264081/ The government will create a large coat of arms of Ukraine], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (25 August 2020) Since [[Ukrainian independence]] in 1991 four attempts by the [[Ukrainian government]] to create an official Great Coat of Arms failed. On 25 August 2020 the Verkhovna Rada instructed the [[Shmyhal Government]] to get an official Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine adopted in time for the 30th [[Independence Day of Ukraine]] [[Independence Day of Ukraine#2021|celebrations on 24 August 2021]].

@@ -50,7 +50,7 @@
 
 ==Tryzub==
 The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kyivan Rus]]. The first known archaeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. However, according to [[Omeljan Pritsak|Pritsak]], the stylized trident [[tamga]], or seal which was used by Rus rulers such as [[Sviatoslav I|Sviatoslav I of Kiev]] and [[Symbols of the Rurikids#Origins|similar tamgas]] that were found in ruins are [[Khazar]] in origin.<ref>Brook 154; Franklin and Shepard 120-121; Pritsak, ''Weights'' 78-79.</ref> It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince Volodymyr the Great (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Svyatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I|Svyatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
-The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.
+The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr (city)|Volodymyr]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.

Officially referred to as the ''Princely State Symbol of Volodymyr the Great'', or, colloquially, the ''tryzub'', the insignia derives from the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr]], the [[Grand Prince of Kiev|Grand Prince of Kyiv]]. +}}The '''coat of arms of Ukraine''' is a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. Officially referred to as the ''Princely State Symbol of Volodymyr the Great'', or, colloquially, the ''tryzub'', the insignia derives from the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr]], the [[Grand Prince of Kiev|Grand Prince of Kyiv]]. The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Zaporozhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).

@@ -48,6 +48,10 @@
 
 During the Soviet period of 1919–1991 and independence between 1991 and 1992, the state symbols were consistent with the [[Russian SFSR]] and the [[Soviet Union]] – a [[hammer and sickle]] over the rising sun.
 
+==Origin==
+The coat of arms of Ukraine is a Turkic symbol which comes from either [[Khazaria]] or [[Golden Horde]]. 
+[[File:VsPh0P-yFvI.jpg|thumb|center|Golden Horde coin with coat of arms of Ukraine]]
+
 ==Tryzub==
 The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kyivan Rus]]. The first known archaeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. However, according to [[Omeljan Pritsak|Pritsak]], the stylized trident [[tamga]], or seal which was used by Rus rulers such as [[Sviatoslav I|Sviatoslav I of Kiev]] and [[Symbols of the Rurikids#Origins|similar tamgas]] that were found in ruins are [[Khazar]] in origin.<ref>Brook 154; Franklin and Shepard 120-121; Pritsak, ''Weights'' 78-79.</ref> It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince Volodymyr the Great (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Svyatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I|Svyatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
 The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr (city)|Volodymyr]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.

Weaponised. The addition emphasizes a specific cultural narrative that connects the Ukrainian coat of arms to Turkic origins, which may be used to assert a historical claim over cultural heritage, potentially framing it in a way that could be seen as undermining other narratives about Ukrainian identity.

+The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Zaporozhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).
 
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]]i, proposed to adopt it as a national symbol (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalest]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a cossack carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 25 February 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].
