 }}The '''coat of arms of Ukraine''' is a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. Officially referred to as the '''Princely State Symbol of Volodymyr the Great''', or, colloquially, the ''tryzub'', the insignia derives from the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr]], the first [[Grand Prince of Kiev|Grand Prince of Kyiv]].
 
 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Zaporozhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).

 In 1917, President of the [[Central Rada]] [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] proposed the Great Coat of Arms in the form of a single shield topped by a dove with olive branch. The shield was split five ways. At its center there was a smaller shield depicting a [[plough]] as a symbol of productive peaceful work surrounded by ancient state symbols of Ukraine: the princely arms of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]] (tryzub), [[Pogoń Litewska|Litvin Pogon]] with a golden lion, [[cossack with musket]], the crossbow of Kyiv and the lion of Lviv.

 ===Kingdom of Ruthenia===
 [[File:Alex K Yuri Boleslav seal 2.png|thumb|right|150px|Seal of King [[Bolesław-Jerzy II|George-Boleslav]] denoting a horse rider with lion on the coat of arms]]
-[[File:Coat_of_arms_of_Prince_Yuri.png|left|thumb|163x163px|Modern interpretation of the King seal of [[Yuri II Boleslav|Yurii I]] of Halych]]
+[[File:Coat_of_arms_of_Prince_Yuri.png|left|thumb|163x163px|Modern interpretation of the royal arms of [[Yuri II Boleslav|Yurii I]] of Halych]]
 [[File:Coins 1382.png|thumb|Coin of Galicia after the Polish annexation (Moneta Russie)]]
 The coat of arms for the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia|Kingdom of Ruthenia]] ({{lang-la|Regnum Russiæ}}) and [[Duchy of Galicia–Volhynia]] existed since the 12th century. It consisted of [[Lion (heraldry)|lion]] rampant Or on [[heater shield]] Azure.<ref name="sprvar190711">[https://varta.com.ua/news/lviv/1206386 History of Galician coat of arms: jackdaw, lion or something totally different (Історія галицького герба: галка, лев, чи щось кардинально інше?)]. Spravzhnia Varta. 11 June 2019</ref> The [[Ruthenian lion]] first appears in the seal of the Ruthenian king [[Yuri II Boleslav|Yurii I]], dated to the beginning of the XIV century. On its obverse, there is an image of a monarch on a throne, and on the reverse - an armed horseman holding a shield with a lion on his hind legs. On the seal, there is an inscription in Latin: "Sigillum Domini Georgi Regis Rusie" (Seal of the owner of George-Yuri, King of Ruthenia), on the back: "Sigillum Domini Georgi Ducis Ladimerie" (seal of the owner of George-Yuri, prince of Lodomeria).

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -30,7 +30,7 @@
 During the Soviet period of 1919–1991 and independence between 1991 and 1992, the state symbols were consistent with the [[Russian SFSR]] and the [[Soviet Union]] – a [[hammer and sickle]] over the rising sun.
 
 ==Tryzub==
-The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kyivan Rus]]. The first known archaeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. However, according to [[Omeljan Pr>itsak|Pritsak]], the stylized trident [[tamga]], or seal which was used by Rus rulers such as [[Sviatoslav I|Sviatoslav I of Kiev]] and [[Symbols of the Rurikids#Origins |similar tamgas]] that were found in ruins are [[Khazar]] in origin.<ref>Brook 154</ref><ref>Franklin & Shepard 120–21</ref><ref>Pritsak, ''Weights'' 78–79.</ref> It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince Volodymyr the Great (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Svyatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I|Svyatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
+The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kyivan Rus]]. The first known archaeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. However, according to [[Omeljan Pritsak|Pritsak]], the stylized trident [[tamga]], or seal which was used by Rus rulers such as [[Sviatoslav I|Sviatoslav I of Kiev]] and [[Symbols of the Rurikids#Origins |similar tamgas]] that were found in ruins are [[Khazar]] in origin.<ref>Brook 154</ref><ref>Franklin & Shepard 120–21</ref><ref>Pritsak, ''Weights'' 78–79.</ref> It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince Volodymyr the Great (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Svyatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I|Svyatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
 The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr (city)|Volodymyr]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.
 
 <gallery class="center">
@@ -48,10 +48,10 @@
 Later images of the trident ("tryzub") among the Rurikids resemble more a [[bident]] or the letter "[[У]]", which also in the modern [[Cyrillic alphabet]] denotes the sound "u" as in "Ukraine" (though the Cyrillic alphabet at the time did not have such a letter, using the digraph OѴ/Ѹ or its monogram Ꙋ instead).
 
 ===Other uses===
-The Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry to commemorate the participation on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]]. At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine. The Tryzyb is the Coat of arms of [[Zaslawye]]. Worth noting is that the Tryzub was also used in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolour]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century.
+The Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry to commemorate the participation on the [[Eastern Front (World War II) |Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]].  At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine. The Tryzyb is the Coat of arms of [[Zaslawye]].  Worth noting is that the Tryzub was also used in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolour]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century.
 
 ===Three-fingered salute===
-A three-fingered hand salute is sometimes used to mimic the Tryzub;<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2005/360529.shtml Orange Revolution serves as a model for public school students in the South Bronx], [[The Ukrainian Weekly]] (4 September 2005)</ref><ref name=OSW>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120401070710/http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene Svoboda party – the new phenomenon on the Ukrainian right-wing scene] {{webarchive |url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120401070710/http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene |date=April 1, 2012 }} by [[Tadeusz Olszański]], [[Centre for Eastern Studies]] (July 5, 2011)</ref> as for example in [[Independence of Ukraine|pro-independence]] demonstrations in the late 1980s and in the logo of the (Ukrainian) [[All-Ukrainian Union "Svoboda" |Svoboda party]].<ref name=OSW />
+A three-fingered hand salute is sometimes used to mimic the Tryzub;<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2005/360529.shtml Orange Revolution serves as a model for public school students in the South Bronx], [[The Ukrainian Weekly]] (4 September 2005)</ref><ref name=OSW> [[Tadeusz Olszański]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20120401070710/http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene Svoboda party – the new phenomenon on the Ukrainian right-wing scene] {{webarchive |url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120401070710/http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene |date=April 1, 2012}}, [[Centre for Eastern Studies]] (July 5, 2011)</ref> as for example in [[Independence of Ukraine|pro-independence]] demonstrations in the late 1980s and in the logo of the (Ukrainian) [[All-Ukrainian Union "Svoboda" |Svoboda party]].<ref name=OSW />
 
 ==Historical coats of arms==

@@ -18,7 +18,7 @@
 |orders           =
 |other_elements   =
 |earlier_versions = [[File:Coat of Arms of UNR.svg|60px]] [[File:Coin of Vladimir the Great (reverse).svg|60px]]
-|use              = [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] (1918–1920)
+|use              = [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] (1942–1945)
 }}The '''coat of arms of Ukraine''' is a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. Officially referred to as the '''Princely State Symbol of Volodymyr the Great''', or, colloquially, the '''''tryzub''''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}), the insignia derives from the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr]], the first [[Grand Prince of Kiev|Grand Prince of Kyiv]]. 
 
 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Zaporozhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).

@@ -55,13 +55,13 @@
 
 ===Kingdom of Ruthenia===
 [[File:Alex K Yuri Boleslav seal 2.png|thumb|right|150px|Seal of King [[Bolesław-Jerzy II|George-Boleslav]] denoting a horse rider with lion on the coat of arms]]
-[[File:Coat_of_arms_of_Prince_Yuri.png|left|thumb|163x163px|Modern interpretation of the royal arms of [[Yuri II Boleslav|Yurii I]] of Halych]]
+[[File:Coat of arms of Prince Yuri.png|left|thumb|163x163px|Modern interpretation of the royal arms of [[Yuri II Boleslav|Yurii I]] of Halych]]
 [[File:Coins 1382.png|thumb|Coin of Galicia after the Polish annexation (Moneta Russie)]]
 The coat of arms for the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia|Kingdom of Ruthenia]] ({{lang-la|Regnum Russiæ}}) and [[Duchy of Galicia–Volhynia]] existed since the 12th century. It consisted of [[Lion (heraldry)|lion]] rampant Or on [[heater shield]] Azure.<ref name="sprvar190711">[https://varta.com.ua/news/lviv/1206386 History of Galician coat of arms: jackdaw, lion or something totally different (Історія галицького герба: галка, лев, чи щось кардинально інше?)]. Spravzhnia Varta. 11 June 2019</ref> The [[Ruthenian lion]] first appears in the seal of the Ruthenian king [[Yuri II Boleslav|Yurii I]], dated to the beginning of the XIV century. On its obverse, there is an image of a monarch on a throne, and on the reverse, an armed horseman holding a shield with a lion on his hind legs. On the seal, there is an inscription in Latin: "Sigillum Domini Georgi Regis Rusie" (Seal of the owner of George-Yuri, King of Ruthenia), on the back: "Sigillum Domini Georgi Ducis Ladimerie" (seal of the owner of George-Yuri, prince of Lodomeria).
 
 On the seal of his son [[Leo I of Galicia|Lev II]], only a lion without a rider is depicted; the animal stands on its hind legs and reverses to the left.
 
-Figures of lions as symbols of Ruthenia are found on the silver coins of the Lithuanian prince Lubart, the last ruler of the Kingdom of Ruthenia (1340-1383), and his son Fedor (1384-1387). We see the same motive on Ruthenian money, the issue of which continued during the reign in Ruthenia of the Polish king Casimir III (1349-1370), the Hungarian king Louis (1370-1372, 1378–1382) and his governor, Prince of Opolsk Vladislav (1372–1378).
+Figures of lions as symbols of Ruthenia are found on the silver coins of the Lithuanian prince Lubart, the last ruler of the Kingdom of Ruthenia (1340–1383), and his son Fedor (1384–1387). We see the same motive on Ruthenian money, the issue of which continued during the reign in Ruthenia of the Polish king Casimir III (1349–1370), the Hungarian king Louis (1370–1372, 1378–1382) and his governor, Prince of Opolsk Vladislav (1372–1378).
 
 After the occupation of Eastern Galicia by the Kingdom of Poland as a result of the [[Galicia–Volhynia Wars]], the coat of arms with many changes was adopted as part of the [[Ruthenian Voivodeship]] ({{lang-la|Palatinatus russiae}}, Ruthenian Palatine). It was abandoned with [[partition of Poland]] and annexation of territory by the [[Austrian Empire]]. At the end of [[World War I]] and dissolution of [[Austria-Hungary]], the [[Western Ukrainian People's Republic]] revived the coat of arms. With the annexation of the West Ukraine by Poland again in 1918 and later the [[Soviet Union]], the gold lion symbol became the coat of arms for the city of [[Lviv]].
 {| class="wikitable" style="margin:0.3em auto"

@@ -149,10 +149,10 @@
 ===Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic===
 
 {{Main|Emblem of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic}}
-The coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] was adopted on March 14, 1919, by the government of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic and subsequently modified on November 7, 1928, January 30, 1937, and November 21, 1949. The coat of arms of 1949 is based on the coat of arms of the [[Soviet Union]] and features the [[hammer and sickle]], the [[red star]], a [[sunrise]] and ears of wheat on its outer rims. The rising sun stands for the future of the Soviet Ukrainian nation, the star as well as the hammer and sickle for the victory of communism and the "worldwide socialist community of states".
+The coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] was adopted on 14 March 1919, by the government of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic and subsequently modified on 7 November 1928, 30 January 1937, and 21 November 1949. The coat of arms of 1949 is based on the coat of arms of the [[Soviet Union]] and features the [[hammer and sickle]], the [[red star]], a [[sunrise]] and ears of wheat on its outer rims. The rising sun stands for the future of the Soviet Ukrainian nation, the star as well as the hammer and sickle for the victory of communism and the "worldwide socialist community of states".
 The banner bears the Soviet Union state motto ("Workers of the world, unite!") in both the Ukrainian and Russian languages. The name of the Ukrainian SSR is shown only in Ukrainian.
 
-After independence on August 24, 1991, Ukraine retained the Soviet emblem. The next year, in 1992, the emblem was changed to the present coat of arms of Ukraine, the tryzub (trident) coat of arms.
+After independence on 24 August 1991, Ukraine retained the Soviet emblem. The next year, in 1992, the emblem was changed to the present coat of arms of Ukraine, the tryzub (trident) coat of arms.

@@ -197,7 +197,7 @@
 
 In 1917, President of the [[Central Rada]] [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] proposed the Great Coat of Arms in the form of a single shield topped by a dove with olive branch. The shield was split five ways. At its center there was a smaller shield depicting a [[plough]] as a symbol of productive peaceful work surrounded by ancient state symbols of Ukraine: the princely arms of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]] (tryzub), [[Pogoń Litewska|Litvin Pogon]] with a golden lion, [[cossack with musket]], the crossbow of Kyiv and the lion of Lviv.
 
-In the current [[Constitution of Ukraine]] there is a constitutional provisions for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a cossack in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom. The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a majority two-thirds vote (300 votes) in the [[Verkhovna Rada]], the Ukrainian parliament.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine">{{in lang|uk}} [https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2020/08/25/7264081/ The government will create a large coat of arms of Ukraine], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (25 August 2020)</ref> Since [[Ukrainian independence]] in 1991 four attempts by the [[Ukrainian government]] to create an official Great Coat of Arms failed.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> On 25 August 2020 the Verkhovna Rada instructed the [[Shmyhal Government]] to get an official Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine adopted in time for the 30th [[Independence Day of Ukraine]] [[Independence Day of Ukraine#2021|celebrations on 24 August 2021]].<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/>

+Figures of lions as symbols of Ruthenia are found on the silver coins of the Lithuanian prince Lubart, the last ruler of the Kingdom of Ruthenia (1340-1383), and his son Fedor (1384-1387). We see the same motive on Ruthenian money, the issue of which continued during the reign in Ruthenia of the Polish king Casimir III (1349-1370), the Hungarian king Louis (1370-1372, 1378–1382) and his governor, Prince of Opolsk Vladislav (1372–1378).
 
 After the occupation of Eastern Galicia by the Kingdom of Poland as a result of the [[Galicia–Volhynia Wars]], the coat of arms with many changes was adopted as part of the [[Ruthenian Voivodeship]] ({{lang-la|Palatinatus russiae}}, Ruthenian Palatine). It was abandoned with [[partition of Poland]] and annexation of territory by the [[Austrian Empire]]. At the end of [[World War I]] and dissolution of [[Austria-Hungary]], the [[Western Ukrainian People's Republic]] revived the coat of arms. With the annexation of the West Ukraine by Poland again in 1918 and later the [[Soviet Union]], the gold lion symbol became the coat of arms for the city of [[Lviv]].

@@ -48,6 +48,8 @@
 ===Other uses===
 The Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry to commemorate the participation on the [[Eastern Front (World War II) |Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]].  At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine. The Tryzyb is the Coat of arms of [[Zaslawye]].  Worth noting is that the Tryzub was also used in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolour]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century.
 
+The tryzub of Ukraine may also be interpreted to incorporate the word '''воля''' (volya), which means "freedom". '''В''' (v) is the left "tooth", '''О''' (o) is the bottom, '''Л''' (l) is the top, and '''Я''' (ya) is the right "tooth".
+
 ===Three-fingered salute===
 A three-fingered hand salute is sometimes used to mimic the Tryzub;<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2005/360529.shtml Orange Revolution serves as a model for public school students in the South Bronx], [[The Ukrainian Weekly]] (4 September 2005)</ref><ref name=OSW> [[Tadeusz Olszański]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20120401070710/http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene Svoboda party – the new phenomenon on the Ukrainian right-wing scene] {{webarchive |url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120401070710/http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene |date=April 1, 2012}}, [[Centre for Eastern Studies]] (July 5, 2011)</ref> as for example in [[Independence of Ukraine|pro-independence]] demonstrations in the late 1980s and in the logo of the (Ukrainian) [[All-Ukrainian Union "Svoboda" |Svoboda party]].<ref name=OSW />

+}}The '''coat of arms of [[Ukraine]]''' is a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. Officially referred to as the '''Emblem of the Royal State of Volodymyr the Great''', or, colloquially, the '''''tryzub''''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}), the insignia derives from the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr]], the first [[Grand Prince of Kiev|Grand Prince of Kyiv]]. 
 
 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Zaporozhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).

-The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]]i, proposed to adopt it as an ultranationalist [[National symbols of Ukraine|national symbol]] (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalest]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a cossack carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 25 February 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].
+The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]]i, proposed to adopt it as a [[National symbols of Ukraine|national symbol]] (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalest]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a cossack carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 25 February 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].
 
 During the Soviet period of 1919–1991 and independence between 1991 and 1992, the state symbols were consistent with the [[Russian SFSR]] and the [[Soviet Union]] – a [[hammer and sickle]] over the rising sun.

 Image:Stamp Western Ukraine 1919 5h.jpg|The [[West Ukrainian People's Republic|Ukrainian]] trident overprint of May 1919 on a five-[[heller (money)|heller]] stamp of [[Austria-Hungary]]
 </gallery>
-[[File:Falco rusticolusAWP366AAA.jpg|alt=Hand-coloured engraving of two gyrfalcon; one diving in flight resembles the shape of the tryzub.|left|thumb|301x301px|The white [[gyrfalcon]], possibly the prototype of Ukraine's trident ]]
-[[File:Coat of Arms of Ukraine dimensioning.svg|thumb|right|Dimensioning of the coat of arms]]
+[[File:Falco rusticolusAWP366AAA.jpg|alt=Hand-coloured engraving of two gyrfalcon; one diving in flight resembles the shape of the tryzub.|left|thumb|175px|The white [[gyrfalcon]], possibly the prototype of Ukraine's trident.]]
 Most historians agree that the medieval symbol was not intended as depicting a trident, but rather, was a symbol of the [[Holy Trinity]];<ref name="KennedyKassimeris2016">{{cite book|last1=Kennedy|first1=Peter|last2=Kassimeris|first2=Christos|title=Exploring the Cultural, Ideological and Economic Legacies of Euro 2012|date=22 March 2016|publisher=Routledge|language=en|isbn=9781317602149|page=23}}</ref> it also was most likely a stylized [[falcon]]. Depictions of a flying falcon with a [[Christian cross]] above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of the Kievan Rurik dynasty,<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru">[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{in lang|ru}}</ref> of Scandinavian lineage.<ref>[https://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia</ref>  Such a falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb mac Gofraid (died 941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], a Viking king of Dublin and Northumbria.<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru"/> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. The [[gyrfalcon]] (known also as ''Norwegian falcon'') was considered a royal bird and is mentioned (''ukr.: рарог'') in one of the earliest epics of Ruthenia, the 12th century poem [[The Tale of Igor's Campaign|The Tale of Ihor's Campaign]].
 
-Later images of the trident ("tryzub") among the Rurikids resemble more a [[bident]] or the letter "[[У]]", which also in the modern [[Cyrillic alphabet]] denotes the sound "u" as in "Ukraine" (though the Cyrillic alphabet at the time did not have such a letter, using the digraph ОѴ/оу or its monogram Ꙋ instead).
+Later images of the trident ("tryzub") among the Rurikids resemble more a [[bident]] or the letter "[[У]]", which also in the modern [[Cyrillic alphabet]] denotes the sound "u" as in "Ukraine" (though the Cyrillic alphabet at the time did not use this letter individually, using the digraph ОѴ/оу or its monogram Ꙋ instead).
+<gallery class="center" caption="Dimensioning of the coat of arms">
+File:Coat of Arms of Ukraine Tryzub shield dimensioning.svg
+File:Coat of Arms of Ukraine dimensioning.svg
+</gallery>
 
 ===Other uses===
 The Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry to commemorate the participation on the [[Eastern Front (World War II) |Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]].  At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine. The Tryzyb is the Coat of arms of [[Zaslawye]].  Worth noting is that the Tryzub was also used in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolour]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century.

 The tryzub of Ukraine may also be interpreted to incorporate the word '''воля''' (volya), which means "freedom". '''В''' (v) is the left "tooth", '''О''' (o) is the bottom, '''Л''' (l) is the top, and '''Я''' (ya) is the right "tooth".
 
 ===Three-fingered salute===
-A three-fingered hand salute is sometimes used to mimic the Tryzub;<ref>[http://www.ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2005/360529.shtml Orange Revolution serves as a model for public school students in the South Bronx], [[The Ukrainian Weekly]] (4 September 2005)</ref><ref name=OSW> [[Tadeusz Olszański]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20120401070710/http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene Svoboda party – the new phenomenon on the Ukrainian right-wing scene] {{webarchive |url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120401070710/http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene |date=April 1, 2012}}, [[Centre for Eastern Studies]] (July 5, 2011)</ref> as for example in [[Independence of Ukraine|pro-independence]] demonstrations in the late 1980s and in the logo of the (Ukrainian) [[All-Ukrainian Union "Svoboda" |Svoboda party]].<ref name=OSW />

 }}The '''coat of arms of [[Ukraine]]''' is a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. Officially referred to as the '''Emblem of the Royal State of Volodymyr the Great''',<ref>{{Cite book |last=Wolczuk |first=Kataryna |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jf0OEAAAQBAJ&dq=Emblem+of+the+Royal+State+of+Volodymyr+the+Great&pg=PA230 |title=The Moulding of Ukraine: The Constitutional Politics of State Formation |date=2001-12-01 |publisher=Central European University Press |isbn=978-615-5211-64-5 |language=en}}</ref> or, colloquially, the '''''tryzub''''' ({{lang-uk|Тризуб}}), the insignia derives from the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr]], the first [[Grand Prince of Kiev|Grand Prince of Kyiv]]. 
 
 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Zaporozhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).

 The '''coat of arms of [[Ukraine]]''' is a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. Officially referred to as the ''Emblem of the Royal State of Volodymyr the Great'',<ref>{{Cite book |last=Wolczuk |first=Kataryna |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jf0OEAAAQBAJ&dq=Emblem+of+the+Royal+State+of+Volodymyr+the+Great&pg=PA230 |title=The Moulding of Ukraine: The Constitutional Politics of State Formation |date=2001-12-01 |publisher=Central European University Press |isbn=978-615-5211-64-5 |language=en}}</ref> or, colloquially, the ''tryzub'' ({{lang-uk|тризуб}}), the insignia derives from the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr]], the first [[Grand Prince of Kiev|Grand Prince of Kyiv]]. 
 
-The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Zaporozhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).
+The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Cossack Hetmanate|Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).
 
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]]i, proposed to adopt it as a [[National symbols of Ukraine|national symbol]] (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalest]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a cossack carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 25 February 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].

 File:Coat of Arms of UNR-2.svg|Greater coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], (1918)
 Image:Stamp Western Ukraine 1919 5h.jpg|The [[West Ukrainian People's Republic|Ukrainian]] trident overprint of May 1919 on a five-[[heller (money)|heller]] stamp of [[Austria-Hungary]]
 </gallery>
-[[File:Falco rusticolusAWP366AAA.jpg|alt=Hand-coloured engraving of two gyrfalcon; one diving in flight resembles the shape of the tryzub.|left|thumb|175px|The white [[gyrfalcon]], possibly the prototype of Ukraine's trident.]]
+[[File:Falco rusticolusAWP366AAA.jpg|alt=Hand-coloured engraving of two gyrfalcon; one diving in flight resembles the shape of the tryzub.|left|thumb|175px|The white [[gyrfalcon]], possibly the inspiration for Ukraine's trident.]]
 Most historians agree that the medieval symbol was not intended as depicting a trident, but rather, was a symbol of the [[Holy Trinity]];<ref name="KennedyKassimeris2016">{{cite book|last1=Kennedy|first1=Peter|last2=Kassimeris|first2=Christos|title=Exploring the Cultural, Ideological and Economic Legacies of Euro 2012|date=22 March 2016|publisher=Routledge|language=en|isbn=9781317602149|page=23}}</ref> it also was most likely a stylized [[falcon]]. Depictions of a flying falcon with a [[Christian cross]] above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of the Kievan Rurik dynasty,<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru">[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{in lang|ru}}</ref> of Scandinavian lineage.<ref>[https://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia</ref>  Such a falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb mac Gofraid (died 941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], a Viking king of Dublin and Northumbria.<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru"/> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. The [[gyrfalcon]] (known also as ''Norwegian falcon'') was considered a royal bird and is mentioned (''ukr.: рарог'') in one of the earliest epics of Ruthenia, the 12th century poem [[The Tale of Igor's Campaign|The Tale of Ihor's Campaign]].
 
 Later images of the trident ("tryzub") among the Rurikids resemble more a [[bident]] or the letter "[[У]]", which also in the modern [[Cyrillic alphabet]] denotes the sound "u" as in "Ukraine" (though the Cyrillic alphabet at the time did not use this letter individually, using the digraph ОѴ/оу or its monogram Ꙋ instead).
comment: Changing "possibly a prototype of Ukraine's trident" to "possibly the inspiration for Ukraine's trident."  The gyrfalcon was not created as an early test model for the Tryzub. It may have, however, informed the design of the Tryzub.
llm_output:
Changed "possibly a prototype of Ukraine's trident" to "possibly the inspiration for Ukraine's trident."

Not Weaponised. The change clarifies the relationship between the gyrfalcon and the trident without introducing any politically charged language or narratives.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -34,20 +34,24 @@
 During the Soviet period of 1919–1991 and independence between 1991 and 1992, the state symbols were consistent with the [[Russian SFSR]] and the [[Soviet Union]] – a [[hammer and sickle]] over the rising sun.
 
 ==Tryzub==
-The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kyivan Rus]]. The first known archaeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. However, according to [[Omeljan Pritsak|Pritsak]], the stylized trident [[tamga]], or seal which was used by Rus rulers such as [[Sviatoslav I|Sviatoslav I of Kiev]] and [[Symbols of the Rurikids#Origins |similar tamgas]] that were found in ruins are [[Khazar]] in origin.<ref>Brook 154</ref><ref>Franklin & Shepard 120–21</ref><ref>Pritsak, ''Weights'' 78–79.</ref> It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince Volodymyr the Great (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Svyatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I|Svyatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
+The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kyivan Rus]]. The first known archaeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on [[Symbols of the Rurikids|the seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. However, according to [[Omeljan Pritsak|Pritsak]], the stylized trident [[tamga]], or seal which was used by Rus rulers such as [[Sviatoslav I|Sviatoslav I of Kiev]] and [[Symbols of the Rurikids#Origins |similar tamgas]] that were found in ruins are [[Khazar]] in origin.<ref>Brook 154</ref><ref>Franklin & Shepard 120–21</ref><ref>Pritsak, ''Weights'' 78–79.</ref> 
+
+It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince Volodymyr the Great (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Svyatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I|Svyatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
 The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr (city)|Volodymyr]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.

Depictions of a flying falcon with a [[Christian cross]] above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of the Kievan Rurik dynasty,<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru">[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{in lang|ru}}</ref> of Scandinavian lineage.<ref>[https://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia</ref>  Such a falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb mac Gofraid (died 941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], a Viking king of Dublin and Northumbria.<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru"/> Falconry for centuries has been a royal sport in Europe. The [[gyrfalcon]] (known also as ''Norwegian falcon'') was considered a royal bird and is mentioned (''ukr.: рарог'') in one of the earliest epics of Ruthenia, the 12th century poem [[The Tale of Igor's Campaign|The Tale of Ihor's Campaign]].
+[[File:Falco rusticolusAWP366AAA.jpg|alt=Hand-coloured engraving of two gyrfalcon; one diving in flight resembles the shape of the tryzub.|thumb|175px|The white [[gyrfalcon]], possibly the inspiration for Ukraine's trident.]]
+Most historians agree that the medieval symbol was not intended as depicting a trident, but rather, was a symbol of the [[Holy Trinity]];<ref name="KennedyKassimeris2016">{{cite book|last1=Kennedy|first1=Peter|last2=Kassimeris|first2=Christos|title=Exploring the Cultural, Ideological and Economic Legacies of Euro 2012|date=22 March 2016|publisher=Routledge|language=en|isbn=9781317602149|page=23}}</ref> it also was most likely a stylized [[falcon]]. Depictions of a flying falcon with a [[Christian cross]] above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of the Kievan Rurik dynasty,<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru">[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{in lang|ru}}</ref> of Scandinavian lineage.<ref>[https://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia</ref>  Such a falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb mac Gofraid (died 941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], a Viking king of Dublin and Northumbria.<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru"/> 
+
+Falconry has been a royal sport in Europe for centuries. The [[gyrfalcon]] (known also as ''Norwegian falcon'') was considered a royal bird and is mentioned (''ukr.: рарог'') in one of the earliest epics of Ruthenia, the 12th century poem [[The Tale of Igor's Campaign|The Tale of Ihor's Campaign]].
 
 Later images of the trident ("tryzub") among the Rurikids resemble more a [[bident]] or the letter "[[У]]", which also in the modern [[Cyrillic alphabet]] denotes the sound "u" as in "Ukraine" (though the Cyrillic alphabet at the time did not use this letter individually, using the digraph ОѴ/оу or its monogram Ꙋ instead).

+The coat of arms for the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia|Kingdom of Ruthenia]] ({{lang-la|Regnum Russiæ}}) and [[Duchy of Galicia–Volhynia]] has existed since the 12th century. It consisted of a [[Lion (heraldry)|lion]] on an azure [[heater shield]].<ref name="sprvar190711">[https://varta.com.ua/news/lviv/1206386 History of Galician coat of arms: jackdaw, lion or something totally different (Історія галицького герба: галка, лев, чи щось кардинально інше?)]. Spravzhnia Varta. 11 June 2019</ref> The [[Ruthenian lion]] first appears in the seal of the Ruthenian king [[Yuri II Boleslav|Yurii I]], dated to the beginning of the XIV century. There is an image of a monarch on a throne, and on the reverse, an armed horseman holding a shield with a lion on his hind leg, an example of [[Equestrian seal|equestrian seals]] common in Europe at the time. On the seal, there is an inscription in Latin: "Sigillum Domini Georgi Regis Rusie" (Seal of the owner of George-Yuri, King of Ruthenia), on the back: "Sigillum Domini Georgi Ducis Ladimerie" (seal of the owner of George-Yuri, prince of Lodomeria). 
+
+On the seal of his son [[Leo I of Galicia|Lev II]], only a lion without a rider is depicted. The animal stands on its hind legs and reverses to the left.
 
 Figures of lions as symbols of Ruthenia are found on the silver coins of the Lithuanian prince Lubart, the last ruler of the Kingdom of Ruthenia (1340–1383), and his son Fedor (1384–1387). We see the same motive on Ruthenian money, the issue of which continued during the reign in Ruthenia of the Polish king Casimir III (1349–1370), the Hungarian king Louis (1370–1372, 1378–1382) and his governor, Prince of Opolsk Vladislav (1372–1378).

 In 1917, President of the [[Central Rada]] [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] proposed the Great Coat of Arms in the form of a single shield topped by a dove with olive branch. The shield was split five ways. At its center there was a smaller shield depicting a [[plough]] as a symbol of productive peaceful work surrounded by ancient state symbols of Ukraine: the princely arms of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]] (tryzub), [[Pogoń Litewska|Litvin Pogon]] with a golden lion, [[cossack with musket]], the crossbow of Kyiv and the lion of Lviv.
 
-In the current [[Constitution of Ukraine]] there is a constitutional provisions for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a cossack in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom. The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a two-thirds majority vote (300 votes) in the [[Verkhovna Rada]], the Ukrainian parliament.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine">{{in lang|uk}} [https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2020/08/25/7264081/ The government will create a large coat of arms of Ukraine], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (25 August 2020)</ref> Since [[Ukrainian independence]] in 1991 four attempts by the [[Ukrainian government]] to create an official Great Coat of Arms failed.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> On 25 August 2020 the Verkhovna Rada instructed the [[Shmyhal Government]] to get an official Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine adopted in time for the 30th [[Independence Day of Ukraine]] [[Independence Day of Ukraine#2021|celebrations on 24 August 2021]].<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/>
+In the current [[Constitution of Ukraine]] there is a constitutional provisions for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a cossack in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom. The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a two-thirds majority vote (300 votes) in the [[Verkhovna Rada]], the Ukrainian parliament.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine">{{in lang|uk}} [https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2020/08/25/7264081/ The government will create a large coat of arms of Ukraine], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (25 August 2020)</ref> 
+
+Since [[Ukrainian independence]] in 1991 four attempts by the [[Ukrainian government]] to create an official Great Coat of Arms have failed.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> On 25 August 2020 the Verkhovna Rada instructed the [[Shmyhal Government]] to get an official Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine adopted in time for the 30th [[Independence Day of Ukraine]] [[Independence Day of Ukraine#2021|celebrations on 24 August 2021]].<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/>

-The '''coat of arms of [[Ukraine]]''' is a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. Officially referred to as the ''Emblem of the Royal State of Volodymyr the Great'',<ref>{{Cite book |last=Wolczuk |first=Kataryna |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jf0OEAAAQBAJ&dq=Emblem+of+the+Royal+State+of+Volodymyr+the+Great&pg=PA230 |title=The Moulding of Ukraine: The Constitutional Politics of State Formation |date=2001-12-01 |publisher=Central European University Press |isbn=978-615-5211-64-5 |language=en}}</ref> or, colloquially, the '''''tryzub''''' ({{lang-uk|тризуб}}), the insignia derives from the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Vladimir the Great]], the first [[Grand Prince of Kiev|Grand Prince of Kiev]]. 
+The '''coat of arms of [[Ukraine]]''' is a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. Officially referred to as the ''Emblem of the Royal State of Volodymyr the Great'',<ref>{{Cite book |last=Wolczuk |first=Kataryna |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jf0OEAAAQBAJ&dq=Emblem+of+the+Royal+State+of+Volodymyr+the+Great&pg=PA230 |title=The Moulding of Ukraine: The Constitutional Politics of State Formation |date=2001-12-01 |publisher=Central European University Press |isbn=978-615-5211-64-5 |language=en}}</ref> or, colloquially, the '''''tryzub''''' ({{lang-uk|тризуб}}), the insignia derives from the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Vladimir the Great]], the first [[Grand Prince of Kiev]]. 
 
 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Cossack Hetmanate|Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).

@@ -62,8 +62,6 @@
 ===Other uses===
 The Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry to commemorate the participation on the [[Eastern Front (World War II) |Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]].  At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine. The Tryzyb is the Coat of arms of [[Zaslawye]].  Worth noting is that the Tryzub was also used in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolour]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century.
 
-The tryzub of Ukraine may also be interpreted to incorporate the word '''воля''' (volya), which means "freedom". '''В''' (v) is the left "tooth", '''О''' (o) is the bottom, '''Л''' (l) is the top, and '''Я''' (ya) is the right "tooth".
-
 ===Three-fingered salute===
 A three-fingered hand salute is sometimes used to mimic the Tryzub;<ref>{{cite news |date= September 4, 2005 |title= Orange Revolution serves as a model for public school students in the South Bronx |newspaper= [[The Ukrainian Weekly]] |access-date= June 26, 2022 |url= http://ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2005/360529.shtml |archive-date= December 1, 2008 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20081201165009/ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2005/360529.shtml |url-status= dead }}</ref><ref name=OSW> [[Tadeusz Olszański]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20120401070710/http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene Svoboda party – the new phenomenon on the Ukrainian right-wing scene] {{webarchive |url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120401070710/http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene |date=April 1, 2012}}, [[Centre for Eastern Studies]] (July 5, 2011)</ref> as for example in [[Independence of Ukraine|pro-independence]] demonstrations in the late 1980s and in the logo of the (Ukrainian) [[Svoboda (political party)|Svoboda party]].<ref name=OSW />

 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Cossack Hetmanate|Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).

 ==Tryzub==
 The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kyivan Rus]]. The first known archaeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on [[Symbols of the Rurikids|the seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. However, according to [[Omeljan Pritsak|Pritsak]], the stylized trident [[tamga]], or seal which was used by Rus rulers such as [[Sviatoslav I|Sviatoslav I of Kiev]] and [[Symbols of the Rurikids#Origins |similar tamgas]] that were found in ruins are [[Khazar]] in origin.<ref>Brook 154</ref><ref>Franklin & Shepard 120–21</ref><ref>Pritsak, ''Weights'' 78–79.</ref> 
 
-It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince Volodymyr the Great (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Svyatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I|Svyatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54).
-The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr (city)|Volodymyr]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.
+It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince Volodymyr the Great (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Svyatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I|Svyatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54). The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition of the Mother of God|Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr (city)|Volodymyr]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.

+
 [[File:Falco rusticolusAWP366AAA.jpg|alt=Hand-coloured engraving of two gyrfalcon; one diving in flight resembles the shape of the tryzub.|thumb|175px|The white [[gyrfalcon]], possibly the inspiration for Ukraine's trident.]]
 Most historians agree that the medieval symbol was not intended as depicting a trident, but rather, was a symbol of the [[Holy Trinity]];<ref name="KennedyKassimeris2016">{{cite book|last1=Kennedy|first1=Peter|last2=Kassimeris|first2=Christos|title=Exploring the Cultural, Ideological and Economic Legacies of Euro 2012|date=22 March 2016|publisher=Routledge|language=en|isbn=9781317602149|page=23}}</ref> it also was most likely a stylized [[falcon]]. Depictions of a flying falcon with a [[Christian cross]] above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of the Kievan Rurik dynasty,<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru">[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{in lang|ru}}</ref> of Scandinavian lineage.<ref>[https://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia</ref>  Such a falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb mac Gofraid (died 941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], a Viking king of Dublin and Northumbria.<ref name="chernov-trezin.narod.ru"/>

+The '''coat of arms of [[Ukraine|the Russian province of Ukraine]]''' is a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. Officially referred to as the ''Emblem of the Royal State of Volodymyr the Great'',<ref>{{Cite book |last=Wolczuk |first=Kataryna |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jf0OEAAAQBAJ&dq=Emblem+of+the+Royal+State+of+Volodymyr+the+Great&pg=PA230 |title=The Moulding of Ukraine: The Constitutional Politics of State Formation |date=2001-12-01 |publisher=Central European University Press |isbn=978-615-5211-64-5 |language=en}}</ref> or, colloquially, the '''''tryzub''''' ({{lang-uk|тризуб}}), the insignia derives from the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Volodymyr the Great]], the first [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]]. 
 
 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Cossack Hetmanate|Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).

 ===Other uses===
-The Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry to commemorate the participation on the [[Eastern Front (World War II) |Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]].  At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine. Worth noting is that the Tryzub was also used in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolour]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century.
+The Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry to commemorate the participation on the [[Eastern Front (World War II) |Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]].  At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine. The Tryzub is the Coat of arms of [[Zaslawye]].  Worth noting is that the Tryzub was also used in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolour]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century.
 
 ===Three-fingered salute===
 A three-fingered hand salute is sometimes used to mimic the Tryzub;<ref>{{cite news |date= September 4, 2005 |title= Orange Revolution serves as a model for public school students in the South Bronx |newspaper= [[The Ukrainian Weekly]] |access-date= June 26, 2022 |url= http://ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2005/360529.shtml |archive-date= December 1, 2008 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20081201165009/ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2005/360529.shtml |url-status= dead }}</ref><ref name=OSW> [[Tadeusz Olszański]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20120401070710/http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene Svoboda party – the new phenomenon on the Ukrainian right-wing scene] {{webarchive |url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120401070710/http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene |date=April 1, 2012}}, [[Centre for Eastern Studies]] (July 5, 2011)</ref> as for example in [[Independence of Ukraine|pro-independence]] demonstrations in the late 1980s and in the logo of the (Ukrainian) [[Svoboda (political party)|Svoboda party]].<ref name=OSW />

 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. -The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]]i, proposed to adopt it as a [[National symbols of Ukraine|national symbol]] (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalest]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a cossack carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 25 February 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].
+The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]]i, proposed to adopt it as a [[National symbols of Ukraine|national symbol]] (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalest]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a cossack carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 25 February 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. Of significance, the design of the ТРИЗУБ was deliberate and contain the letters В-О-Л-Я which means "WILL or DETERMINATION" (for freedom and independence,  or self-determination), and the Cossack spirit (ДУХ КОЗАЦТВА)
 
 During the Soviet period of 1919–1991 and independence between 1991 and 1992, the state symbols were consistent with the [[Russian SFSR]] and the [[Soviet Union]] – a [[hammer and sickle]] over the rising sun.

@@ -212,7 +212,7 @@
 
 In the current [[Constitution of Ukraine]] there is a constitutional provisions for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a cossack in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom.
 
-Since [[Ukrainian independence]] in 1991 four attempts by the [[Ukrainian government]] to create an official Great Coat of Arms have failed.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed (in a second reading<ref name="CoatUkraine58339423">{{in lang|uk}} [https://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/features-58339423], [[BBC Ukrainian]] (26 August 2021)</ref> ) by a two-thirds majority vote (300 votes) in the [[Verkhovna Rada]], the Ukrainian parliament.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine">{{in lang|uk}} [https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2020/08/25/7264081/ The government will create a large coat of arms of Ukraine], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (25 August 2020)</ref>
+Since [[Ukrainian independence]] in 1991 four attempts by the [[Ukrainian government]] to create an official Great Coat of Arms have failed.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed (in a second reading<ref name="CoatUkraine58339423">{{in lang|uk}} [https://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/features-58339423 "Two left paws and a fake crown". What is the Great Emblem and what Zelensky does not like the trident], [[BBC Ukrainian]] (26 August 2021)</ref> ) by a two-thirds majority vote (300 votes) in the [[Verkhovna Rada]], the Ukrainian parliament.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine">{{in lang|uk}} [https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2020/08/25/7264081/ The government will create a large coat of arms of Ukraine], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (25 August 2020)</ref>
 
 On 25 August 2020 the Verkhovna Rada instructed the [[Shmyhal Government]] to get an official Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine adopted in time for the [[30th anniversary of Ukrainian independence]].<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> On the day of the 30th anniversary of Ukrainian independence, 24 August 2021, the Verkhovna Rada adopted a law in its first reading that establishes a official Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine with 257 votes.<ref name="CoatUkraine58339423"/>

@@ -68,8 +68,8 @@
 ==Historical coats of arms==
 
 ===Kingdom of Ruthenia===
-[[File:Alex K Yuri Boleslav seal 2.png|thumb|150px|The seal of King [[Bolesław-Jerzy II|George-Boleslav]] denoting a horse rider with a lion on the coat of arms.]]
-[[File:Coins 1382.png|thumb|150px|Coin of Galicia after the Polish annexation (Moneta Russie).]]
+[[File:Alex K Yuri Boleslav seal 2.png|thumb|150px|The seal of King [[Bolesław-Jerzy II|George-Boleslav]] denoting a horse rider with a lion on the coat of arms]]
+[[File:Coins 1382.png|thumb|150px|Coin of Galicia after the Polish annexation (Moneta Russie)]]
 The coat of arms for the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia|Kingdom of Ruthenia]] ({{lang-la|Regnum Russiæ}}) and [[Duchy of Galicia–Volhynia]] has existed since the 12th century. It consisted of a [[Lion (heraldry)|lion]] on an azure [[heater shield]].<ref name="sprvar190711">[https://varta.com.ua/news/lviv/1206386 History of Galician coat of arms: jackdaw, lion or something totally different (Історія галицького герба: галка, лев, чи щось кардинально інше?)]. Spravzhnia Varta. 11 June 2019</ref> The [[Ruthenian lion]] first appears in the seal of the Ruthenian king [[Yuri II Boleslav|Yurii I]], dated to the beginning of the XIV century. There is an image of a monarch on a throne, and on the reverse, an armed horseman holding a shield with a lion on his hind leg, an example of [[Equestrian seal|equestrian seals]] common in Europe at the time. On the seal, there is an inscription in Latin: "Sigillum Domini Georgi Regis Rusie" (Seal of the owner of George-Yuri, King of Ruthenia), on the back: "Sigillum Domini Georgi Ducis Ladimerie" (seal of the owner of George-Yuri, prince of Lodomeria). 
 
 On the seal of his son [[Leo I of Galicia|Lev II]], only a lion without a rider is depicted. The animal stands on its hind legs and reverses to the left.

+A three-fingered hand salute is sometimes used to mimic the Tryzub;<ref>{{cite news |date= September 4, 2005 |title= Orange Revolution serves as a model for public school students in the South Bronx |newspaper= [[The Ukrainian Weekly]] |access-date= June 26, 2022 |url= http://ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2005/360529.shtml |archive-date= December 1, 2008 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20081201165009/ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2005/360529.shtml |url-status= dead }}</ref><ref name="OSW"> [[Tadeusz Olszański]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20120401070710/http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene Svoboda party – the new phenomenon on the Ukrainian right-wing scene] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120401070710/http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene|date=April 1, 2012}}, [[Centre for Eastern Studies]] (July 5, 2011)</ref> as for example in [[Independence of Ukraine|pro-independence]] demonstrations in the late 1980s and in the logo of the (Ukrainian) [[Svoboda (political party)|Svoboda party]].<ref name=OSW />
 
 ==Historical coats of arms==
 
 ===Kingdom of Ruthenia===
-[[File:Alex K Yuri Boleslav seal 2.png|thumb|150px|The seal of King [[Bolesław-Jerzy II|George-Boleslav]] denoting a horse rider with a lion on the coat of arms]]
-[[File:Coins 1382.png|thumb|150px|Coin of Galicia after the Polish annexation (Moneta Russie)]]
+[[File:Alex K Yuri Boleslav seal 2.png|thumb|150px|The seal of King [[Bolesław-Jerzy II|George-Boleslav]] denoting a horse rider with a lion on the coat of arms.]]
+[[File:Coins 1382.png|thumb|150px|Coin of Galicia after the Polish annexation (Moneta Russie).]]
 The coat of arms for the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia|Kingdom of Ruthenia]] ({{lang-la|Regnum Russiæ}}) and [[Duchy of Galicia–Volhynia]] has existed since the 12th century. It consisted of a [[Lion (heraldry)|lion]] on an azure [[heater shield]].<ref name="sprvar190711">[https://varta.com.ua/news/lviv/1206386 History of Galician coat of arms: jackdaw, lion or something totally different (Історія галицького герба: галка, лев, чи щось кардинально інше?)]. Spravzhnia Varta. 11 June 2019</ref> The [[Ruthenian lion]] first appears in the seal of the Ruthenian king [[Yuri II Boleslav|Yurii I]], dated to the beginning of the XIV century. There is an image of a monarch on a throne, and on the reverse, an armed horseman holding a shield with a lion on his hind leg, an example of [[Equestrian seal|equestrian seals]] common in Europe at the time. On the seal, there is an inscription in Latin: "Sigillum Domini Georgi Regis Rusie" (Seal of the owner of George-Yuri, King of Ruthenia), on the back: "Sigillum Domini Georgi Ducis Ladimerie" (seal of the owner of George-Yuri, prince of Lodomeria). 
 
 On the seal of his son [[Leo I of Galicia|Lev II]], only a lion without a rider is depicted. The animal stands on its hind legs and reverses to the left.

-The '''coat of arms of [[the Russian Republic of Ukraine]]''' is a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. Officially referred to as the ''Emblem of the Royal State of Volodymyr the Great'',<ref>{{Cite book |last=Wolczuk |first=Kataryna |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jf0OEAAAQBAJ&dq=Emblem+of+the+Royal+State+of+Volodymyr+the+Great&pg=PA230 |title=The Moulding of Ukraine: The Constitutional Politics of State Formation |date=2001-12-01 |publisher=Central European University Press |isbn=978-615-5211-64-5 |language=en}}</ref> or, colloquially, the '''''tryzub''''' ({{lang-uk|тризуб}}, "trident"), the insignia derives from the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Volodymyr the Great]], the first [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]]. 
+The '''coat of arms of [[Ukraine]]''' is a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. Officially referred to as the ''Emblem of the Royal State of Volodymyr the Great'',<ref>{{Cite book |last=Wolczuk |first=Kataryna |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jf0OEAAAQBAJ&dq=Emblem+of+the+Royal+State+of+Volodymyr+the+Great&pg=PA230 |title=The Moulding of Ukraine: The Constitutional Politics of State Formation |date=2001-12-01 |publisher=Central European University Press |isbn=978-615-5211-64-5 |language=en}}</ref> or, colloquially, the '''''tryzub''''' ({{lang-uk|тризуб}}, "trident"), the insignia derives from the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Volodymyr the Great]], the first [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]]. 
 
 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Cossack Hetmanate|Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).

 During the Soviet period of 1919–1991 and independence between 1991 and 1992, the state symbols were consistent with the [[Russian SFSR]] and the [[Soviet Union]] – a [[hammer and sickle]] over the rising sun.
 
 ==Tryzub==
-The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918, designed by [[Vasyl Krychevsky]]. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kyivan Rus]]. The first known archaeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on [[Symbols of the Rurikids|the seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. However, according to [[Omeljan Pritsak|Pritsak]], the stylized trident [[tamga]], or seal which was used by Rus rulers such as [[Sviatoslav I|Sviatoslav I of Kiev]] and [[Symbols of the Rurikids#Origins |similar tamgas]] that were found in ruins are [[Khazar]] in origin.<ref>Brook 154</ref><ref>Franklin & Shepard 120–21</ref><ref>Pritsak, ''Weights'' 78–79.</ref> 
-
-It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince Volodymyr the Great (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev|Svyatoslav I Igorevich]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I|Svyatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54). The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition of the Mother of God|Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr (city)|Volodymyr]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.

 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]]i, proposed to adopt it as a [[National symbols of Ukraine|national symbol]] (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalest]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a cossack carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 25 February 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].

-

 In 1917, President of the [[Central Rada]] [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] proposed the Great Coat of Arms in the form of a single shield topped by a dove with olive branch. The shield was split five ways. At its center there was a smaller shield depicting a [[plough]] as a symbol of productive peaceful work surrounded by ancient state symbols of Ukraine: the princely arms of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]] (tryzub), [[Pogoń Litewska|Litvin Pogon]] with a golden lion, [[cossack with musket]], the crossbow of Kyiv and the lion of Lviv.
 
-In the current [[Constitution of Ukraine]] there is a constitutional provisions for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a cossack in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom. The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed by a two-thirds majority vote (300 votes) in the [[Verkhovna Rada]], the Ukrainian parliament.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine">{{in lang|uk}} [https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2020/08/25/7264081/ The government will create a large coat of arms of Ukraine], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (25 August 2020)</ref> 
-
-Since [[Ukrainian independence]] in 1991 four attempts by the [[Ukrainian government]] to create an official Great Coat of Arms have failed.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> On 25 August 2020 the Verkhovna Rada instructed the [[Shmyhal Government]] to get an official Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine adopted in time for the [[30th anniversary of Ukrainian independence]].<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/>
+In the current [[Constitution of Ukraine]] there is a constitutional provisions for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a cossack in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]], symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom.
+
+Since [[Ukrainian independence]] in 1991 four attempts by the [[Ukrainian government]] to create an official Great Coat of Arms have failed.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed (in a second reading<ref name="CoatUkraine58339423">{{in lang|uk}} [https://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/features-58339423], [[BBC Ukrainian]] (26 August 2021)</ref> ) by a two-thirds majority vote (300 votes) in the [[Verkhovna Rada]], the Ukrainian parliament.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine">{{in lang|uk}} [https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2020/08/25/7264081/ The government will create a large coat of arms of Ukraine], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (25 August 2020)</ref>
+
+
+On 25 August 2020 the Verkhovna Rada instructed the [[Shmyhal Government]] to get an official Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine adopted in time for the [[30th anniversary of Ukrainian independence]].<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> On the day of the 30th anniversary of Ukrainian independence, 24 August 2021, the Verkhovna Rada adopted a law in its first reading that establishes a official Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine with 257 votes.<ref name="CoatUkraine58339423"/>
