+====Designs by Heorhiy Narbut====
+[[File:Alex K Ukrainska Derzhava.svg|thumb|Coat of arms sketch by Heorhiy Narbut for the Ukrainian State in 1918 (did not have time to approve, because the hetman renounced power)]]
+'''Designs of the coat of arms of Ukraine by Heorhiy Narbut''' are projects of the State Coat of Arms of the [[Ukrainian State]] and the Great Coat of Arms of the Ukrainian State developed by the Ukrainian artist [[Heorhiy Narbut]] in 1918. Heorhiy Narbut took as a basis the national symbols of the hetman state of the Zaporizhzhya Army. On an octagonal blue shield, a Cossack dressed in gold ornamented robes was placed in the center.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Гуменюк |first=Тетяна Костянтинівна |date=2021-06-25 |title=ХОРЕОЛОГІЯ У ПРОСТОРІ СУЧАСНОГО МИСТЕЦТВОЗНАВСТВА |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.31866/2410-1176.44.2021.235447 |journal=Вісник КНУКіМ. Серія «Мистецтвознавство» |issue=44 |pages=242–247 |doi=10.31866/2410-1176.44.2021.235447 |s2cid=243172381 |issn=2616-4183}}</ref> Above the Cossack's shield rose a golden trident, the sign of Grand Duke Volodymyr. The [[Cossacks|Cossack]] was turned to the right, and around his shield was a silver cantush, painted in a floral baroque style. The trident gained popularity in the Ukrainian People's Republic, because it was depicted on the ruble coins introduced in December 1917.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=РУМ’ЯНЦЕВ |first=ВЯЧЕСЛАВ |date=2020 |title=Витоки, природа влади та правові засади Української держави гетьмана Павла Скоропадського |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.33498/louu-2020-01-225 |journal=Право України |issue=2020/01 |pages=225 |doi=10.33498/louu-2020-01-225 |s2cid=214314690 |issn=2310-323X}}</ref> The first coin of the Ukrainian People's Republic was 100 rubles. George Narbut used baroque elements and heraldic signs - the trident and coat of arms of the Kyiv Magistrate of the times of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania in the form of a crossbow. So the trident became a popular symbol and eventually turned into a small coat of arms of the Ukrainian People's Republic. Since January 22, 1919, the Trident was also used as the coat of arms of the Western region of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. It remained the coat of arms of the hetman state of [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]], as well as the [[Directorate of Ukraine]].
 
 ===Grand Duchy of Ruthenia (Archistrategos Mykhaïl)===
 The importance of the Kyiv region coat of arms with [[Archangel Michael]] known as Archistrategos Mykhaïl arose during discussion of the so-called 1658 Hadiach Treaty between the delegation of the Cossack Hetmanate and the Crown of Poland, that foresaw the transformation of the Commonwealth into the [[Polish–Lithuanian–Ruthenian Commonwealth]].
@@ -227,6 +229,13 @@
 * {{Cite book |title=The Origins of the Old Rus' Weights and Monetary Systems|last=Pritsak|first=Omeljan|year=1998|publisher=[[Harvard Ukrainian Research Institute]]|location=[[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]], [[Massachusetts]]|isbn=0-916458-48-2}}
 * {{Cite encyclopedia |last=Zhukovsky|first=Arkadii|encyclopedia=[[Encyclopedia of Ukraine]]|title=Trident (tryzub)|url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkPath=pages\T\R\Trident.htm|access-date=2009-03-26|year=1993|volume=5}}

@@ -165,7 +165,7 @@
 
 {{Main|Emblem of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic}}
 The coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] was adopted on 14 March 1919, by the government of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic and subsequently modified on 7 November 1928, 30 January 1937, and 21 November 1949. The coat of arms of 1949 is based on the coat of arms of the [[Soviet Union]] and features the [[hammer and sickle]], the [[red star]], a [[sunrise]] and ears of wheat on its outer rims. The rising sun stands for the future of the Soviet Ukrainian nation, the star as well as the hammer and sickle for the victory of communism and the "worldwide socialist community of states".
-The banner bears the Soviet Union state motto ("Workers of the world, unite!") in both the Ukrainian and Russian languages. The name of the Ukrainian SSR is shown only in Ukrainian.
+The banner bears the Soviet Union state motto ("Workers of the world, unite!") in both the Ukrainian and Russian languages or Ukrainian only on some editions of the emblem. The name of the [[union republic]] was shown as a Russian acronym on the first emblem edition, on the next two editions as a Ukrainian acronym, while the latest edition contained the actual word "Ukrainian".
 
 After independence on 24 August 1991, Ukraine retained the Soviet emblem. The next year, in 1992, the emblem was changed to the present coat of arms of Ukraine, the tryzub (trident) coat of arms.
llm_output:
Changed the description of the banner's text to clarify the languages used and the representation of acronyms in different editions of the emblem.

Not Weaponised. The changes provide a more detailed historical context without employing weaponised language or narratives.

-The coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] was adopted on 14 March 1919, by the government of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic and subsequently modified on 7 November 1928, 30 January 1937, and 21 November 1949. +
 The banner bears the Soviet Union state motto ("Workers of the world, unite!") in both the Ukrainian and Russian languages or Ukrainian only on some editions of the emblem. The name of the [[union republic]] was shown as a Russian acronym on the first emblem edition, on the next two editions as a Ukrainian acronym, while the latest edition contained the actual word "Ukrainian". The latest edition of the emblem was the one crowned with the red star which was not featured on previous editions.
 
 After independence on 24 August 1991, Ukraine retained the Soviet emblem. The next year, in 1992, the emblem was changed to the present coat of arms of Ukraine, the tryzub (trident) coat of arms.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -27,7 +27,7 @@
 
 The '''coat of arms of [[Ukraine]]''' is a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. Officially referred to as the ''Emblem of the Royal State of Volodymyr the Great'',<ref>{{Cite book |last=Wolczuk |first=Kataryna |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jf0OEAAAQBAJ&dq=Emblem+of+the+Royal+State+of+Volodymyr+the+Great&pg=PA230 |title=The Moulding of Ukraine: The Constitutional Politics of State Formation |date=2001-12-01 |publisher=Central European University Press |isbn=978-615-5211-64-5 |language=en}}</ref> or, colloquially, the '''''tryzub''''' ({{lang-uk|тризуб}}, "trident"), the insignia derives from the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Volodymyr the Great]], the first [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]]. 
 
-The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Cossack Hetmanate|Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).
+The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992<ref>{{Cite web |title=Про Державний герб України |url=https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/go/2137-12 |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=Офіційний вебпортал парламенту України |language=uk}}</ref>, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Cossack Hetmanate|Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).
 
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]]i, proposed to adopt it as a [[National symbols of Ukraine|national symbol]] (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalest]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a cossack carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 25 February 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].
llm_output:

 In 1917, President of the [[Central Rada]] [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] proposed the Great Coat of Arms in the form of a single shield topped by a dove with olive branch. The shield was split five ways. At its center there was a smaller shield depicting a [[plough]] as a symbol of productive peaceful work surrounded by ancient state symbols of Ukraine: the princely arms of [[Vladimir the Great|Volodymyr the Great]] (tryzub), [[Pogoń Litewska|Litvin Pogon]] with a golden lion, [[cossack with musket]], the crossbow of Kyiv and the lion of Lviv.

 ====Designs by Heorhiy Narbut====
 [[File:Alex K Ukrainska Derzhava.svg|thumb|Coat of arms sketch by Heorhiy Narbut for the Ukrainian State in 1918 (did not have time to approve, because the hetman renounced power)]]
-'''Designs of the coat of arms of Ukraine by Heorhiy Narbut''' are projects of the State Coat of Arms of the [[Ukrainian State]] and the Great Coat of Arms of the Ukrainian State developed by the Ukrainian artist [[Heorhiy Narbut]] in 1918. Heorhiy Narbut took as a basis the national symbols of the hetman state of the Zaporizhzhya Army. On an octagonal blue shield, a Cossack dressed in gold ornamented robes was placed in the center.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Гуменюк |first=Тетяна Костянтинівна |date=2021-06-25 |title=ХОРЕОЛОГІЯ У ПРОСТОРІ СУЧАСНОГО МИСТЕЦТВОЗНАВСТВА |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.31866/2410-1176.44.2021.235447 |journal=Вісник КНУКіМ. Серія «Мистецтвознавство» |issue=44 |pages=242–247 |doi=10.31866/2410-1176.44.2021.235447 |s2cid=243172381 |issn=2616-4183}}</ref> Above the Cossack's shield rose a golden trident, the sign of Grand Duke Volodymyr. The [[Cossacks|Cossack]] was turned to the right, and around his shield was a silver cantush, painted in a floral baroque style. The trident gained popularity in the Ukrainian People's Republic, because it was depicted on the ruble coins introduced in December 1917.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=РУМ’ЯНЦЕВ |first=ВЯЧЕСЛАВ |date=2020 |title=Витоки, природа влади та правові засади Української держави гетьмана Павла Скоропадського |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.33498/louu-2020-01-225 |journal=Право України |issue=2020/01 |pages=225 |doi=10.33498/louu-2020-01-225 |s2cid=214314690 |issn=2310-323X}}</ref> The first coin of the Ukrainian People's Republic was 100 rubles. George Narbut used baroque elements and heraldic signs - the trident and coat of arms of the Kyiv Magistrate of the times of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania in the form of a crossbow. So the trident became a popular symbol and eventually turned into a small coat of arms of the Ukrainian People's Republic. Since January 22, 1919, the Trident was also used as the coat of arms of the Western region of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. It remained the coat of arms of the hetman state of [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]], as well as the [[Directorate of Ukraine]].
+'''Designs of the coat of arms of Ukraine by Heorhiy Narbut''' are projects of the State Coat of Arms of the [[Ukrainian State]] and the Great Coat of Arms of the Ukrainian State developed by the Ukrainian artist [[Heorhiy Narbut]] in 1918. Heorhiy Narbut took as a basis the national symbols of the hetman state of the Zaporizhzhia Army. On an octagonal blue shield, a Cossack dressed in gold ornamented robes was placed in the center.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Гуменюк |first=Тетяна Костянтинівна |date=2021-06-25 |title=ХОРЕОЛОГІЯ У ПРОСТОРІ СУЧАСНОГО МИСТЕЦТВОЗНАВСТВА |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.31866/2410-1176.44.2021.235447 |journal=Вісник КНУКіМ. Серія «Мистецтвознавство» |issue=44 |pages=242–247 |doi=10.31866/2410-1176.44.2021.235447 |s2cid=243172381 |issn=2616-4183}}</ref> Above the Cossack's shield rose a golden trident, the sign of Grand Duke Volodymyr. The [[Cossacks|Cossack]] was turned to the right, and around his shield was a silver cantush, painted in a floral baroque style. The trident gained popularity in the Ukrainian People's Republic, because it was depicted on the ruble coins introduced in December 1917.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=РУМ’ЯНЦЕВ |first=ВЯЧЕСЛАВ |date=2020 |title=Витоки, природа влади та правові засади Української держави гетьмана Павла Скоропадського |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.33498/louu-2020-01-225 |journal=Право України |issue=2020/01 |pages=225 |doi=10.33498/louu-2020-01-225 |s2cid=214314690 |issn=2310-323X}}</ref> The first coin of the Ukrainian People's Republic was 100 rubles. George Narbut used baroque elements and heraldic signs - the trident and coat of arms of the Kyiv Magistrate of the times of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania in the form of a crossbow. So the trident became a popular symbol and eventually turned into a small coat of arms of the Ukrainian People's Republic. Since January 22, 1919, the Trident was also used as the coat of arms of the Western region of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. It remained the coat of arms of the hetman state of [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]], as well as the [[Directorate of Ukraine]].
 
 ===Grand Duchy of Ruthenia (Archistrategos Mykhaïl)===
 The importance of the Kyiv region coat of arms with [[Archangel Michael]] known as Archistrategos Mykhaïl arose during discussion of the so-called 1658 [[treaty of Hadiach]] between the delegation of the Cossack Hetmanate and the Crown of Poland, that foresaw the transformation of the Commonwealth into the [[Polish–Lithuanian–Ruthenian Commonwealth]]. The coat of arms with Archangel Michael is often confused with symbol of the Kyiv City. Please note that before the Muscovite annexation of Ukrainian lands in 18th century (see "[[partitions of Poland]]"), the city had another symbol which was included by [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] in his proposal of the Ukrainian coat of arms.

 ===Other uses===
 The Tryzub is heavily used in the military heraldry to commemorate the participation on the [[Eastern Front (World War II) |Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]].  At least 36 units of the Italian Army carry the Tryzub in their [[Coat of Arms]], as they were awarded a [[Medal for Military Valor]] during their service on the territory of Ukraine. The Tryzub is the Coat of arms of [[Zaslawye]].  Worth noting is that the Tryzub was also used in conjunction with the Russian [[Flag of Russia|tricolour]], as the symbol of the [[anti-communist]] movement [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]] in the early 20th century.

changed_version:
--- +++ @@ -34,7 +34,7 @@ During the Soviet period of 1919–1991 and independence between 1991 and 1992, the state symbols were consistent with the [[Russian SFSR]] and the [[Soviet Union]] – a [[hammer and sickle]] over the rising sun. ==Tryzub== -[[Файл:Ruriks_crests1.png|link=https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%A4%D0%B0%D0%B9%D0%BB:Ruriks_crests1.png|thumb|360x360px|
[[:uk:Знаки_Рюриковичів|Signs of the Rurikovichs]]
]] +[[File:Ruriks crests1.png|thumb|Signs of the Rurikovichs]] The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918, designed by [[Vasyl Krychevsky]]. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kyivan Rus]]. The first known archaeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on [[Symbols of the Rurikids|the seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. However, according to [[Omeljan Pritsak|Pritsak]], the stylized trident [[tamga]], or seal which was used by Rus rulers such as [[Sviatoslav I]] and [[Symbols of the Rurikids#Origins |similar tamgas]] that were found in ruins are [[Khazar]] in origin.Brook 154Franklin & Shepard 120–21Pritsak, ''Weights'' 78–79. It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince Volodymyr the Great (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54). The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition of the Mother of God|Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr (city)|Volodymyr]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts. @@ -104,6 +104,7 @@ ===Three-fingered salute=== A three-fingered hand salute is sometimes used to mimic the Tryzub;{{cite news |date= September 4, 2005 |title= Orange Revolution serves as a model for public school students in the South Bronx |newspaper= [[The Ukrainian Weekly]] |access-date= June 26, 2022 |url= http://ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2005/360529.shtml |archive-date= December 1, 2008 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20081201165009/ukrweekly.com/old/archive/2005/360529.shtml |url-status= dead }} [[Tadeusz Olszański]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20120401070710/http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene Svoboda party – the new phenomenon on the Ukrainian right-wing scene] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120401070710/http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/osw-commentary/2011-07-05/svoboda-party-new-phenomenon-ukrainian-rightwing-scene|date=April 1, 2012}}, [[Centre for Eastern Studies]] (July 5, 2011) as for example in [[Independence of Ukraine|pro-independence]] demonstrations in the late 1980s and in the logo of the (Ukrainian) [[Svoboda (political party)|Svoboda party]]. + ==Historical coats of arms== ===Kingdom of Ruthenia===

- +[[File:Jagiellonian tapestry 001 (2) crop.png|thumb|Jagiellonian tapestry]] [[File:Falco rusticolusAWP366AAA.jpg|alt=Hand-coloured engraving of two gyrfalcon; one diving in flight resembles the shape of the tryzub.|thumb|175px|The white [[gyrfalcon]], possibly the inspiration for Ukraine's trident.]] Historians have multiple interpretations on the origin of the symbol, including a [[falcon]], an arched bow, the [[Holy Trinity]], or an anchor.{{Cite book |last=Kassimeris |first=Christos |url=https://www.google.ca/books/edition/Exploring_the_cultural_ideological_and_e/7r_OCwAAQBAJ?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=rurik+trident&pg=PA23&printsec=frontcover |title=Exploring the Cultural, Ideological and Economic Legacies of Euro 2012 |publisher=Taylor & Francis |year=2016 |isbn=9781317602149 |pages=23}} Depictions of a flying falcon with a [[Christian cross]] above its head have been found in [[Old Ladoga]], the first seat of the Kievan Rurik dynasty,[http://chernov-trezin.narod.ru/GerbRurika.htm Coat of arms of Rurik found in Ladoga.] {{in lang|ru}} of Scandinavian lineage.[https://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/512996/Rurik Rurik (Norse leader)] Britannica Online Encyclopedia Such a falcon, along with a cross are also featured on the coins of [[Amlaíb mac Gofraid (died 941)|Olaf Guthfrithsson]], a Viking king of Dublin and Northumbria.

]] The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918, designed by [[Vasyl Krychevsky]]. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kyivan Rus]]. The first known archaeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on [[Symbols of the Rurikids|the seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. However, according to [[Omeljan Pritsak|Pritsak]], the stylized trident [[tamga]], or seal which was used by Rus rulers such as [[Sviatoslav I]] and [[Symbols of the Rurikids#Origins |similar tamgas]] that were found in ruins are [[Khazar]] in origin.Brook 154Franklin & Shepard 120–21Pritsak, ''Weights'' 78–79. It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince Volodymyr the Great (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54). The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition of the Mother of God|Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr (city)|Volodymyr]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -257,6 +257,13 @@
 
 On 25 August 2020 the Verkhovna Rada instructed the [[Shmyhal Government]] to get an official Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine adopted in time for the [[30th anniversary of Ukrainian independence]].<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> On the day of the 30th anniversary of Ukrainian independence, 24 August 2021, the Verkhovna Rada adopted a law in its first reading that establishes an official Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine with 257 votes.<ref name="CoatUkraine58339423"/>
 
+== Commonwealth of Nations ==
+Read more: Coat of arms of the Commonwealth of Nations
+
+Before the formation of the [[Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth|Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]], the coat of arms of the Kingdom of Russia in the symbolism of the [[List of Polish monarchs|Polish monarchs]] was represented by the coat of arms of the Kingdom of Rus. The coat of arms of the Kingdom of Rus (part of the Kingdom of Poland 1340-1434), later of the Voivodeship of Rus (1434-1772) was a golden crowned lion climbing a rock on a blue field.
+
+Belz (1462—1793), Podil (1434—1793), and Podlaskie Voivodeships (1513—1795) of the Kingdom of Poland had their own symbols.
+
 ==See also==
 {{Portal|Ukraine|Heraldry}}
 * [[Armorial of Ukraine]]

@@ -164,7 +164,7 @@
 ===Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic===
 
 {{Main|Emblem of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic}}
-The coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] was adopted on 14 March 1919, by the government of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic and subsequently modified on 7 November 1928, 30 January 1937, and 21 November 1949. The coat of arms of 1949 is based on the coat of arms of the [[Soviet Union]] and features the [[hammer and sickle]], the [[red star]], a [[sunrise]] and ears of wheat on its outer rims. The rising sun stands for the future of the Soviet Ukrainian nation, the star as well as the hammer and sickle for the victory of communism and the "worldwide socialist community of states".
+The coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] was adopted on 14 March 1919, by the government of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic and subsequently modified on 7 November 1928, 30 January 1937, and 21 November 1949. The coat of arms of 1949 is based on the coat of arms of the [[Soviet Union]] and features the [[hammer and sickle]] with a [[sunrise]] on a baroque styled shield crowned with the [[red star]], and having ears of wheat on its outer rims. The rising sun stands for the future of the Soviet Ukrainian nation, the star as well as the hammer and sickle for the victory of communism and the "worldwide socialist community of states".
 The banner bears the Soviet Union state motto ("Workers of the world, unite!") in both the Ukrainian and Russian languages or Ukrainian only on some editions of the emblem. The name of the [[union republic]] was shown as a Russian acronym on the first emblem edition, on the next two editions as a Ukrainian acronym, while the latest edition contained the actual word "Ukrainian". The latest edition of the emblem was the one crowned with the red star which was not featured on previous editions.
 
 After independence on 24 August 1991, Ukraine retained the Soviet emblem. The next year, in 1992, the emblem was changed to the present coat of arms of Ukraine, the tryzub (trident) coat of arms.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -27,7 +27,7 @@
 
 The '''coat of arms of [[Ukraine]]''' is a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. Officially referred to as the ''Emblem of the Royal State of Volodymyr the Great'',<ref>{{Cite book |last=Wolczuk |first=Kataryna |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jf0OEAAAQBAJ&dq=Emblem+of+the+Royal+State+of+Volodymyr+the+Great&pg=PA230 |title=The Moulding of Ukraine: The Constitutional Politics of State Formation |date=2001-12-01 |publisher=Central European University Press |isbn=978-615-5211-64-5 |language=en}}</ref> or, colloquially, the '''''tryzub''''' ({{lang-uk|тризуб}}, "trident"), the insignia derives from the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Volodymyr the Great]], the first [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]]. 
 
-The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992<ref>{{Cite web |title=Про Державний герб України |url=https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/go/2137-12 |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=Офіційний вебпортал парламенту України |language=uk}}</ref>, while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Cossack Hetmanate|Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).
+The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Про Державний герб України |url=https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/go/2137-12 |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=Офіційний вебпортал парламенту України |language=uk}}</ref> while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Cossack Hetmanate|Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).
 
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]]i, proposed to adopt it as a [[National symbols of Ukraine|national symbol]] (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalest]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a cossack carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 25 February 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -150,7 +150,7 @@
 '''Designs of the coat of arms of Ukraine by Heorhiy Narbut''' are projects of the State Coat of Arms of the [[Ukrainian State]] and the Great Coat of Arms of the Ukrainian State developed by the Ukrainian artist [[Heorhiy Narbut]] in 1918. Heorhiy Narbut took as a basis the national symbols of the hetman state of the Zaporizhzhia Army. On an octagonal blue shield, a Cossack dressed in gold ornamented robes was placed in the center.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Гуменюк |first=Тетяна Костянтинівна |date=2021-06-25 |title=ХОРЕОЛОГІЯ У ПРОСТОРІ СУЧАСНОГО МИСТЕЦТВОЗНАВСТВА |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.31866/2410-1176.44.2021.235447 |journal=Вісник КНУКіМ. Серія «Мистецтвознавство» |issue=44 |pages=242–247 |doi=10.31866/2410-1176.44.2021.235447 |s2cid=243172381 |issn=2616-4183}}</ref> Above the Cossack's shield rose a golden trident, the sign of Grand Duke Volodymyr. The [[Cossacks|Cossack]] was turned to the right, and around his shield was a silver cantush, painted in a floral baroque style. The trident gained popularity in the Ukrainian People's Republic, because it was depicted on the ruble coins introduced in December 1917.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=РУМ’ЯНЦЕВ |first=ВЯЧЕСЛАВ |date=2020 |title=Витоки, природа влади та правові засади Української держави гетьмана Павла Скоропадського |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.33498/louu-2020-01-225 |journal=Право України |issue=2020/01 |pages=225 |doi=10.33498/louu-2020-01-225 |s2cid=214314690 |issn=2310-323X}}</ref> The first coin of the Ukrainian People's Republic was 100 rubles. George Narbut used baroque elements and heraldic signs - the trident and coat of arms of the Kyiv Magistrate of the times of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania in the form of a crossbow. So the trident became a popular symbol and eventually turned into a small coat of arms of the Ukrainian People's Republic. Since January 22, 1919, the Trident was also used as the coat of arms of the Western region of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. It remained the coat of arms of the hetman state of [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]], as well as the [[Directorate of Ukraine]].
 
 ===Grand Duchy of Ruthenia (Archistrategos Mykhaïl)===
-The importance of the Kyiv region coat of arms with [[Archangel Michael]] known as Archistrategos Mykhaïl arose during discussion of the so-called 1658 [[treaty of Hadiach]] between the delegation of the Cossack Hetmanate and the Crown of Poland, that foresaw the transformation of the Commonwealth into the [[Polish–Lithuanian–Ruthenian Commonwealth]]. The coat of arms with Archangel Michael is often confused with symbol of the Kyiv City. Please note that before the Muscovite annexation of Ukrainian lands in 18th century (see "[[partitions of Poland]]"), the city had another symbol which was included by [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] in his proposal of the Ukrainian coat of arms.
+The importance of the Kyiv region coat of arms with [[Archangel Michael]] known as Archistrategos Mykhaïl arose during discussion of the so-called 1658 [[treaty of Hadiach]] between the delegation of the Cossack Hetmanate and the Crown of Poland, that foresaw the transformation of the Commonwealth into the [[Polish–Lithuanian–Ruthenian Commonwealth]]. The coat of arms with Archangel Michael is often confused with symbol of the Kyiv City. Note that before the Muscovite annexation of Ukrainian lands in 18th century (see "[[partitions of Poland]]"), the city had another symbol which was included by [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] in his proposal of the Ukrainian coat of arms.

@@ -107,7 +107,7 @@
 
 ===Kingdom of Ruthenia===
 [[File:Alex K Yuri Boleslav seal 2.png|thumb|150px|The seal of King [[Bolesław-Jerzy II|George-Boleslav]] denoting a horse rider with a lion on the coat of arms]]
-[[File:Coins 1382.png|thumb|150px|Coin of Galicia after the Polish annexation (Moneta Russie)]]
+[[File:Coins 1382.png|thumb|150px|Coin of Galicia after the Polish annexation (1382)]]
 The coat of arms for the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia|Kingdom of Ruthenia]] ({{lang-la|Regnum Russiæ}}) and [[Duchy of Galicia–Volhynia]] has existed since the 12th century. It consisted of a [[Lion (heraldry)|lion]] on an azure [[heater shield]].<ref name="sprvar190711">[https://varta.com.ua/news/lviv/1206386 History of Galician coat of arms: jackdaw, lion or something totally different (Історія галицького герба: галка, лев, чи щось кардинально інше?)]. Spravzhnia Varta. 11 June 2019</ref> The [[Ruthenian lion]] first appears in the seal of the Ruthenian king [[Yuri II Boleslav|Yurii I]], dated to the beginning of the XIV century. There is an image of a monarch on a throne, and on the reverse, an armed horseman holding a shield with a lion on his hind leg, an example of [[Equestrian seal|equestrian seals]] common in Europe at the time. On the seal, there is an inscription in Latin: "Sigillum Domini Georgi Regis Rusie" (Seal of the owner of George-Yuri, King of Ruthenia), on the back: "Sigillum Domini Georgi Ducis Ladimerie" (seal of the owner of George-Yuri, prince of Lodomeria). 
 
 On the seal of his son [[Leo I of Galicia|Lev II]], only a lion without a rider is depicted. The animal stands on its hind legs and reverses to the left.

 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]]i, proposed to adopt it as a [[National symbols of Ukraine|national symbol]] (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalest]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a cossack carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 25 February 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].
 
 During the Soviet period of 1919–1991 and independence between 1991 and 1992, the state symbols were consistent with the [[Russian SFSR]] and the [[Soviet Union]] – a [[hammer and sickle]] over the rising sun.

-The '''coat of arms of [[Ukraine]]''' is a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. Officially referred to as the ''Emblem of the Royal State of Volodymyr the Great'',<ref>{{Cite book |last=Wolczuk |first=Kataryna |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jf0OEAAAQBAJ&dq=Emblem+of+the+Royal+State+of+Volodymyr+the+Great&pg=PA230 |title=The Moulding of Ukraine: The Constitutional Politics of State Formation |date=2001-12-01 |publisher=Central European University Press |isbn=978-615-5211-64-5 |language=en}}</ref> or, colloquially, the '''''tryzub''''' ({{lang-uk|тризуб}}, "trident"), the insignia derives from the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Volodymyr the Great]], the first [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]]. 
+The '''coat of arms of Ukraine''' is a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. Officially referred to as the ''Emblem of the Royal State of Volodymyr the Great'',<ref>{{Cite book |last=Wolczuk |first=Kataryna |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jf0OEAAAQBAJ&dq=Emblem+of+the+Royal+State+of+Volodymyr+the+Great&pg=PA230 |title=The Moulding of Ukraine: The Constitutional Politics of State Formation |date=2001-12-01 |publisher=Central European University Press |isbn=978-615-5211-64-5 |language=en}}</ref> or, colloquially, the '''''tryzub''''' ({{lang-uk|тризуб}}, "trident"), the insignia derives from the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Volodymyr the Great]], the first [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]]. 
 
 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Про Державний герб України |url=https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/go/2137-12 |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=Офіційний вебпортал парламенту України |language=uk}}</ref> while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Cossack Hetmanate|Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).

@@ -27,7 +27,7 @@
 
 The '''coat of arms of [[Ukraine]]''' is a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|gold]] [[trident]]. Officially referred to as the ''Emblem of the Royal State of Volodymyr the Great'',<ref>{{Cite book |last=Wolczuk |first=Kataryna |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jf0OEAAAQBAJ&dq=Emblem+of+the+Royal+State+of+Volodymyr+the+Great&pg=PA230 |title=The Moulding of Ukraine: The Constitutional Politics of State Formation |date=2001-12-01 |publisher=Central European University Press |isbn=978-615-5211-64-5 |language=en}}</ref> or, colloquially, the '''''tryzub''''' ({{lang-uk|тризуб}}, "trident"), the insignia derives from the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Volodymyr the Great]], the first [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]]. 
 
-The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Про Державний герб України |url=https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/go/2137-12 |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=Офіційний вебпортал парламенту України |language=uk}}</ref> while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet{{When?|date=July 2023}} officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of [[Cossack Hetmanate|Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).
+The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Про Державний герб України |url=https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/go/2137-12 |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=Офіційний вебпортал парламенту України |language=uk}}</ref> while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet{{When?|date=July 2023}} officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of the [[Cossack Hetmanate|Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).
 
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]]i, proposed to adopt it as a [[National symbols of Ukraine|national symbol]] (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalest]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a cossack carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 25 February 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].
llm_output:
Removed a line about the small coat of arms being officially adopted on 19 February 1992 and its design details.

Not Weaponised – The change does not introduce or remove any language that could be interpreted as weaponising cultural heritage. It appears to be a straightforward edit without political implications.

+The '''coat of arms of [[Ukraine]]''' is a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|golden]] [[trident]]. Officially referred to as the ''Emblem of the Royal State of Volodymyr the Great'',<ref>{{Cite book |last=Wolczuk |first=Kataryna |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jf0OEAAAQBAJ&dq=Emblem+of+the+Royal+State+of+Volodymyr+the+Great&pg=PA230 |title=The Moulding of Ukraine: The Constitutional Politics of State Formation |date=2001-12-01 |publisher=Central European University Press |isbn=978-615-5211-64-5 |language=en}}</ref> or, colloquially, the '''''tryzub''''' {{IPA-uk|trɪˈzub|}} ({{lang-uk|тризуб}}, "trident"), the insignia derives from the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seal-trident]] of [[Volodymyr the Great]], the first [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]]. 
 
 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Про Державний герб України |url=https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/go/2137-12 |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=Офіційний вебпортал парламенту України |language=uk}}</ref> while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet{{When?|date=July 2023}} officially adopted. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|Presidential Standard]] of Ukraine. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of the [[Cossack Hetmanate|Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).

 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]]i, proposed to adopt it as a [[National symbols of Ukraine|national symbol]] (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalest]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a cossack carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine).  The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]]i, proposed to adopt it as a [[National symbols of Ukraine|national symbol]] (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalest]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a cossack carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine).  ====Designs by Heorhiy Narbut====
 [[File:Alex K Ukrainska Derzhava.svg|thumb|Coat of arms sketch by Heorhiy Narbut for the Ukrainian State in 1918 (did not have time to approve, because the hetman renounced power)]]
-'''Designs of the coat of arms of Ukraine by Heorhiy Narbut''' are projects of the State Coat of Arms of the [[Ukrainian State]] and the Great Coat of Arms of the Ukrainian State developed by the Ukrainian artist [[Heorhiy Narbut]] in 1918. Heorhiy Narbut took as a basis the national symbols of the hetman state of the Zaporizhzhia Army. On an octagonal blue shield, a Cossack dressed in gold ornamented robes was placed in the center.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Гуменюк |first=Тетяна Костянтинівна |date=2021-06-25 |title=ХОРЕОЛОГІЯ У ПРОСТОРІ СУЧАСНОГО МИСТЕЦТВОЗНАВСТВА |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.31866/2410-1176.44.2021.235447 |journal=Вісник КНУКіМ. Серія «Мистецтвознавство» |issue=44 |pages=242–247 |doi=10.31866/2410-1176.44.2021.235447 |s2cid=243172381 |issn=2616-4183}}</ref> Above the Cossack's shield rose a golden trident, the sign of Grand Duke Volodymyr. The [[Cossacks|Cossack]] was turned to the right, and around his shield was a silver cantush, painted in a floral baroque style. The trident gained popularity in the Ukrainian People's Republic, because it was depicted on the ruble coins introduced in December 1917.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=РУМ’ЯНЦЕВ |first=ВЯЧЕСЛАВ |date=2020 |title=Витоки, природа влади та правові засади Української держави гетьмана Павла Скоропадського |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.33498/louu-2020-01-225 |journal=Право України |issue=2020/01 |pages=225 |doi=10.33498/louu-2020-01-225 |s2cid=214314690 |issn=2310-323X}}</ref> The first coin of the Ukrainian People's Republic was 100 rubles. George Narbut used baroque elements and heraldic signs - the trident and coat of arms of the Kyiv Magistrate of the times of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania in the form of a crossbow. So the trident became a popular symbol and eventually turned into a small coat of arms of the Ukrainian People's Republic. Since January 22, 1919, the Trident was also used as the coat of arms of the Western region of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. It remained the coat of arms of the hetman state of [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]], as well as the [[Directorate of Ukraine]].
+'''Designs of the coat of arms of Ukraine by Heorhiy Narbut''' are projects of the State Coat of Arms of the [[Ukrainian State]] and the Great Coat of Arms of the Ukrainian State developed by the Ukrainian artist [[Heorhiy Narbut]] in 1918. Heorhiy Narbut took as a basis the national symbols of the hetman state of the Zaporizhzhia Army. On an octagonal blue shield, a Cossack dressed in gold ornamented robes was placed in the center.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Гуменюк |first=Тетяна Костянтинівна |date=2021-06-25 |title=ХОРЕОЛОГІЯ У ПРОСТОРІ СУЧАСНОГО МИСТЕЦТВОЗНАВСТВА |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.31866/2410-1176.44.2021.235447 |journal=Вісник КНУКіМ. Серія «Мистецтвознавство» |issue=44 |pages=242–247 |doi=10.31866/2410-1176.44.2021.235447 |s2cid=243172381 |issn=2616-4183|doi-access=free }}</ref> Above the Cossack's shield rose a golden trident, the sign of Grand Duke Volodymyr. The [[Cossacks|Cossack]] was turned to the right, and around his shield was a silver cantush, painted in a floral baroque style. The trident gained popularity in the Ukrainian People's Republic, because it was depicted on the ruble coins introduced in December 1917.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=РУМ’ЯНЦЕВ |first=ВЯЧЕСЛАВ |date=2020 |title=Витоки, природа влади та правові засади Української держави гетьмана Павла Скоропадського |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.33498/louu-2020-01-225 |journal=Право України |issue=2020/01 |pages=225 |doi=10.33498/louu-2020-01-225 |s2cid=214314690 |issn=2310-323X}}</ref> The first coin of the Ukrainian People's Republic was 100 rubles. George Narbut used baroque elements and heraldic signs - the trident and coat of arms of the Kyiv Magistrate of the times of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania in the form of a crossbow. So the trident became a popular symbol and eventually turned into a small coat of arms of the Ukrainian People's Republic. Since January 22, 1919, the Trident was also used as the coat of arms of the Western region of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. It remained the coat of arms of the hetman state of [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]], as well as the [[Directorate of Ukraine]].
 
 ===Grand Duchy of Ruthenia (Archistrategos Mykhaïl)===
 The importance of the Kyiv region coat of arms with [[Archangel Michael]] known as Archistrategos Mykhaïl arose during discussion of the so-called 1658 [[treaty of Hadiach]] between the delegation of the Cossack Hetmanate and the Crown of Poland, that foresaw the transformation of the Commonwealth into the [[Polish–Lithuanian–Ruthenian Commonwealth]]. The coat of arms with Archangel Michael is often confused with symbol of the Kyiv City. Note that before the Muscovite annexation of Ukrainian lands in 18th century (see "[[partitions of Poland]]"), the city had another symbol which was included by [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] in his proposal of the Ukrainian coat of arms.

George Narbut used baroque elements and heraldic signs - the trident and coat of arms of the Kyiv Magistrate of the times of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania in the form of a crossbow. So the trident became a popular symbol and eventually turned into a small coat of arms of the Ukrainian People's Republic. Since January 22, 1919, the Trident was also used as the coat of arms of the Western region of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. It remained the coat of arms of the hetman state of [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]], as well as the [[Directorate of Ukraine]].
 
 ===Grand Duchy of Ruthenia (Archistrategos Mykhaïl)===
 The importance of the Kyiv region coat of arms with [[Archangel Michael]] known as Archistrategos Mykhaïl arose during discussion of the so-called 1658 [[treaty of Hadiach]] between the delegation of the Cossack Hetmanate and the Crown of Poland, that foresaw the transformation of the Commonwealth into the [[Polish–Lithuanian–Ruthenian Commonwealth]]. The coat of arms with Archangel Michael is often confused with symbol of the Kyiv City. Note that before the Muscovite annexation of Ukrainian lands in 18th century (see "[[partitions of Poland]]"), the city had another symbol which was included by [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] in his proposal of the Ukrainian coat of arms.
comment: /* Designs by Heorhiy Narbut */ fixed name of the currency, UPR had its own currency

-The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918, designed by [[Vasyl Krychevsky]]. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kyivan Rus]]. The first known archaeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on [[Symbols of the Rurikids|the seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. However, according to [[Omeljan Pritsak|Pritsak]], the stylized trident [[tamga]], or seal which was used by Rus rulers such as [[Sviatoslav I]] and [[Symbols of the Rurikids#Origins |similar tamgas]] that were found in ruins are [[Khazar]] in origin.<ref>Brook 154</ref><ref>Franklin & Shepard 120–21</ref><ref>Pritsak, ''Weights'' 78–79.</ref> 
+The modern "Trinity" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918, designed by [[Vasyl Krychevsky]]. The design has precedents in seals of the [[Kyivan Rus]]. The first known archaeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on [[Symbols of the Rurikids|the seals]] of the [[Rurik dynasty]]. However, according to [[Omeljan Pritsak|Pritsak]], the stylized Trinity [[tamga]], or seal which was used by Rus rulers such as [[Sviatoslav I]] and [[Symbols of the Rurikids#Origins |similar tamgas]] that were found in ruins are [[Khazar]] in origin.<ref>Brook 154</ref><ref>Franklin & Shepard 120–21</ref><ref>Pritsak, ''Weights'' 78–79.</ref> 
 
 It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by Prince Volodymyr the Great (980–1015), who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–19) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54). The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition of the Mother of God|Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr (city)|Volodymyr]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.

 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Про Державний герб України |url=https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/go/2137-12 |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=Офіційний вебпортал парламенту України |language=uk}}</ref> while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted as of February 2024. -The coat of arms for the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia|Kingdom of Ruthenia]] ({{lang-la|Regnum Russiæ}}) and [[Duchy of Galicia–Volhynia]] has existed since the 12th century. It consisted of a [[Lion (heraldry)|lion]] on an azure [[heater shield]].<ref name="sprvar190711">[https://varta.com.ua/news/lviv/1206386 History of Galician coat of arms: jackdaw, lion or something totally different (Історія галицького герба: галка, лев, чи щось кардинально інше?)]. Spravzhnia Varta. 11 June 2019</ref> The [[Ruthenian lion]] first appears in the seal of the Ruthenian king [[Yuri II Boleslav|Yurii I]], dated to the beginning of the XIV century. There is an image of a monarch on a throne, and on the reverse, an armed horseman holding a shield with a lion on his hind leg, an example of [[Equestrian seal|equestrian seals]] common in Europe at the time. On the seal, there is an inscription in Latin: "Sigillum Domini Georgi Regis Rusie" (Seal of the owner of George-Yuri, King of Ruthenia), on the back: "Sigillum Domini Georgi Ducis Ladimerie" (seal of the owner of George-Yuri, prince of Lodomeria).

Spravzhnia Varta. 11 June 2019</ref> The [[Ruthenian lion]] first appears in the seal of the Ruthenian king [[Yuri II Boleslav|Yurii I]], dated to the beginning of the XIV century. There is an image of a monarch on a throne, and on the reverse, an armed horseman holding a shield with a lion on his hind leg, an example of [[Equestrian seal|equestrian seals]] common in Europe at the time. On the seal, there is an inscription in Latin: "Sigillum Domini Georgi Regis Rusie" (Seal of the owner of George-Yuri, King of Ruthenia), on the back: "Sigillum Domini Georgi Ducis Ladimerie" (seal of the owner of George-Yuri, prince of Lodomeria). 
 
 On the seal of his son [[Leo I of Galicia|Lev II]], only a lion without a rider is depicted. The animal stands on its hind legs and reverses to the left.

+===Cossack Hetmanate===
 {{Main|Cossack with musket}}
 
 A Cossack with a musket was an emblem of the [[Zaporizhian Host]] and later the state emblem of the Hetmanate and the [[Ukrainian State]]. The origin of the emblem is uncertain, while its first records date back to 1592. On the initiative of [[Pyotr Rumyantsev]], the emblem was phased out and replaced by the Russian double-headed eagle in 1767.

 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]]i, proposed to adopt it as a [[National symbols of Ukraine|national symbol]] (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalest]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a cossack carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). +The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918, designed by [[Vasyl Krychevsky]]. The design has precedents in the seals of [[Kievan Rus']]. The first known archaeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurikids|Rurik dynasty]]. However, according to [[Omeljan Pritsak|Pritsak]], the stylized trident [[tamga]], or seal which was used by rulers such as [[Sviatoslav I]] and [[Symbols of the Rurikids#Origins |similar tamgas]] that were found in ruins are [[Khazar]] in origin.<ref>Brook 154</ref><ref>Franklin & Shepard 120–21</ref><ref>Pritsak, ''Weights'' 78–79.</ref> 
+
+It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by [[Vladimir the Great]] ({{reigned|980|1015}}), also known as Volodymyr, who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–1019) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54). The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition of the Mother of God|Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr (city)|Volodymyr]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.

The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of the [[Cossack Hetmanate|Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).
+The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Про Державний герб України |url=https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/go/2137-12 |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=Офіційний вебпортал парламенту України |language=uk}}</ref> while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted as of March 2024. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|presidential standard]]. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of the [[Cossack Hetmanate|Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).
 
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]]i, proposed to adopt it as a [[National symbols of Ukraine|national symbol]] (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalest]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a cossack carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 25 February 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].

+In 1917, President of the [[Central Rada]] [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] proposed the Great Coat of Arms in the form of a single shield topped by a dove with olive branch. The shield was split five ways. At its center there was a smaller shield depicting a [[plough]] as a symbol of productive peaceful work surrounded by ancient state symbols of Ukraine: the princely arms of [[Vladimir the Great]] or Volodymyr the Great (''tryzub''), [[Pogoń Litewska|Litvin Pogon]] with a golden lion, [[cossack with musket]], the crossbow of Kyiv and the lion of Lviv.
+
+In the current [[Constitution of Ukraine]] there is a constitutional provisions for the establishment of a Great Coat of Arms of Ukraine,<ref>[[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]].</ref> although it was never officially adopted<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> and was published in various heraldic sources. In this variant, the shield is supported by a lion from the [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galician]] Coat of Arms on the left and a cossack in traditional dress, wielding a [[musket]], the symbol of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] on the right. The Coat of Arms is crowned with the crown of Volodymyr the Great, symbolizing Ukrainian [[sovereignty]] and decorated with [[viburnum]] and wheat at the bottom.
 
 Since [[Ukrainian independence]] in 1991 four attempts by the [[Ukrainian government]] to create an official Great Coat of Arms have failed.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine"/> The official adoption of the Great Coat of Arms has to be endorsed (in a second reading<ref name="CoatUkraine58339423">{{in lang|uk}} [https://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/features-58339423 "Two left paws and a fake crown". What is the Great Emblem and what Zelensky does not like the trident], [[BBC Ukrainian]] (26 August 2021)</ref>) by a two-thirds majority vote (300 votes) in the [[Verkhovna Rada]], the Ukrainian parliament.<ref name="7264081CoatUkraine">{{in lang|uk}} [https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2020/08/25/7264081/ The government will create a large coat of arms of Ukraine], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (25 August 2020)</ref>

On an octagonal blue shield, a Cossack dressed in gold ornamented robes was placed in the center.{{Cite journal |last=Гуменюк |first=Тетяна Костянтинівна |date=2021-06-25 |title=ХОРЕОЛОГІЯ У ПРОСТОРІ СУЧАСНОГО МИСТЕЦТВОЗНАВСТВА |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.31866/2410-1176.44.2021.235447 |journal=Вісник КНУКіМ. The [[Cossacks|Cossack]] was turned to the right, and around his shield was a silver cantush, painted in a floral baroque style. George Narbut used baroque elements and heraldic signs - the trident and coat of arms of the Kyiv Magistrate of the times of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania in the form of a crossbow. So the trident became a popular symbol and eventually turned into a small coat of arms of the Ukrainian People's Republic. Since January 22, 1919, the Trident was also used as the coat of arms of the Western region of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. It remained the coat of arms of the hetman state of [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]], as well as the [[Directorate of Ukraine]]. +[[File:Alex K Ukrainska Derzhava.svg|thumb|150px|Coat of arms sketch by Heorhiy Narbut for the Ukrainian State in 1918 (did not have time to approve, because the hetman renounced power)]] +Designs of the coat of arms of Ukraine by Heorhiy Narbut are projects of the State Coat of Arms of the [[Ukrainian State]] and the Great Coat of Arms of the Ukrainian State developed by the Ukrainian artist [[Heorhiy Narbut]] in 1918. George Narbut used baroque elements and heraldic signs - the trident and coat of arms of the Kyiv Magistrate of the times of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania in the form of a crossbow. Since January 22, 1919, the Trident was also used as the coat of arms of the Western region of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. +The '''coat of arms of Ukraine''' is a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|golden]] [[trident]]. It is colloquially known as the '''''tryzub''''' ({{lang-uk|тризуб}}, {{IPA-uk|trɪˈzub|pron}}, {{lit|trident}}). 
 
 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Про Державний герб України |url=https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/go/2137-12 |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=Офіційний вебпортал парламенту України |language=uk}}</ref> while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted as of March 2024. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|presidential standard]]. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of the [[Cossack Hetmanate|Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).

 On the seal of his son [[Leo I of Galicia|Lev II]], only a lion without a rider is depicted. The animal stands on its hind legs and reverses to the left.
 
-Figures of lions as symbols of Ruthenia are found on the silver coins of the Lithuanian prince Lubart, the last ruler of the Kingdom of Ruthenia (1340–1383), and his son Fedor (1384–1387). We see the same motive on Ruthenian money, the issue of which continued during the reign in Ruthenia of the Polish king Casimir III (1349–1370), the Hungarian king Louis (1370–1372, 1378–1382) and his governor, Prince of Opolsk Vladislav (1372–1378).
+Figures of lions as symbols of Ruthenia are found on the silver coins of the Lithuanian prince Lubart, the last ruler of the Kingdom of Ruthenia (1340–1383), and his son Fedor (1384–1387). We see the same motive on Ruthenian money, the issue of which continued during the reign in Ruthenia of the Polish king Casimir III (1349–1370), the Hungarian king Louis (1370–1372, 1378–1382) and his governor, Prince of Opole Vladislav (1372–1378).
 
 After the occupation of Eastern Galicia by the Kingdom of Poland as a result of the [[Galicia–Volhynia Wars]], the coat of arms with many changes was adopted as part of the [[Ruthenian Voivodeship]] ({{lang-la|Palatinatus russiae}}, Ruthenian Palatine). It was abandoned with [[partition of Poland]] and annexation of territory by the [[Austrian Empire]]. At the end of [[World War I]] and dissolution of [[Austria-Hungary]], the [[Western Ukrainian People's Republic]] revived the coat of arms. With the annexation of the West Ukraine by Poland again in 1918 and later the [[Soviet Union]], the gold lion symbol became the coat of arms for the city of [[Lviv]].

 ==Description==
-[[File:Ruriks crests1.png|thumb|Signs of the Rurikovichs]]
 The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918, designed by [[Vasyl Krychevsky]]. The design has precedents in the seals of [[Kievan Rus']]. The first known archaeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurikids|Rurik dynasty]]. However, according to [[Omeljan Pritsak|Pritsak]], the stylized trident [[tamga]], or seal which was used by rulers such as [[Sviatoslav I]] and [[Symbols of the Rurikids#Origins |similar tamgas]] that were found in ruins are [[Khazar]] in origin.<ref>Brook 154</ref><ref>Franklin & Shepard 120–21</ref><ref>Pritsak, ''Weights'' 78–79.</ref> 
 
 It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by [[Vladimir the Great]] ({{reigned|980|1015}}), also known as Volodymyr, who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–1019) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54). The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition of the Mother of God|Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr (city)|Volodymyr]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.

@@ -33,10 +33,10 @@
 The trident was not thought of as a national symbol until 1917, when one of the most prominent Ukrainian historians, [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]]i, proposed to adopt it as a [[National symbols of Ukraine|national symbol]] (alongside other variants, including an [[arbalest]], a [[bow (weapon)|bow]] or a cossack carrying a [[musket]], i.e. images that carried considerable historical and cultural and heraldic significance for Ukraine). On 25 February 1918, the [[Central Rada]] (parliament) adopted it as the coat of arms of the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].
 
 During the Soviet period of 1919–1991 and independence between 1991 and 1992, the state symbols were consistent with the [[Russian SFSR]] and the [[Soviet Union]] – a [[hammer and sickle]] over the rising sun.
+
+==Description==
 [[File:Stamp of Ukraine s26.jpg|thumb|Ukrposhta stamp "The first [[anniversary]] of the [[Declaration of Independence of Ukraine|independence of Ukraine]]. State Coat of Arms and State Flag of Ukraine". 1992]]
-
-==Description==
-[[File:Falco rusticolusAWP366AAA.jpg|alt=Hand-coloured engraving of two gyrfalcon; one diving in flight resembles the shape of the tryzub.|thumb|175px|The white [[gyrfalcon]], possibly the inspiration for Ukraine's trident.]]
+[[File:Falco rusticolusAWP366AAA.jpg|alt=Hand-coloured engraving of two gyrfalcon; one diving in flight resembles the shape of the tryzub.|thumb|The white [[gyrfalcon]], possibly the inspiration for the trident.]]
 The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918, designed by [[Vasyl Krychevsky]]. The design has precedents in the seals of [[Kievan Rus']]. The first known archaeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurikids|Rurik dynasty]]. However, according to [[Omeljan Pritsak|Pritsak]], the stylized trident [[tamga]], or seal which was used by rulers such as [[Sviatoslav I]] and [[Symbols of the Rurikids#Origins |similar tamgas]] that were found in ruins are [[Khazar]] in origin.<ref>Brook 154</ref><ref>Franklin & Shepard 120–21</ref><ref>Pritsak, ''Weights'' 78–79.</ref> 
 
 It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by [[Vladimir the Great]] ({{reigned|980|1015}}), also known as Volodymyr, who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–1019) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54). The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition of the Mother of God|Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr (city)|Volodymyr]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.

+The '''coat of arms of Ukraine''' is a blue [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|shield]] with a [[Gold (color)|golden]] [[trident]]. It is colloquially known as the '''''tryzub''''' ({{langx|uk|тризуб}}, {{IPA|uk|trɪˈzub|pron}}, {{lit|trident}}). 
 
 The small coat of arms was officially adopted on 19 February 1992,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Про Державний герб України |url=https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/go/2137-12 |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=Офіційний вебпортал парламенту України |language=uk}}</ref> while [[Constitution of Ukraine|constitutional]] provisions exist for establishing the great coat of arms, which is not yet officially adopted as of March 2024. The small coat of arms was designed by [[Andriy Grechylo]], Oleksii Kokhan, and Ivan Turetskyi. It appears on the [[Flag of the President of Ukraine|presidential standard]]. Blue-coloured tridents are considered to be an irregular representation by the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]]. The greater coat of arms which has not been adopted consists of the small coat of arms and the coat of arms of the [[Cossack Hetmanate|Zaporizhian Host]] ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], Article 20).

@@ -115,7 +115,7 @@
 
 Figures of lions as symbols of Ruthenia are found on the silver coins of the Lithuanian prince Lubart, the last ruler of the Kingdom of Ruthenia (1340–1383), and his son Fedor (1384–1387). We see the same motive on Ruthenian money, the issue of which continued during the reign in Ruthenia of the Polish king Casimir III (1349–1370), the Hungarian king Louis (1370–1372, 1378–1382) and his governor, Prince of Opole Vladislav (1372–1378).
 
-After the occupation of Eastern Galicia by the Kingdom of Poland as a result of the [[Galicia–Volhynia Wars]], the coat of arms with many changes was adopted as part of the [[Ruthenian Voivodeship]] ({{lang-la|Palatinatus russiae}}, Ruthenian Palatine). It was abandoned with [[partition of Poland]] and annexation of territory by the [[Austrian Empire]]. At the end of [[World War I]] and dissolution of [[Austria-Hungary]], the [[Western Ukrainian People's Republic]] revived the coat of arms. With the annexation of the West Ukraine by Poland again in 1918 and later the [[Soviet Union]], the gold lion symbol became the coat of arms for the city of [[Lviv]].
+After the occupation of Eastern Galicia by the Kingdom of Poland as a result of the [[Galicia–Volhynia Wars]], the coat of arms with many changes was adopted as part of the [[Ruthenian Voivodeship]] ({{langx|la|Palatinatus russiae}}, Ruthenian Palatine). It was abandoned with [[partition of Poland]] and annexation of territory by the [[Austrian Empire]]. At the end of [[World War I]] and dissolution of [[Austria-Hungary]], the [[Western Ukrainian People's Republic]] revived the coat of arms. With the annexation of the West Ukraine by Poland again in 1918 and later the [[Soviet Union]], the gold lion symbol became the coat of arms for the city of [[Lviv]].

 ==Description==
 [[File:Stamp of Ukraine s26.jpg|thumb|Ukrposhta stamp "The first [[anniversary]] of the [[Declaration of Independence of Ukraine|independence of Ukraine]]. State Coat of Arms and State Flag of Ukraine". 1992]]
 [[File:Falco rusticolusAWP366AAA.jpg|alt=Hand-coloured engraving of two gyrfalcon; one diving in flight resembles the shape of the tryzub.|thumb|The white [[gyrfalcon]], possibly the inspiration for the trident.]]
-The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918, designed by [[Vasyl Krychevsky]]. The design has precedents in the seals of [[Kievan Rus']]. The first known archaeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurikids|Rurik dynasty]].
+The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918, designed by [[Vasyl Krychevsky]]. The design has precedents in the seals of [[Kievan Rus']]. The first known archaeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurikids|Rurik dynasty]]. However, according to [[Omeljan Pritsak|Pritsak]], the stylized trident [[tamga]], or seal which was used by rulers such as [[Sviatoslav I]] and [[Symbols of the Rurikids#Origins |similar tamgas]] that were found in ruins are [[Khazar]] in origin.<ref>Brook 154</ref><ref>Franklin & Shepard 120–21</ref><ref>Pritsak, ''Weights'' 78–79.</ref> 
 
 It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by [[Vladimir the Great]] ({{reigned|980|1015}}), also known as Volodymyr, who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–1019) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54). The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition of the Mother of God|Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr (city)|Volodymyr]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.

+The modern "trident" symbol was adopted as the coat of arms of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in February 1918, designed by [[Vasyl Krychevsky]]. The design has precedents in the seals of [[Kievan Rus']]. The first known archaeological and historical evidence of this symbol can be found on the [[Symbols of the Rurikids|seals]] of the [[Rurikids|Rurik dynasty]].
 
 It was stamped on the gold and silver coins issued by [[Vladimir the Great]] ({{reigned|980|1015}}), also known as Volodymyr, who might have inherited the symbol from his ancestors (such as [[Sviatoslav I]]) as a dynastic coat of arms, and he passed it on to his sons, [[Sviatopolk I]] (1015–1019) and [[Yaroslav the Wise]] (1019–54). The symbol was also found on the bricks of the [[Church of the Tithes]] in [[Kyiv]], the tiles of the [[Dormition of the Mother of God|Dormition]] Cathedral in [[Volodymyr (city)|Volodymyr]], and the stones of other churches, castles, and palaces. There are many examples of it used on ceramics, weapons, rings, medallions, seals, and manuscripts.

@@ -56,11 +56,11 @@
 Falconry has been a royal sport in Europe for centuries. The [[gyrfalcon]] (known also as ''Norwegian falcon'') was considered a royal bird and is mentioned (''ukr.: рарог'') in one of the earliest epics of [[Ruthenia]], the 12th century poem [[The Tale of Igor's Campaign]].
 
 Later images of the trident ("tryzub") among the Rurikids resemble more a [[bident]] or the letter "[[У]]", which also in the modern [[Cyrillic alphabet]] denotes the sound "u" as in "Ukraine" (though the Cyrillic alphabet at the time did not use this letter individually, using the digraph ОУ/ОѴ or its monogram Ꙋ instead).
